This honestly has got to be one of my least favorite otome games I've played. Most of the characters are bland, some of the art has bad anatomy, and the story is pretty lackluster. Because I really enjoy otome games I played through all of the main routes and endings, but I don't feel much interest in doing the extra content or getting all of the endings (keep in mind that I usually like clearing ALL endings in a game). One of the most annoying parts is how Orion takes over what you think and do most of the time, making you an incredibly silent and boring protagonist. The story isn't anything special and I never got really attached to any of the guys, as most of them had one note personalities and the voice acting for them made them sound like they were constantly bored. There are also lots of unwarranted dark themes in this story, such as hints of Stockholm syndrome, sexual harassment, violent bullying, etc, and I feel like it isn't written maturely enough to handle the subjects. 

If you are a BIG fan of otome games then it's alright to play this game. Maybe there will be a guy you really enjoy the route of (I personally tolerated Kent's the most) but as a whole package, it's lacking in general. Only play this if you like this genre of gaming but if you aren't, this is something you should probably skip.

39068491.review:
I have a fair bit of experience with visual novels and dating sims, and I can say honeslty that Amnesia Memories is the best Otome visual novel I have ever played and it is well worth full price, but often goes on sale.

Instead of throwing the heroine into the mix and having four or five guys fight over her, Amnesia allows you to choose between four alternate realities, each representing the guy you will be pursuing - with a fifth one unlocked when you playthrough them all. For each world, there is about four endings, so there is a huge amount of replayability here. With lots of mystery and surprised, fans of Doki Doki Literature Club will really like this.  

What original drew me to it, was knowing that the heroine could die and that some of the endings were toxic (but you should try to avoid reading spoilers for the full experience), and with at least two bad endings for each world, I definitely was given the messed up story lines I expected. Because there is so much variation and such a large possibility of dying, if you like receiving acheivements, I recommend using a guide. There are quire a few good walk throughs, and if you save at that right points, you can save yourself time and from rereading the text four times (also keep in mind you can press S to skip anything you have already read). A guide also comes in handy if you're gunning for certain endings, especially when some of the choices you have to make to reach those endings often feel unintuitive or going against everything you have ever learnt about romance [spoiler] *cough cough* literally everything involving Toma. [/spoiler] 

While it doesn't matter which world you choose first, I recommend chosing Clover World first; Kent's good storyline is the least popular but it is also the most straight forward. Playing it gives you a good grip on the style and characters  [spoiler] not to mention, Kent is bae and I found his good ending to be the most romantic... just remember to keep a calculator handy if you aren't good at math [/spoiler]

The characters aree great and are very real. Unlike some otome games which make idealized archetypical characters, Amnesia boys have major flaws. When getting to know them, it's things that you work through with them and sometimes things you can't get past. This really humanized the characters for me, and at times made me go against the guides and completely change the ending I was heading towards. 

There are a few cons. One, the female lead really has no personality since most of her thoughts are spoken through Orion (basically a spirit stuck in your memories), and when one is suggested, she seems really unlikeable. I think this is probably done so that we the players can insert our own personality on to her, but it honestly is a pet peeve of mine within the genre. Two, everyone is really sex negative, but especially other women and the romantic leads towards the main character. Three, [spoiler] I often wanted to date Sawa more than the guy I was supposed to want to date... Bi people problems	[/spoiler]

The game is really well done, with loads of replayability and mini games. I urge everyone even the least bit visual novels to try this at some point.

The tag of "visual novel" feels like a more accurate description of this game as there is a lot of reading (I don't see this as a bad point but some might because there actually is a decent amount) and not a whole lot of involvement from the player's character (the protagonist's dialogue is relatively short and infrequent), however, which I found to be slightly disappointing as I feel these games should be a bit more immersive to make the story really hit home with the player. It's also not very clear at all which dialogue is suitable to choose for the ending the player wants to receieve most of the time (some of the dialogue options seem tremendously similar and it started to feel a little bit repetitive in some places). You might want to check out some walkthroughs if you're going into this game trying to get a certain ending. If you enjoy or don't mind mostly reading to get into a story, then this game is definitely made with a player like you in mind.

38815964.review:
Amnesia™: Memories is WILD. I thoroughly enjoyed this game, playing through each route and the plethora of endings (good, normal and bad) for each world, and clocking up an impressive 35.7 hours of gameplay - definitely the most I've played on a visual novel before.

Five fully-fleshed out, divergent storylines with a multitude of interesting characters - including five very eligible love interests - who have their own independant histories and plots that differ from world to world is an incredible feat from what I've seen of visual novels/otomes so far. The art for this game was absolutely stunning, the dialogue refreshing and funny, and the payoffs - when they came - incredibly satisfying. The CG's in particular were very well-crafted, and I'm so happy to see them have an independant gallery so you can review them once you've completed the story!

There was some repetition to the conversations the Heroine had with Orion, but this was negligible in comparison to the sheer amount of original content packed into each storyline. The "Skip Read" function assisted greatly in multiple playthoughs of the same world, ensuring I flipped through what I had already seen but didn't miss what I hadn't when pursuing the multitude of endings available.

Despite the so far glowing review, this game isn't without it's flaws. Some of the plot was cringeworthy at best, downright horrifying at worst, and the way certain love interests behaved at times was almost enough to turn me off one of the routes. Yet, I persisted with it and I'm very glad I did because all personal feelings aside, the world in question was one that had me on the edge of my seat the entire time - not so much for the romantic conclusion, but the wider one.

I still thoroughly enjoyed the ride, even the parts of the game I can't agree with. Clover and Joker were by far my favorite worlds; the latter in particular I wasn't expecting to like as much as I did, considering all I knew about the character from the other routes. It managed to surprise me with its depth, both of the character in question and the plot he was involved in. It wasn't until I reached the end of this route that I understood the way everything was connected, and how it came together from there was marvelous; I was quite emotional when the last "good ending" CG popped up, and even thinking about it gets me a little teary.

I've added some observations on the heavier themes in this game under the cut below. They aren't necessary for the review, but something I thought I'd include anyway for anyone who has already played the game:

[spoiler]
The discussion surrounding Ukyo's mental illness was brief (a passing line, even) but incredibly important, and upon learning of his plight I couldn't help but be sympathetic to the part of him that had struggled with such horrifying death for so long.

I feel that in comparison to this, Toma's character was done a disservice in that no such discussion was extended to his actions in either Heart or Diamond; actions which weren't quite as drastic as Ukyo's, but were felt more keenly by the player when the game refused to give us a choice in how to handle it, especially in Diamond. To me, the final choice in Joker made all the difference in allowing me to control how I ended things, and whether or not I extended that forgiveness to Ukyo for all he had done.

I wish we'd seen an official explanation of Toma's illness and how this resolved in his world. 'Oh, so you returned my feelings after all? Guess I'll stop gaslighting, drugging and caging you now' wasn't a good enough "good" ending in my opinion, and the lack of this follow-through ultimately bumps my preference for Diamond from the "good" ending to the "normal" one. I don't hate Toma, but I wish the game did more to get us to understand him like it did it's other love interests. [/spoiler] 

All in all, Amnesia™: Memories was a fun, entertaining, well-rounded game that equal parts shocked and delighted me. The art was amazing, the characters charming and the plot compelling. I highly recommend it to any fan of the genre.

38539023.review:
Um dos melhores jogos de Visual Novel que eu já joguei.

A começar pelo traço: a arte é magnífica, as proporções, o sombreamento, as luzes, tudo contribui para o efeito de sentido no jogo e é maravilhoso. As CGs são ainda mais maravilhosas. Além disso, a ideia de vozear os personagens é simplesmente genial; creio que isso nos conecta ainda mais com ele e com sua história. Cada voz reflete bem a personalidade de cada um.

Os personagens têm personalidades completamente diferentes, o que nos leva a ficar cada vez mais envolvidas com eles e, por conseguinte, com as diferentes histórias que a protagonista tem com eles. Os desenvolvedores souberam muito bem, por exemplo, manter em segredo todos os mistérios até a rota do Ukyo - a qual só é liberada após jogarmos com todos os outros 4 personagens. O plot da história é muito bem desenvolvido, bem sustentado pelo próprio jogo - e não algo bem aleatório. 

Os finais ruins são chocantes. Talvez não tão chocantes quanto Dramatical Murder, por exemplo (creio que não é a intenção chocar TANTO), mas, ainda assim, alguns finais são mais perturbadores que outros. O interessante é o jeito que foi escrito, pois, conforme a história corria na bad ending, era possível já sentir um clima de tensão e o envolvimento com a história é ainda muito maior; ao final, sente-se aquele aperto na garganta, cujo creio que seja a intenção de uma bad ending: causar desconforto e angústia. Toda a escrita do jogo contribui para, então, todo o efeito de sentido, nos leva a ter sentimentos que não teríamos se a história fosse escrita de outra maneira (isso não se limita apenas aos finais ruins). 

Além disso, após acabar o final bom da quinta rota (Ukyo), uma série de light novels são liberadas, cada personagem com sua respectiva light novel. Além disso, temos as memórias, que se passam em dias específicos para cada um dos personagens (e estas sim, são visual novel). Por fim, temos também os joguinhos. 

Tudo isso contribui para que haja um jogo completo: uma história maravilhosa e bem desenvolvida, com ótimas ilustrações e ótimos dubladores, além de histórias de apoio, para sustentar ainda mais o romance entre você e o seu escolhido - além do plot em si -, e, pra quebrar o gelo, mini-jogos para se divertir com os personagens. 

Obviamente, é um jogo que contém algumas falhas - mas qual jogo não tem, não é mesmo? É super recomendável.

38536084.review:
I loved this game so much! Easily one of my top Visual Novel games.

Gorgeous art and characterization. The background/landscape art is beautiful and uniquely drawn, the BGM as well is fun to listen to and doesn't get tiresome. 

The story is so interesting and the game encourages you to go through every route, which is such a treat in the case of Amnesia because each route is SO different! As you switch between parallel worlds, the dynamics of your relationships change depending on who you're romancing, and the threats/bad ending pitfalls vary as well depending on the world. This is one of the few games where I bothered to explore the bad endings as well as the good.

TLDR
Good art. Good Music. Interesting Bishi guys to romance, where each route is different. Interesting story to pursue to the very end.

38474603.review:
+Loved the game's main gimmick of navigating through your life and relationships as someone who lost her memories.

+No common route! After a short intro you just pick what route you want (each is quite different).

+Interesting blend of supernatural, mystery and horror elements.

+All characters are 18+ and have more adult problems than your usual cast of teenagers.

+Artwork, music, and UI are all great with high production values

-Character designs are ridiculous.

-Characters are fine by anime standards but still disappointingly archetypal (particularly in comic relief scenes).

-The protagonist is incredibly passive and naive due to her vulnerable mental state. Spoiler: this never improves.

-If you're looking for healthy, equal relationships, this game is a bad choice. None of the routes feature a love interest who is simply kind and respectful towards the MC. Some routes are more female-friendly than others though.

-The good endings tend to be really sappy. I liked the neutral endings more.

-Steer clear of this game if you don't like yandere.

-Hated one route, enjoyed the rest.

38191304.review: I also own this on ps t.v./vita, where i've done all the routes except Joker world. i have 15-20hrs on my save file for that version. I like -most- of the routes (Particularly Kents' and Shins') so far, but one of the routes is just...toxic, as others have stated in their reviews too. Not sure if that's a cultural misunderstanding (is kidnapping/forcible confinement okay in Japanese culture?) but to a western viewer like myself...that was NOT a display of affection or overprotectiveness, that was a display of extreme obsession, selfish manipulation, and disregard for individuality. Aside from the main character being a doormat like Yuna in FFX (for a quick comparison of personality), the art assets, music(the opening theme is fantastic) and the use of color is top-notch. The main outfits for the male characters look laughable, but the other outfits for side characters, and special event scenes look good. The voice acting has some top notch talent, and only Orion comes across as grating at times. thankfully, individual voices can be turned off in the menu opitions. I do like that the game starts out with your character in separate worlds; that you don't start from point A, meet all the guys, then from choices you make, get stuck in a given route with a guy you may not like. For example; Heart World has you as Shin's girlfriend from the start, rather than you picking and choosing between men as you progress based on choices. i still recommend the game; not all of the routes are bad relationships, and no one should look to a fictional heroine as a real-world model for behavior. If you enjoy otome games, and can get over the heroine being a doormat at times,and the aforementioned toxic route, you should derive some enjoyment from the game. it generally goes on sale for $10 or less pretty regularly, so i wouldn't recommend paying full price for it. I would enjoy seeing other games in the lineup (Amnesia Later, etc) get an English translation too. I think Idea Factory and Otomate have done a solid job on bringing games of this type to a western audience within the past 5+ years. I play a fair amount of games in this genre, and i feel like Amnesia: Memories, is legitimately worth the time/money spent if you catch it on sale.

嘛，关于skip选项啊load选项的问题，因为Amnesia是PSV移植来的，按键操作还是保留了PSV的设定，插个手柄玩会方便很多（因为是手柄党没有研究过电脑对应的skip按钮在哪里）。

移植版的OP是织田小姐演唱的[spoiler]OP和角色攻略Ending的ED其实都可以在游戏所属文件里找到Movie文件夹刨出来单独看的[/spoiler]推荐一下PSP版AMNESIA CROWD的ED之一，也是织田小姐献唱的君と愛になる，也非常好听。

配音也是很熟悉的吧，Toma役日野聪，Shin役柿原彻也，Ikki役谷山纪章，Kent役石田彰，Ukyo役宫田幸季，Orion役五十岚裕美[strike]女儿[/strike]。各个支线人物的性格也和cv们平时主役很相近，比如幼驯染[strike]败犬[/strike]病娇聪哥，把笨蛋挂在嘴边的年下担当柿子[strike]在otomate party里代表自己主役角色念台词的环节里，柿子试图对着在场五千名观众说五千遍baka[/strike]……加上聪哥柿子滚爷宫田都基本在作为声优偶像活动（es，bf，歌王子，B Project……），有兴趣的可以先从Amnesia的角色曲入手听听看，聪哥的After Season啊，滚爷的Lonely Starlight，柿子的Calling Me啊，五十岚的きみとぼくのSTORIA啊……柿子现在是歌手兼会长，聪哥和立花还有ELETIKER ROUND的歌手组合，滚爷和宫田的唱功自然不用说了，声线可男可女的石头也……——等等好像偏题了（陷入沉思

这部作品原作是AMNESIA，续作分别是AMNESIA LATER，AMNESIA CROWD，AMNESIA WORLD，有PSP，PSV，PC三个版本。PSP是全部续作都有的，PSV现在移植暂时只有本体和1.2，也就是本体和LATER+CROWD，PC版就是这里了。衍生的话有AMNESIA Cafe（虽然现在已经没了，对cafe限定贩售商品有兴趣的可以去骏河屋看看），一系列广播剧，角色曲CD，等等。对CV们有兴趣的可以去看看发行商每年举办的Otomate Party，是一个兼具Live&Talk的活动_(:з」∠)_

Steam平台上相关乙女游戏的话可能首推百花百狼了，cv阵容一样不错，别的勉强推一个ozmafia吧，画师也是魔恋的画师，画风应该很熟悉。别的不推荐了，质量个人都不能接受_(:з」∠)_不如去PSP/PSV上玩别的，如果觉得PSP/PSV入正经济实在有压力而转向汉化资源的，也别忘了支持一下自家担当的角色CD哟（会日亚的就不用说了，不会的话可以尝试萌购or魔法集市这种国内集成式的购买网站）。cv阵容差不多的其他类型游戏推荐个空之轨迹闪之轨迹吧，印象里柿子和宫田在里面都是主要角色的配音。手游es，bf，什么的不用说了，还有像养成类的ときレス和本质消消乐的スタマイ，柿子推私心再安利个B Pro和刀剣（莺丸真可爱）。

以上。以后想到什么再来修改补充吧

38166246.review:
This game...
-_-''
resuming: if you are easily disturbed, skip this game. And if you get easily mad at passive, obedient heroines this is definitely NOT for you.

I cannot on good conscience recommend this to anyone. I have to say though that i did not do two of the routes Shin's and the secret one. Why?
Because I made Toma's in 3rd place...

This must have been the first otome i did not fully finish. 
My 2 problems:
1) Passive, obedient heroine. She does not have a mind of her own. She's a doll and that's it.
2) Disturbing, toxic relationships. Sure I guess they wanted to focus on that but this is not the way to do it. If you want to make people see that these are disturbed people you should have a heroine that reacts to it in some matter but she DOESN'T! This is problematic because you might have a susceptible audience that is supposed to be guided by this heroine, to have her as a role model. This is not a good role model and this kind of toxicity shouldn't be approached in a "oh, poor guy he just suffered so much, that's why he is like this." This is very problematic. In real life this could be the beginning of a true horror story that many women are suffering as I write this.

I have no intention of supporting this game but i must thank it for one thing: it has made me realize that many of these otome games have serious problems with portraying toxic people/relationships and that any visual novel creator should have this in consideration when creating their work.

38101594.review:
[b]Current status:[/b] finished all four routes except for Toma's.
[b]Current grade:[/b] 7.5/10

To be honest, when i started to play this, I didn't know what to expect. All i knew is that in this game your heroine can die in many ways (and btw, all of those deaths are for reason) and that the characters are not what you expect them to be. This turned out to be true and very interesting.

First, there are characters I loved and characters I loathed with passion. 

As all otome games, you are able to choose between four guys (in order to unlock the fifth one) to reach all endings. Ofc some may be more tragic than you hope for, but it was really interesting.

The thing is, it's about your Heroine who got amnesia when spirit Orion accidentally bumped into her when crossing through parallel worlds. Because of it, the heroine has to reconnect with people in order to reclaim her memories on her own, because hospitals would only shun her from people and she would be unable to remember and there would be severe consequences. So, you can chose which world you wanna start with.

Shin's route is detective route - you were attacked and you don't know who it was or if it was on purpose. 
Ikki's route is more like a tense love x-angle where Ikki's fans are trying to make your life worse and Ikki is trying to protect you from them
Kent's route is so far the most normal of them all: he just wants to figure out what dating means and to throw math puzzles at you (and Ikki)
Toma's route is more of a "i'll protect you from everything" route, so if you are looking for extremes... here you go, have him.
And finally, the last person: Ukyo - is the one who is a constant through all routes - after all, in most of them he kills you or just disappears entirely. So what is his reason for doing this? Stay tunned and suffer through all routes to unlock his tragic white haired anime boy story (oops his hair is green though).

FInally, the remaining cast of characters is great. In each route they had few of their characterstics the same, and sometimes it was complete 180 degrees flip (like Rika and Waka). I loved that there were girls in the game like Mine and Sawa and Rika - they were a refreshment. 

The art is gorgeous but the fashion is really disasturous lol.

Anyway, in my opinion this game was worth for Ukyo's, Kent's and Shin's routes. I wasn't fan of Ikki's route and I'll do Toma's route once I am ready to reach for some... extreme in my gaming life.

Overall, not bad and everything is explained in the final route, even the things I thought were unimportant - even though they were kept mentioned in each route (such as the [spoiler]weather problems in august [/spoiler].

37987120.review:
I'll start by saying this is not an otome game for everyone. I've played many over the years, and a good majority will always have "that one guy" who is certifiably nuts and you're better off avoiding-- unless you're into that sort of thing. This game not only has that, but quite a few disturbing elements even in the most innocuous routes. 

Pros:
- I love a good twist and the game is full of them. The overarching concept I thought was very interesting. 
- The artwork is fairly stunning. There's some odd proportions on some of the characters but overall all of the eligible male characters are very attractive. The voice acting is also excellent and includes famous ones like Akira Ishida. 
- A long, involved storyline with interesting characters, all of whom have their own motivations. 

Cons: 
- There were times where it felt as if the heroine's choices were fairly meaningless. If you're someone attempting to get only good endings, I could definitely see how it would be a challenge in this game. This was not a problem for me, as I always try to get 100% of all the endings, so just be aware of that. 
- I mentioned the story is long as a pro, but it could also be a con. The branches feel a bit sprawling for some of them, with some conversations that might not necessarily be relevant and tedious after a while.
- The heroine herself is a character who has lost her memories (hence the title) and thus in a lot of ways it makes sense that she is fairly "cookie cutter". However, I found myself a bit bothered by the fact that this seems to stifle the amount of personality one is able to infer from her.
- As is often mentioned in other reviews, one of the characters has a very controversial approach that, no matter one's choices, is impossible to avoid. Depending on how squeamish you are, it can be a bit shocking.

Overall I did enjoy this game, but that was because I was looking for something shocking to play and I had an idea of what I'd be getting into. I wouldn't recommend this to anyone looking for standard otome fare, you may find yourself disappointed. If you do like dark dramas, then you may like this a lot.

37741686.review:
The game is such a steal with the huge discounts it gets. Even at full price, I can safely say that I would feel satisfied because I enjoy the story and characters so much.

I've only played one route (Shin's), but I can definitely say that this is a good VN. If you've never read an otome style VN, then this is a fine place to start. I like the game's explanation for the different routes; the game begins with you being lost in between parallel worlds, and your guide, Orion, gives you the choice of which world to enter. The protagonist is a young woman who was in an accident and lost her memories. In Shin's route, it plays out like a murder mystery (without the murder since no one died). On top of trying to piece together the protagonist's lost memories, you are also trying to determine what exactly happened the night of the accident. In the Heart World, Shin is/was your boyfriend before the accident. He's not a bad person, but he's rough around the edges and it isn't unreasonable to be suspicious of him. You make choices through the story about whom you trust, whom you don't trust, and your feelings for different characters all leading to multiple endings in every route.

If you enjoy visual novels and romance stories, then you can't go wrong, especially when it's only $3.

37728753.review:
I thoroughly enjoyed this game up until the point I played through the Diamond World route.

The previous three routes are bittersweet with a touch of mystery and sinisterness. However, they're still highly enjoyable and the further you progress the more pieces start getting put together for the overarching story and theme. However, Diamond World nearly stopped me from playing the game entirely.

Romanticising Stockholm Syndrome and possessive, destructive, manipulative men - even for the sake of a visual novel - isn't cool. It's the most uncomfortable I've ever felt playing a video game. Even a warning of potentially sensitive content would have been nice as the tone shift between the previous three worlds and this one is just insane. This route very nearly ruined my opinion and enjoyment of the game. I still recommend the game, but only on the basis of how strong the rest of it is. The art is gorgeous, the music is wonderful and I always appreciate a fully voiced VN. 

Some people may dig the storyline of the Diamond World route, whatver floats your boat. But [spoiler]the fact that you are locked in a cage and have to become a personal pet in order to achieve the good ending[/spoiler] made me feel physically sick.

Apart from that particular route, I definitely recommend this game! Picked it up on sale for £2.99 but would've happily forked out full price for it.

37202049.review:
Everything in Amnesia: Memories is tied together with the help of the facts you never expect to uncover.

A pretty lighthearted story at first, it gradually takes a turn for the worse, becoming darker and darker with each piece of the plot's puzzle you fit in place.

The outcomes of your choices are totally unpredictable for the most part, and it is one of the main reasons the game really stands out. Let's be real here: pllenty of otome plot developments are far from reaching any form of sophistication. But Amnesia has made some difference for me.

Great music, voice acting and art to boot.

***
Upd.

I think I have to correct myself here.

While everything I've said before about the game conposition and the unpredictability of the plot twists is true, I have a MASSIVE number of issues with the plot itself.

All the relationships are unhealthy in some way. The disturbing nuances of the events described are not helped by the heroine being an Extreme Doormat™ forced to go along with pretty much everything. I wish I had paid more attention to the warnings concerning this point (granted, there have been many) before I dived headfirst into the game. 

I had nonchalantly dismissed it at first thinking something along the lines of 'It probably won't be so bad, I'm not that sensitive" but once I started to delve deeper it got WAY worse than I could've possibly imagined. So now I want to be one more voice contributing to this.

I'm not saying you should run away from here really fast not to return ever again. As I've said before, the technical realisation of the plot idea is sound enough to give it a try, after all.

Just be warned.
And consider actually taking it seriously.

One of the most well written, smooth and polished Visual Novels I've ever played. No annoying stat grinding, either, which is what I personally prefer - just dialogue choices and 'True', 'Neutral', and 'Dead' ends.

The routes are all different, and have their own fun twists about them that I won't spoil - but I will say they use some very fun ideas that are quite inventive.

36636730.review:
"Amnesia: Memories" was an absolute delight. With this game, there was no contest between quantity and quality; it sacrificed neither, boasting five beautifully made routes with about twenty-six different endings. I got it on sale for about three dollars, but the content is easily worth as much as the usual price asks for.

The art used in the game is beatifully made, for all of the CGs, backgrounds, and character models. Everything is extremely detailed, and there are over one-hundred images to be collected for the gallery. Even the layout is aesthetically pleasing. The title screens, load screens, and text boxes all share a common theme and are easy on the eyes, unlike those belonging to more flamboyant visual novels. The only aspect of the game that wasn't very visually appealing was the air hockey mini-game, but this flaw is highly insignificant. 

The plots for all routes were very engaging, and wildly different depending on the character of your choosing. The game did not bore, even as I replayed portions of it to achieve all endings. There are many interconnecting factors between the routes that increase the compelling force of the story, and plot twists are executed effortlessly. Character development was an extremely well thought out factor for this game, and made playing it an emotional journey.

In all, this game is everything you'd want out of a visual novel and more. With an abundance of high-quality content, it is worth every penny. I whole heartedly recommend it to any visual novel player with the emotional armor to withstand the realism of this game.

36636068.review: Jogo incrível e viciante, Amei muito <3

36617346.review:
I encountered the anime version of this several years ago - enjoyed it, but it was mostly like a preview for getting into the game. It's not quite the same story, nor is it complete. So, I was happy to jump into the full version in game form.

Well, after almost 50 hours total, I've gotten all the good endings and several of the others (both bad and normal). I enjoyed every route, even if the character wasn't my usual "type". I started with Kent, 'cause I often like the stoic/nerdy type, which pretty much sums him up. He still has plenty of cute, awkward moments, though, and like all the others, he is deeply in love with your character. Next I went with Shin, because I liked his intensity. He's kinda grouchy, sometimes distant, but there's reason behind it. He gets jealous the most often which is a pro to me, heh. Then there's Toma, his competition, who alongside Shin was a childhood friend or brother figure. He plays the indulgent older brother, kind of a foil to Shin's sometimes tough love. But, his protective nature can sometimes make him go too far. Lastly - or so I thought - there's Ikki. I left him for last because I'm not as fond of playboy characters, but in his case, he's an unwilling playboy. And in the end, I loved each of their stories. Plenty of emotional and blush-inducing moments!

There is a fifth route once you've gotten the four good endings. Ukyo is a mysterious character that shows up here and there in the other routes, and he clearly has feelings for the protagonist, but is for some reason keeping his distance. Finishing his route addresses many of the questions that have cropped up throughout the game - thus, his story is quite different from the others. I liked that there was more to reveal about the world and circumstances in general once you've gotten through the first four routes. He's a fun character as well - probably the most awkward yet affectionate of the bunch.

The art style worked for me. It's not the most detailed, but every character has their own little flair. The sound is not bad - I quite enjoyed the voice-acting. On the other hand, the music is mostly boring and repetitive. Guess that's pretty common in these kinds of games.

The tone of the game is about average for otome games, too. Some routes deal with somewhat mundane problems (like choosing between a dream career and love), while others deal with kidnapping or murder. They're all pretty serious and tug on the heartstrings, though. The game doesn't really have gore, but it does describe some brutal events. In all, it's not a particularly dark game, but your character can be killed in each route. She also gets into some slightly...rapey situations. They don't go into detail, but there is talk of "taking by force" and such. It didn't go too far for my tastes, but if you don't like that sort of thing...uh, it must be hard to find otome games to play, 'cause they really seem to think girls are into that. Anyway, that stuff is in the minority - mostly the guys are being sweet or protective. Each one has four or five good scenes with a special CG - I could've done with more, but then, can't we always?

In between such scenes, I did get a little bored sometimes. I think it's a positive that the game isn't terribly long to get through - it doesn't go huge amounts of time between the good bits (the juicy stuff). I mean, who cares that much about seeing a girl trying to relearn her waitressing job? Especially FIVE DIFFERENT TIMES? And of course I didn't have much interest in her female friends, either, but they are still kinda cute and not too, too annoying with their squeaky voices.

Not sure this is worth full price - I got it on sale - but if you have the cash to spare, it could be a pretty good investment of your time, too.

36446874.review:
Amnesia: Memories is an emotional rollercoaster, but surely is one of the best otome visual novels. Prepare to die a lot, in many brutal ways.


Pros:
- Characters have a lot of depth; all of them have completely different personality and story behind them.
- Every route has plenty of different endings.
- Music and voice acting are really great.
- Art in this game is gorgeous.
- Plenty of replay value; if you're an achievement and ending collector, then it's a huge plus.
- Interesting story full of mystery and emotions. Every route is tied together, but makes more sense once you unlock the last fifth world, it unraveles a lot of information, which has been lacking in the other routes.

Cons:
- Toma. Diamond world is the worst, imo. If you're easily disturbed or can't stand any kind of abuse, just force skip through that route.
- Some route outcomes might be really toxic.


If you're a fan of otomes, then this one is a must-have. For better experience go through the worlds by the listed order, that way you will be prepared for escalation of insanity. 
If you're unsure about purchasing it, watch the anime first to get the idea of what's this all about, though it doesn't have as much depth and story as this visual novel; or you can just grab it on sale.

Personally, I had a lot of fun reading through all the stories, so definitely recommended. Would cry over Ukyo again.

36349289.review:
Das Spiel hatte ich mir hauptsächlich wegen dem Anime dazu gekauft.
Ich wollte die Original Geschichte auch noch erfahren. 
Weshalb ich auch nicht größten Erwartungen an das Spiel hatte.
 
Das Spielmenü ist übersichtlich und leicht verständlich gehalten. 
Genauso ist die Aufmachung schön und schlicht, wodurch sie sehr gut zur Story passt.
Die Zeichnungen sind ebenfalls sehr schön, wenn auch bei Ikkis Route zu wenig Änderungen 
reingenommen wurden. Zumindest hatte es mich gestört, dass ein und das selbe Bild mehrmals vorkam, 
auch wenn es nicht mehr so gut zur Story gepasst hat.

Die Musik ist recht harmonisch wenn auch ein wenig eintönig, was nicht wirklich förderlich ist,
bei vielen langatmigen Anfängen der Routen. Die Musik unterstreicht das langweilige und eintönige nur noch mehr. 

Aber ansonsten ist die Hintergrundstory recht gut gemacht. 
Auch wenn Sie einiges an Potential verschenkt haben. Sie hätten viel mehr Tiefe mit reinbringen können.
Einige der Routen waren auch nicht so interessant wie andere. Die Joker Route hatte mir persönlich am besten gefallen. Sie hatte die meiste Abwechslung und Spannung.
Im Gegensatz zum Anime war sie aber um einiges umfangreicher. 
Man konnte viel mehr über die einzelnen Charaktere und deren Vergangenheit erfahren.
Die Story ist wie im Anime auch leicht Fantasy lastig. Zumindest Orion und der Hintergrund zu Ikkis Fähigkeit.
Der Rest ist relativ normal gehalten.

Die Bad Endings, die man freischalten kann, können zum Teil recht verstörend sein und man bekommt sie auch sehr leicht je nachdem welche Route man spielt. Bei der Zusatzroute sollte man besonders vorsichtig sein.

So sind Charaktere teilweise recht Stereotypisch gemacht. 
Auch wenn sie sich im Laufer der Story noch ein wenig verändern. Einige mehr als andere. 
Die Heldin die man selbst spielt wird vielen als sehr passiv erscheinen. 
Das ändert sich allerdings in einigen Routen noch. Wenn auch nicht so sehr viel.

Bei den Entscheidungsmöglichkeiten hätte man auch noch einige dazu machen können. Zumindest zieht sich der Anfang bei einigen Routen ein bisschen und man kann nicht viele Entscheidungen treffen, die das interessanter machen könnten.

Dennoch im Großen und Ganzen ein Otome Game das einen mehrere Stunden beschäftigen kann und Spaß macht.

36250271.review:
I think that I'm reaching 200 reviews on Steam and I apologize for this one since it's very short.
It's short because I really can't add anything to the thousands review this game already has, and since this isn't a 100-hours open world RPG I can't of course tell many innovative things xD
It's one of the best visual novels I played here on Steam, although it's a port of an older game.
The artwork is really great, I loved the colors and the touch. It's not so easy to find a visual novel so greatly polished.
The plot is awesome and there are lots of different endings and routes, it'll take many hours to complete everything for sure. Voice acting (Japanese) and music are great too!
There are no forced/stupid endings or plot twists, it's really like a book. All the characters have their personalities and I think that this game had a very long and important phase of study behind it.
I'd not suggest this to those who are new to visual novels (ok, otome, you won't have me, I'll never be a wapanese sorry ahah), since although here everything goes smooth and there are no flaws at all, it's a long and dramatic story that can bother someone who has never played a visual novel before.
Apart from this, it's really really awesome. Pretty much how a visual novel should be done. Maybe a little too difficult and too long, but it's ok. 
I mean, this game has an Italian wikipedia page long like a novel. I think that I really can't add anything else, it should be famous all over the world :P
Yeah, I think that being an all-around gamer I sound only stupid to those who have passed 20 years in these games while I'm jumping from Yoshi's Island to fps shooters and RPGs made in Vietnam.
Get this visual novel and play it offline and online for hours ;)

35684059.review:
I've played many a visual novels, this was my first otome game.

I honestly avoided the "reverse harem" subgenre for a long time because I assumed it would be the typical anime harem set up with all of the guys in one route fighting over the main character.

Amnesia: Memories was a pleasant surprise and I haven't really enjoyed an otome game quite as much since, though Otomate is a very fine publisher.

What I really love about Amnesia: Memories is that the worlds and romance are clean cut and divided and this bypasses the aformentioned problem of the typical harem hijinks aka all fo the guys fighting over the main character in one route.

By dividing it into 5 different worlds and the Heroine having seperate relationships and histories with each, it was a lot more enjoyable and easy to get into than a set up where the character jumps from love-interest-to-love interest / ship limbo.

And each of the guys is quite flawed and human, which is good. No relationship or character is perfect, and there is a flavor for everyone.

I'd love to see the sequels localized, hopefully if the fandom can spread more positivity and show they can handle more mature subject matters we will someday; though it's been two years.

35408662.review:
I had maaaaybe one or two otome games under my belt when I played Amnesia for the first time.

I had no idea what I was getting into. 

Thus, a word to the wise: if this is your first foray into otome, be aware that you're in for a wild, wild ride. What I once dismissed as a rom-com genre is happy home to more blood and guts and homicidal maniacs than any FPS or RPG in my experience. Bare bones example of one of the many, many, many, many bad endings my hapless heroine met with: [spoiler]in one playthrough, my story ended with being pushed in front of a car, surviving that to be taken to a hospital, and then that night being snatched from my bed and dropped off the hospital roof to my doom.[/spoiler] 

After dying many a gruesome death in the name of love, I found myself addicted. Truth be told, I don't really find the "romances" in Amnesia romantic, but they're cathartic and the characters are fascinating. Sure, most of the leading men have control issues, and some have serious consent issues, and the plot is frankly a bit thin on the ground, but whether it's just exorcising the worst fears women live with, or if a cypher of a main character is really just a placeholder while, contrary to gender expectations, we identify with "male" controlling / angry / possessive desires, there is a great deal of satisfaction to be derived from even the bloodiest of bad endings here. There are emotions taboo and conventional to explore, and those emotions are validated without judgment, even if the validation is a little bit twisted. Simply surviving is a challenging and rewarding puzzle on its own.

This all sounds bananas, but the game is both bananas and awesome. I laughed, I died, I died some more, I got a good end. I looked up walkthroughs to make sure I got all the good and bad ends. There are many more bad than good ends.  

Recommendation on play order: the game obviously wants you to like Shin and (Secret Route) best, but Ikki is, bizarrely, the least problematic for those who care about consent and respect for bodily autonomy, in my opinion. I'd recommend Ikki/Spade > Kent/Club > Shin/Heart > Toma/Diamond > (Secret Route)/Joker. It's a slow degradation from warped but cute to lots and lots and lots of death (and laughter). 

On a technical note, there are some issues with achievements triggering, but overall? 9/10.

35229851.review:
[If I can't protect you, should I break you?]

Amnesia - это не только отличный хоррор про смерть и сумасшествие, а еще и неплохая отомэ-игра про смерть и сумасшествие. Оказывается, так бывает. 

Героиня этой визуальной новеллы просыпается утром в больнице, после падения с утеса на вечеринке. Она не помнит ничего, кроме своего имени, а также видит перед глазами странное существо – какого-то эльфа-недоростка. Существо сообщает героине, что оно случайно «влетело» ей в голову, когда путешествовало между вселенными, и, в целом, самые важные воспоминания из головы и выбил. Теперь им вдвоем придется разобраться в том, кто из окружающих друг, кто враг, и как приветствовать гостей в меид-кафе. 

Все начинается очень миленько и – уж не знаю, стандарт ли это для отомэ-игр? – заканчивается полным адом. Очень скоро друзья начинают намекать героине, что в больнице с амнезией она оказалась неспроста: с утеса ее, возможно, столкнул собственный парень. Который и сейчас ходит за ней хвостиком – может, надеется добить? 

У героини крайне большие шансы погибнуть в погоне за воспоминаниями. Только вот после смерти она просыпается снова – в мире, который точь-в-точь как предыдущий, и все же другой. Тот, кто раньше был другом, может оказаться врагом или незнакомцем. Тот, кого она считала близким – в этом мире может совсем ее не знать. 

Отсутствие воспоминаний – это стандартно работающий сюжетный ход для того, чтобы поставить игрока и главную героиню в одинаковое положение. Так как отомэ-игры созданы для проецирования происходящего на себя, у героини минимально прописаны какие-то черты характера. Но при этом - увы - большинство ее поступков не являются реалистичными, что как раз сильно влияет на впечатления. 

В Amnesia существует 5 «путей», которые соответствуют четырем мастям (+ финальный Джокер), и, соответственно, 5 парней, с которыми в разных мирах героиня попытается завести отношения. В отличие от других отомэ-игр, в Амнезии все пути практически полностью отличаются, в них нет «закрепленных» сюжетных ходов. По достижению хороших концовок в четырех мирах, открывается «мир Джокера» и возможность узнать историю загадочного персонажа, который попадается героине на глаза во всех мирах. 

Конечно, Amnesia, это не Hatoful Boyfriend и тут обходится без отрезанных голов, но жестокости хватает. При этом смысл всего происходящего раскрывается в конце, и игра вообще начинает напоминать «Пункт назначения». Симулятором свиданий тут и не пахнет, ведь вместо наслаждения пафосными фразами парней, все время приходится думать, почему тот персонаж прыгнул под машину в одном мире и вышел в окно в другом.

34914328.review:
This is an otome with a pretty interesting premise. Yes, amnesia is an overdone story gimmick in video games, but here the game is actually built around the amnesia, rather than having it as a convenient way of hiding story elements to the player and make some cheap plot twist. The character has to regain her memories in order to obviously live a normal life, but also to kick a spirit out of her mind (I swear it makes sense... kinda). 

What is nice is that the five main routes all happen in parallel universes (ok, here's another cliche, but much more used in comics than in video games), but they all connect to each other. Your relationships with the other characters change in the different universes, but if two of them are friends in a universe, they tend to be friends in the others, and to have somewhat similar personalities. The fifth route, where everything is explained, is pretty satisfying. 

The art is very pretty, there are some very cute moments (I took way too many screenshots while playing this game), there is a nice mystery in all of the routes, and the writing, without being outstanding, is good. Plus, there are fun minigames, and I haven't played with the voiceovers for a very long time (it distracts me too much), but it was well done from what I heard. 

However, there are a few issues. Within a route, there isn't a lot of branching. If you take very different decisions, the few following dialogues will vary, and maybe the ending will be different, but that's it. There are no different scenes other than that. Sure, you can skip the rest of the dialogues, but it still makes replaying a route not that worth it. 

Then, between each of the five main routes (especially the first four routes), there's a lot of redundance. You always work at the same place with the same people, one of them as a lot of success with the ladies and has a dangerous group of fans, one of them is a mathematics genius, two are childhood friends, and so on. It's like being served more or less the same VN four times. I would have prefered four shorter stories that are more varied than those long stories that almost don't change. 

Finally, speaking of redundancy, Amnesia has a recurrent theme: the borderline abusive boyfriend. Except for one of them (Kent, not the most loving guy, but at least the only decent one), they all have some kind of inappropriate relationship with the protagonist. Switching between the very emotional or melting moments and the ones where they treat you wrongly is a very messed up pattern. In every good ending, I'm mixed in a very bad way. I think "Well, this is a very happy and lovely moment... if you ignore how badly he treats me the rest of the time, but shhhhh". I know it's fiction and it's not meant to represent what should be reality, but it's bad that in a dating-sim game, I don't feel invested in the relationships, and even a lot reluctant.

34894527.review:
While I have yet to finish every route the game has to offer (3/5 routes have been finished), I can say with certainty that this game is worth the buy. Last year, I bought this during the summer sale after learning that it was finally localized. This is one of these Otome games where it's highly reccommended that you play the character routes in a certain order for plot reasons. I didn't know this initially myself but that's what I came to learn after I started on Shin's route. I was glad I started with his route for the very reason that is the route you're supposed to start out with. This is the specific order that I reccommend to go in:
Shin (Heart)
Toma (Diamond)
Kent (Clover)
Ikki (Spade)

Then lastly, Ukyo. That's the route to do last no matter what since in every version except for Android, you have to unlock him by getting the normal endings of each characters. I have seen sites where it's reccommended that you go through Ikki's route 2nd then Toma's route 4th and you can't exactly go wrong with either or. It's very much like Mystic Messenger in this sense when it comes to doing the routes in order.

The art (done by: Hanamura Mai) is fantastic. There is no doubt that this artist has an abundance of experience under her belt, and ontop of that her style fits in well with the style of story. The colors are very vibrant as well, which adds to the wonderfulness that is Hanamura Mai's art. The voice acting is really good, you have so many amazing seiyus involved in this game that you're pretty much bound to recognize at least one of them or more. Every one of them did an amazing job in bringing the cast of characters to life. I must mention the characterization too is well done, with even fleshing out secondary characters instead of just making them well... side characters!

There isn't much to say as far as gameplay goes considering this is a visual novel otome first and foremost. Your dialogue options tend to determine what your ending is going to be, and I would say that works well, and is typical of a game like this. I do wish however that there would be more instances where you could have dialogue options. But since the main character has amnesia (not really a spoiler) it's only natural that she would be so quiet.

The only bad thing I can say is this... While it's better than nothing, this is the only Amnesia game that has been localized so far as of this review. I am hoping that soon maybe, the other games get localized as it would be nice to have every game easily accessible. It wouldn't be such a problem really if I was able to fluently able to speak + understand as well as being able to read Japanese. I'm not sure if this game got very much traction though here which may explain why there hasn't been any confirmation regarding the other games being released outside of Japan.

Overall, an amazing VN and Otome game

34884072.review:
What began as a somewhat intruiging, mysterious story added up in the end to a meditation on fate, humanity, and choice, as well as love. Without spoiling I will say that the the way everything is pulled together in the end is beautiful and phenomenal. 

Shin and Ukyo were my two favorites, with Kent as a close third. Kent's story was moving and touching in a very genuine way. Shin is rough around the edges, but never came across to me like a real jerk, as he respects the heroine's choices first and foremost. He seems cold at first but his character is actually very caring and compassionate, even for the person who ends up being the villain in his storyline. Which makes him the embodiment of the "Heart" in the deck of cards, as contradictory as it seemed at first. Ukyo ... without saying too much, his story is the one that made me cry. Dangit. A very ordinary, humble, creative soul grappling with something mindbendingly terrible. Ikki's story I enjoyed though it didn't quite get up to love for me. I can't stand Toma, though I know others enjoyed him. I can empathize with the issues he was dealing with but he would have had to be incredibly more proactive about them to be a convincing love interest imo. Then again, maybe you have to get one bad apple in the bunch and that was the point. Idk. 

The art is lovely, immensely appealing to look at. I loved the side characters who all felt very distinctive and memorable. That made the world feel realer and more enjoyable even when you're not with your love interest.

34713453.review:
Vous interprétez une jeune fille amnésique qui cherche à recouvrer ses souvenirs à travers des rencontres et dialogues. 
Plusieurs "mondes" sont possibles et chaque monde possède plusieurs fins alternatives. Cependant le schéma dans chacun des mondes est le même : vous avez un petit ami (dont vous ne vous rappellez pas) et vous devez choisir si vous restez avec lui (fin qualifiée par le jeu de "heureuse") ou si vous faites tout pour rompre (fin qualifiée de "malheureuse").

Et c'est là que le jeu pêche : vous incarnez un personnage passif à souhait. Vous avez peut être une cinquantaine de réponses à donner au cours du jeu. En fait on se contente de choisir des réponses romantiques (pour accéder à la fin heureuse) ou non (pour se coltiner la fin malheureuse). Donc on s'ennuie ferme.

Le second point qui m'a personnellement choquée reste la "morale" de TOUTES ces histoires d'amour : Invariablement, dans chacun des mondes, votre petit ami vous insulte/traite d'idiote ou d'incompétente totale/essaie de vous forcer à coucher avec lui... Et la fin "heureuse" d'après le jeu consiste à mettre de côté le fait que ce type est un abruti fini et rester avec lui jusqu'à la fin de ses jours? On a même le droit à des dialogues expliquant que ce genre d'abus, ce n'est pas si grâve, car après tout "il vous aime"... Pardon? A aucun moment le jeu ne semble se rendre compte que ce message est légèrement génant...

34697123.review:
First, I would like to say that this was my first otome game and I started to play from a friend's library just spend some time with some light game. I ended up getting caught by the otome game world's cruel claws *being dramatic*. It is true in some sense because I couldn't stop myself playing it. And I ended up buying it, I didn't even wait for sale. In my opinion, it's worth every penny! 

I was so curious with what's going to happen with the next choice or character. It is a very well written visual novel. Characters have some depths and are not some shallow love interests. Developer did very good job on that. Every character has some reason behind why they decided to act that way, some more convincing than others but still ok. And what's the most amazing thing for me is that the story is consistent in every possible character. It doesn't matter who you choose as your love interest other love interest that haven't chosen have the traits. It really gives parallel universe feeling, like you're exploring what could have been in other universe. And it was this kept me in this game.  

The game start with the introduction of Orion, a spirit. By some unknown reason that you are not going to learn until you unlock last character, Orion trapped inside you and it caused you to lost your memories. He is your guide during the game. And by his suggestion, you're entering different parallel universes that can be the universe you're coming from on equal chances. 

In this game, you have five love interests. You're choosing one of them when choose your "world". As soon as you choose the character, every choice you make lead you one of the good, bad, and normal endings. Every character has one good ending and can be intriguing to get. Luckily, there are plenty of walkthroughs on the internet. I happened to always get normal or bad ending on my own. Apart from that, every love interest has several normal and bad endings. Some bad endings can be shocking. I sometimes said "no way!" and it can be creepy. But it is just a game, isn't it?! 

Overall, I highly recommend this game even if you never played otome before. It is story rich and it is not some game that you make every obvious decisions to end the game and get the guy. It's worth giving a shot.

34563225.review:
Only get it for 3 dollars when it goes on sale. I played Ikki's story first, which nearly turned me off from the game, but I would imagine playing him after you have some experience and know his deal would make his route much more bearable. There are some sweet moments in it, truthfully. I picked Toma next and nearly quit altogether. But Kent restored my faith.

I would recommend Shin and Kent, whichever interests you more first, then Ikki, then just skip through Toma's on full speed without even reading it so you can play Ukyo's route. 

Everyone else has summed up some of the game's issues better than I ever could. Honestly, I think the side characters are what makes the game shine. Sawa is really cute and Orion is comforting to have around. Rika adds an interesting dynamic and some conflict in many of the routes. Mine is just so much fun to hate (unless she's your friend).

34563092.review:
Я не стану ходить вокруг да около. Напишу просто, что новелла великолепна. Как минимум дня 2 вы потратите просто на то, чтобы порядочно так затупить и допустить наступление плохих концовок почти во всех рутах. Так что, не используя руководства стима во время прохождения рута, играть еще интереснее. На прохождения всех 5-ти рутов лично мне понадобилось 3 дня в очень спокойном темпе. Если вы используете вполне себе удобную систему пропуска, то значительно укоротите себе прохождение. Лично я старалась вникать в текст. 

Являясь русским пользователем, никаких трудностей с освоением английского языка я не ощутила. Перевод очень понятный, а история преподносится довольно-таки доступно. Для тех, кто действительно слабоват в английском в конце всё раскладывается буквально по полочкам, описывая все события для лучшего понимания, что удобно.  Так что если вы хотите попробовать поиграть и не знаете насколько проблематично будет в плане понимания сюжетной линии и фраз персонажей, основываясь на небольшом знании английского языка, то можете спокойно добавлять её в свой список игр: элементарной школьной программы  здесь с лихвой достаточно чтобы прекрасно ориентироваться. Так как с пониманием языка лично у меня проблем не бывает особо, то тут и подавно не стало, хотя текста довольно-таки много.

Все руты достаточно интересны, по-своему оригинальны. К слову, их первоначально 4, но позже может быть 5. Персонажи хорошо продуманны, выполнены в красочных и оригинальных стилях. Характеры героев отображаются не прямолинейно и местами ввергают в шок, демонстрируя свою  скрытую сторону. Здесь не будет никакого стандартного наклацивая ответов в негативной и позитивной форме. Здесь вы не  станете рандомно выбирать вариант ответа и моментально получать позитивную реакцию. Все ваши ответы имеют накопительный эффект и только по концовке уже можно будет судить удачным ли был ваш выбор.    Несомненно, меня радует и то, что каждый рут начинается совершенно по-разному, а не с какой-то стартовой точки по стандарту, где меняется только сам персонаж, выбранный вами. Здесь истории  имеют разное начало, что является еще одним плюсом.

ЦГ в этой новелле требуют отдельной похвалы. Лично фоны не сильно детализированы, но как таковых претензий к ним нет, но детализации я там не увидела и отметить их красоту не могу, но что касается прорисовки ЦГ, то тут всё сделано качественно, красиво и с душой. Помимо того, что их довольно-таки много (если быть точнее, то их там около 10 на только одного героя, и это еще без учета того, что есть еще ЦГ для отрисовки событий массового характера и отдельно для второстепенных какие-то мелкие зарисовки), они дополняются малозначительной анимацией  действий.  Это достойно похвалы, ведь выглядит это просто превосходно. 
Озвучка от профессиональных сейу, большое обилие авторских OST, дополнение различными звуками для атмосферности. Ах, что же еще нужно для счастья. 

+++
Отдельно от себя напишу, что рут Укё является моим любимым, но не спешите добираться до него сразу. Укё – это бонусный персонаж для любителей качественного и скурпулёзного прохождения визуальных новелл. Что мне импонирует, так это то, что открыть дополнительный рут можно только при достижении позитивных концовок в четырёх предыдущих рутах.  Это достигается путём приложения усилий, так как пройти все руты позитивно, не достигнув при этом плохих концовок, можно лишь с использованием руководств. Прибегать к ним или нет – дело исключительно индивидуальное, но так или иначе, очередная прелесть игры заключается в том, что просто так бонусы получить не получится. 

И еще хотелось бы отметить, что  в игре присутствуют дополнительные развлекательные возможности, а именно мини-игры в виде «Камень-ножницы-бумага» со своим любимчиком, а так же аэро хоккей. Для небольшой эмоциональной разгрузки и расслабления, видимо. Мелочь, а приятно. 
Рекомендую к прохождению всем любительницам романтичных  историй, галантных 2д мужчин, глядя на которых отбивается смотреть на реальных (so sorry),  и просто любителям визуальных новелл.

34539062.review:
Una gran visual novel. Cada una de sus rutas son distintas y especiales, tienen historias interesantes y todas forman un conjunto de la historia en general. El prologo contecta con el final de la ultima ruta (desbloqueable después de jugar las otras cuatro) y eso le da una profundidad que no he notado en otros juegos del estilo.

Cada juego tiene su encanto, pero en este no solo se experimenta el tipico otome romantico, también tiene fantasía, misterio y asesinato. Se pone turbio cuando quiere y te explica todo en detalle.

A parte de las rutas, el juego recolecta ilustraciones hermosas de las rutas, tiene minijuegos e historias extra que complementan a la experiencia que ya de base está dando.

Las voces expresan a la perfección los sentimientos de los personajes y el arte del juego es hermoso.
Valió cada centavo.

I LOVE TOMA AND HIS FUCKING ROUTE! ♥

34351008.review:
I'm not a fan of modern setting games. I like fantasy in my games, I get enough of modern life as is. However, I gave this one a try cause why not - I really REALLY enjoyed Nightshade and Hakuoki. 

I was leery because there are mini games and I didn't want to have to master some weird twitchy mechanics just to get through the stories. Stories that I seriously recommend you play in the order they're offered, for a couple of reasons:

1 - Little details will make a lot more sense.
2 - they're all actually tied together, and doing them in order makes it a lot easier to follow along.

Toma's story line is certainly problematic, but if you play the others first you can at least understand why. It was a little uncomfortable getting through it, and I really think the good ending should've been a montage of him making amends for like the next decade, _but_ regardless.

Also, for S&Gs, I'll put the story lines in order from best to well, worst isn't a good word so much as least favorite.
Kent, Ikki, Shin, Ukyo, Toma.

but seriously, play them in order, the over-arching story that pulls the whole thing together is just immense and a lot less confusing if you go in order ^_^

33978098.review: I had no knowledge of the anime beforehand and bought this game knowing I haven't been crazy about visual novels in the past, but this was very close to being the best visual novel I've read. I enjoyed every story, however some were more interesting than others. Toma's storyline was my favorite as it was very unexpected and creepy, to the point where I was wondering what I was reading. Shin's storyline was also surprisingly good. At first. However, as I thought of myself as a detective trying to find out who the culprit of the story was, it took quite disappointing turn and it felt quite frankly a bit unfinished. Despite some dull moments, the game was incredibly well made. Featuring good music, lots of choice making (that I often had to do walkthroughs of to get a good ending) and well drawn characters, this is a game I definitely recommend to those looking for a game to sweep you away from reality for a while. The creepy moments in the game are also something I loved. Those were often surprising and thrilling.

33807480.review:
This is very much a classical dating sim, with a limp-handshake heroine, affection meters, and a lot of very tightly plotted choices. And of course tall and princely bishonnen, ranging from the gruff but loving tsundere to charming and psychotic yandere, and I mean [i]yandere[/i]. There is also excellent voice acting and character art, an intricate but very manageable path to the endings, and an unusual premise, though more unusual than original.

Beyond the premise that the heroine isn't generally trying to find a boyfriend, but to save her troubled current relationship with the help of a cute narrative Imp from another dimension, the actual plot is sadly much more about intricate plot than deep original themes or psychology; it's better than Mills and Boon, but very much to a formula. There is a lot of genuine torrid passion, but the passion of fairly unoriginal character, crafted very much for particular tastes, is of much less value than otherwise. Also, the game is long, perhaps too long. 

Dedicated Otome game fans should love this title. Possibly not everyone else.

GAME WARNING AND SPOILER: If you want to unlock the final arc and complete the game, the heroine has to go out with all four boys, even the rape-happy yandere. Hence, I'm not going going to be finishing this game.

33416867.review:
Amnesia: Memories truly is a remarkable game. I bought it during the steam winter sale and did one route, but I didn't pick it up again until this summer. I don't regret it at all. The artwork is very well done and is appealing to the eye.
Each path you choose is different from one another, and I personally found all routes intruiging. The guys in this game aren't necessarily the best with some of their personalities. (Not the worst by any means, though!) The route order you choose to do doesn't matter all that much, but I would strongly advise you to save the Diamond route for last, as for the overall tone of the game takes a dark turn. The "true" route tied up the game very nicely!
Orion was a very entertaining companion throughtout the entire game, but for some his incessant babbling may become annoying.
The MC: As a lot of people have mentioned, the MC really doesn't have much of a personality. If you want a MC with a personality, this game mignt not be for you.
Overall, Amnesia: Memories is an excellent game for all otome lovers. The characters are certaintly memorable and there is a lot of content on this game. (The mini games and side stories). This game tends to be on sale quite frequently for a superb price, so if you don't want to pay full price, the sales would be an amazing opportunity to obtain this game!  I can see myself most definitely replaying Amnesia: Memories again.

33275655.review:
I dived into this game without watching the anime or knowing anything about it beforehand. This review was written after completing every route and achievement in the game. This game gets a 10/10 from me.

If you are a fan of visual novels or otome games, this game is definitely one you should consider buying! Futhermore, it often goes on sale for ~$2 which is definitely a steal. Keep a lookout for this game during sales!

Firstly, this game has gorgeous art. I know art shouldn't be the main factor in a VN but it is a huge plus! There are five love interests you can romance, and each love interest has more than one ending. The personalities of the guys also varies so you should more than likely be able to find a favourite. Their routes branch out quite a bit as well, so you wouldn't feel like you are repeating the same storyline for a different character. The personalities of your friends and other extra characters changes depending on your route, which brought about a certain kind of freshness. Saving, loading and skipping functions were bug-free and worked well - which is essential if you are planning to complete all routes.

Although some parts were pretty cheesy and cringe (quite common in otome games though), I truly enjoyed playing through this game. There were many surprises and I even teared at some of the scenes... especially at the true ending. However, the MC doesn't really have a character of her own (except in one of the routes) and she is very passive, often letting Orion voice her thoughts for you. This is due to her amnesia. Honestly, this caused me to be quite irritated at her at some points in the game. Some of the routes (especially the bad endings) may be quite triggering too.

Overall, I would recommend this game, especially when it's on sale. My favourite routes are Kent and Ukyo, and I did enjoy all five main routes so I hope you would too.

33258857.review:
Let me preface this review by saying that I've played visual novels like Hakuoki and Code: Realize (and XBlaze Code: Embryo, though it has some of the same faults as this) so I might be a little spoiled in my VN expectations.

I have the game on Steam but have been playing it on my Vita. I've played through two routes in the past couple of days in order to get a decent enough feel of it for a review. I played through Ikki's/Spade World first just as random selection, and then through Shin's/Heart. You aren't introduced to the characters at all before you pick, but I had seen some screen shots beforehand to know names/faces.

This really shouldn't be spoilery. I'm not going into any plot points.

PROS:

--You're not determining the love interest based on choices in the first 5 chapters or so, like I'm used to. After the brief intro/prologue, you pick a route based on a card suit, and that determines the love interest and story. This is a plus in the sense that you don't have to read several chapters that are 98% similar to the other routes each time.

--The stories themselves aren't nearly as long as what I'm used to. Generally, I would prefer longer, fleshed out stories, but dragging these stories out would probably just get tiring. The length suits them because so far they seem to just be "slice of life" and nothing super involved.

--The characters aren't the same personality dropped into a bunch of different skins. You have your playboy type, childhood friend(s), some mystery dude, math nerd, mean girl, etc. They're tropes, sure, but at least you can tell them all apart by personality, actions, etc. They're interesting and colorful. 

CONS:

--The MC is like, nonexistent. I guess it was an attempt at making the player feel like they're her, but it just ended up making everyone talk in these extended monologues and wasn't AT ALL immersive. Someone is talking to her and her only responses are when you're prompted to make a choice, but that's usually while they've said a million things that you'd expect her to respond to so that it actually feels like a conversation. Toward the end of both routes, she had actual dialogue, but that's after going through the whole story with the spirit in her head saying things like, "You're really tired," or otherwise voicing her feelings aloud as if she's incapable. She lost her memories, she's not a vegetable. 

--Tying into the last one...there's no real narration. Other than the spirit's comments about what's happening or on the day's events, there's no narrator describing the surroundings or otherwise doing any world-building. It made the stories a little flat for me. All dialogue and no "I went to work the next day, nervous about blah blah blah." The characters are obviously the main focus in the art, but they're not really deep enough for the game to simply be character-driven.


HALF PRO/HALF CON:
--The character art is pretty, as expected from otomate. They're expressive, beautifully-colored, and the outfits are interesting. The backgrounds are detailed enough drawings, but then they're just monochrome watercolor-splashed, so they're all pretty muted and not very immersive. Again, this could be because they wanted to focus on characters, but...see above.

--Not a whole lot happened in Ikki's route, but Shin's was kind of a mystery investigation. They're totally different stories, which I liked (going back to what I said about not having to play half of the story in order to choose the love interest). Just about all of the characters are present in each, but they play somewhat different roles.

All of that being said, I'm definitely going to read through the other routes, but the experience hasn't been nearly what I expected. I was used to the lively narration of both Code: Realize and Hakuoki, in which the narrator actually had dialogue and told a story in between interactions with other characters. It was hard to really feel anything for this MC because it was like she wasn't even there until a CG popped up.

If you go into it expecting a casual VN that will be entertaining enough but not super immersive, then go for it, especially while it's on sale. The focus seems to be on characters, not backgrounds or deep plots that take several hours to read through. I don't dislike the game, but I have certainly played better VNs.

33055501.review:
There's lots wrong with the game, but it's still really good; once you start laughing at all the crazy stuff that can happen if you mess up one choice. I don't reccommend doing Toma first, as it will completely turn you off from the game. Do them in the order the worlds appear. Heart, Spade, Clover, Diamond, and then Joker once you unlock it.

The art quality is fantastic, despite everyones very....um...odd choices of fashion. The artist really REALLY loves belt buckles. The only thing I didn't like about the art is the ridiculous stunned bunny look the MC always has on her face. Compared to the guys, she's always an expresionless doll. She doesn't really have any personality, for obvious reasons, but I was fine with that, as at least she's not dumb as a doorknob with no common sense like the MC in OZMAFIA!! so I was able to skim past her flaws. Orion more than makes up for her.

I knew going into it, that there was going to be a lot of messed up stuff, and that one of the characters is a hardcore yandere. I ended up taking a screenshot every time someone he said raised a red flag, and I made a game of it to make it a bit more lighthearted. By the 15th day, I had over 70 screenshots. I ended up just giving up, since I didn't want a thousand more screenshots.

From best to worst, my characters would be-
Ukyo + Orion cuz he's B E S T B O Y E
Ikki
Kent
Shin
Toma

Toma is well...Toma...It's funny, if I didn't know information about the game before hand, Toma would have been my first route. The sweet, scincere, protective childhood friend. *snorts*.  Toma's good ending is "um...." Toma's normal ending is "um...." Toma's two bad endings are "um...."

Shin's romance was meh. I was more interested in the actual murder mystery who-dunint than anything else. Not much else to say, really. I don't like tsunderes, they remind me of a child still stuck in the 'pulling the hair of the girl you like' stage. Shin's good ending is "That's it?". Shin's normal ending is "Meh" but Shin's two bad endings? They give you the true taste of what is to come in the game, and they are great. Which is why I reccomend doing him first.

Kent is the cyborg learning emotions for the first time. It's endearing most of the time, but can get kind of cringy at times. His good ending was very sweet. Normal end is kind of bittersweet, while I haven't bothered to do his bad ends yet.

Ikki was a surprise. I knew he was the playboy type character which I always loathe, but once you get into his route more, he's one of those "surounded and 'loved' by everyone but still lonely" characters, which I always end up being a sucker for. I enjoyed his route a lot. I figured he'd be my top guy at the end, but Ukyo came out of left field and shoved everyone else off the pedestal. Good end is just great. His three bad ends are great as well. 

Finally is Ukyo. Ukyo, Ukyo, Ukyo. He is locked at the beginning of the game. You need to obtain the good ending with the four other characters to unlock him, but honestly it's so worth suffering through Toma route for him. During all the other guys, you'll get bits and peices that will make you very curious as to who this guy is. This shit is the true ending. Going into this Otome you need to understand that it exhibits some borderline and not so borderline abusive relationships. While they do have reasons as to why they are the way they are, whether or not it is justified is completely up to you. 

This Otome has everything I look for. It has beautiful artwork, unique characters, voice acting, lots of choices, numerous endings, and a deep well-written story. Each route can feel like they drag on for a bit but as this isn't free, I appreciated the amount of content. The characters are all extremely well-written and are easily recognizable from one another both physically and personality-wise. Getting a glimpse into the mentality or rather mental health of the protagonist and male leads was not only incredibly interesting, it is something I have not witnessed in many other Otomes. There's even some post-game goodies that you get to enjoy such as the mini-games, memories, and voice-overs on the CGs. 

Overall, great story and great characters. I definitely reccommend playing through the whole thing.
