24237664.review:
[b]"And, even yet, I dare not let it languish, 
Dare not indulge in memory's rapturous pain; 
Once drinking deep of that divinest anguish, 
How could I seek the empty world again?" - Emily Bronte, [i]Remembrance[/i][/b]

[i]Amnesia: Memories[/i] is the only game ported to PC from the highly successful otome game series called Amnesia by Otomate and Idea Factory. Originally made for Playstation Portable and later Playstation Vita; Amnesia game series were started in 2011 and it was well received primarily in Japan. Within a year or so, the franchise earned a notable fan base and a reputation all over the world as a high quality otome series with countless merchandise and many sequels. Here we have [i]Amnesia: Memories[/i], which is actually the 4th game in the series, yet it is consistent and well elaborated enough within its own self, so you don't necessarily have to play any other games to enjoy it.

Our heroine is a college student whose life will take an unexpected and unexplainable turn with the appearance of a spirit called Orion. Apparently, Orion was pulled into our consciousness and merged with our heroine accidentally while he was travelling between worlds. As it may be significant to mention, Orion's merge into our mind pushed our former memories out and our heroine ended up with Amnesia! We have no idea about who we were supposed to be, what was our personality like, whom might be our friends etc. and we are stuck with a spirit only we can hear or see. Luckily, Orion is a good natured one and takes full responsibility of this accident, even agreeing to stay by our side until we can recover our memories and adapt into our life. By the way, it seems that we are surrounded by charming yet problematic gentlemen with interesting backstories whom are desperately in love with us and there is no reason that we shouldn't pursue the romance of our hearts... Will our heroine be able to find her memories and win the heart of her preferred gentleman while doing so?

Cheesy? Yeah, a bit. The storyline isn't terribly imaginative for our chosen romance options, but all their singular stories are relevantly intertwined on a bigger picture. Once you complete four different romance paths with good endings, you'll be allowed to explore a fifth path to take a glance on this bigger picture and discover the reasoning behind seemingly irrelevant plot holes in all other stories. By its ability to collect all different paths in a unified story consistency, the core story is amazing and surely refreshing in this genre. According to my own experience, a solid core story for the starting plot and the setting consistency always wins over pretty romanceable boys with not so interesting personality defects. Thus, the final story was my favorite. Our 4 primary romance, on the other hand, felt a bit rushed and hollow. Sure, the narrative is good, event correlation is amazing etc. but only one of our pretty boys felt like an actually likable sort for me. Then again, this is a matter of taste.

As the game starts, we are asked to choose between four different worlds, where our heroine and any other character connected to her will take a different incarnation and a difference in interrelation. Core liaisons between characters rarely change. In all worlds, we are a college student with psychology major who lives alone, works in a maid cafe named Meido no Hitsuji during the summer and has more or less similar kind of relationships with people around her. In each incarnation, our primary romance target changes though and we gain new opportunities to discover more about our pretty boys.

Artworks are glamorous with a good amount of CGs used. Character designs are a bit flamboyant and exaggerated for my taste - like a Final Fantasy villain fashion show - but they are quite unique. All the boys are designed to be a symbolic representative of four French suits of a pack of cards: hearts (Shin), spades (Ikki), clubs (Kent) and diamonds (Toma) - Ukyo being the joker. That presents an Alice-like taste for the whole game: elegant yet uncanny. All characters are properly voice acted with suitable choices. Environment design might be called stylized, - pastel colored renderings of some basic drawings - but it wasn't really appealing or remarkable.

5 romance paths with each their good and normal endings + a truck load of bad endings thanks to the world being a constant danger to you for some reason + extra memories and short story routes present you a nearly 50-60 hour experience, and this is by skipping already seen text. There is also a great amount of choice options within each path with a good cause - consequence relation presented. If you are not using a guide, I highly recommend for you to take frequent saves. When you are bored of all the drama, you can take a break by playing some mini-games too.

For any otome gamer, Amnesia is a good deal and goes into a decent sale like %90 twice in a year or so. Okay, I'm hushing myself now. It was already hard for me not to spoil the actual story in this review. I'm going away before I blabber about something. Good gaming to you!

Please also check out Lady Storyteller's Curator page [url=http://steamcommunity.com/groups/ladystoryteller#curation]here[/url] - follow for regular updates on reviews for other games!

24146970.review:
People are going to either hate or love this otome visual novel. I personally enjoyed it immensely because of how everything tied in together, and I love the dark tone and even darker tone of some characters. Many people will disagree on the story and characters because a lot of it is very controversial (borders on abuse in some places, etc.).

They're also going to point out that the main character has no personality. Well, considering that she's lost her memories I'm not sure what they expected. As you go through the game, you start to learn more about yourself and who you were, which I think is just fine in this setting. Some people may disagree.

All in all, I really loved the art, characters, and story. I would give this a try, especially if it's on sale and you don't mind something with some darker tones to it.

EDIT: I also want to point out that not everything is peaches and pretty little flowers in relationships or peoples lives. Yeah some of the story accepts this abuse in some way, but there are people in this world who do, or do accept it because of certain circumstances, or because maybe they realize a person can be saved. Not everything has to be the *perfect* romance. Just my two cents.

24112723.review:
I'm sorry, but this is the most boring visual novel I've ever played so far. I don't like it when I have unfinished games and locked achievements, but I can't do anything in this case, I just can't finish it.

Pros:
+ the art is nice (even though sometimes anathomy and proportions  are just ridiculous)
+ the voice acting is nice
+ the concept is quite good
+ there are some relatively interesting places in the plot, but...

Cons:
- ...this places are in the end of each route so you'll have to suffer for at least 3 hours to make it to them.
- the dialogues are bad. Just bad. Boring, poorly written, illogical, overflowing with Orion and guys telling protagonist, what does she think or feel right now, boring again. 
- the characters are awfully plain and cliched, things they say made me cringe, a lot. Sometimes it was really painful.
- the protagonist is irritatingly passive. She hardly ever speaks. She hardly ever reacts. And it's not like she is just a kuudere or dandere type. There are countless amount of moments when somebody asks a direct question to protagonist. You expect some choices to pop up, but — nothing. The one who asked a question answers to himself and makes conclusions about what do you think or feel without your responce. Then he makes a decision about what to do then. You, the player, just feel like a wordless dog.
- the protagonist has no personality at all. Literally. I almost laughed out when one of the guys said something like: "Now when I know what it's like to be with you I couldn't bear to lose you". Well it's definitely terribly painful to lose relationships with a person who has a personality of a slice of bread.

All in all, it's a visual novel with [b]mostly[/b] uninteresting story and characters. But it looks and sounds nice.

24092552.review:
I really wanted to like this game, I really did. Especially since so many people recommended this to me as one of the holy grails of otome games. I was very excited to try this game, but after my first playthrough I felt very confused and disappointed. So I tried another route, thinking that I just had a bad route on my first try. The second route I tried was even worse than the first. I did not like this game at all. Perhaps it was my incredibly high expectations for this game that made it such a large disappointment. But either way, the game was just not enjoyable at all.

The main problem I have with this game is the story and characters. The story is very cliche and the game sometimes moves at a painfully slow rate. The characters are so unrealistic and their actions and motives make absolutely no sense at all. Almost all of the guys are either egocentric jerks or literal psychopaths. They never apologize for their hurtful behavior. EVER. These men constantly hurt the protagonist and expect her to forgive them and welcome them with open arms without showing any remorse or guilt over their previous actions. The only way to get the "good ends" involve either forgiving them, submitting to them, apologising for things that are not your fault, or ignoring their behaviour. The routes I played just aggravated me. I hated the fact that these men treated me so poorly and I was just supposed to ignore it. This game would be great if the premise was to teach people what unhealthy abusive relationships look like. But unfortunately, that is not the case.

The protagonist has literally no personality at all. And I get that the character you play as often doesn't have as much depth as the characters you meet, but this was just ridiculous. The entire game you feel like Orion is controlling all of your emotions and thoughts-- because he pretty much is. This character has no thoughts. She simply has Orion to tell her his feelings and what HE thinks she should do in the situation. 

This game was just bad. Each time I played it I became very anxious to just get it over with and finish it already. Then each time I ended a route, I felt even more annoyed than when I was playing because the endings were so awful and uneventful. It's very unfortunate that a game with such beautiful art and stellar voice acting would be cursed with such a bad plot and characters. My advice on this game is to simply steer clear.

24086080.review:
This game was probably one of the best otome games i've ever played. I LOVED how every route was a different story. Word to the wise, for those looking to play this game though. Play the character's routes in order of top to bottom when selecting the world you will be in. Just trust me on this one.

The only route I didn't care for was Toma's. Obviously. Not because of anything other then the fact that he was bonkers. But I  feel like it was intended to be the way it was, to show another kind of bat shit crazy love perspective, that some people ACTUALLY would put themselves through. I dreaded his route the entire time after I finished Shin's. I was like, "man I really don't wanna do that lunatic's route..." but in the end wanting to unlock Ukyo's route won and I did it.. and it was even more bat shit crazy than I expected. I kept hoping that since it was an alternate world that he would actually be a normal sweet guy. But nooooooooo. Looney. Absolutely Looney. The pro to it though? It was refreshingly very different. No matter how dark it was. 

SHIN FOR THE WIN.

24055012.review:
[h1]Overview[/h1]
[i]This is an otome game with four main paths as well as secrets within the game. So far, I've done one route and thouroughly enjoyed it. I plan to do all the paths and if my views change, I'll edit this review.[/i]

[h1]The Story[/h1]
You meet a spirit named Orion who now inhabits your consciousness, telling you that you must now choose which reality to go back to in order to regain your lost memories due to him accidentally shoving them out. You're then given four choices and sent into that world to meet your friends and those important to you to try and remember. Each path has a different story to it, which is actually pretty nice for a game like this. Much better than what you can end up with when it comes to this type of game.

From what I understand, each path has a good ending, a normal ending, and one - two bad endings, so there's a lot to explore even after your first playthrough through a world, as the game calls them. Each of your datable boys is based off of a suit in cards. Hearts, Diamonds, Clovers, and Spades. Going through the story, you'll easily be able to tell which boy is which suit (and in turn which world).

[h1]Pros[/h1]
[list]
[*] The visuals in this game are stunning.
[*] A bunch of unlockables throughout the game, as well as a way to keep track of them.
[*] The music fits and is pleasing to listen to. It also fits with what's going on with the story.
[*] Replayability (obviously)
[*] Paths are distinct from one another and are a decent length each time through.
[/list]

[h1]Cons[/h1]
[*] The backgrounds tend to be a little drab compared to the drawings of the characters and the CGs.
[*] If you don't like boys who tend to be a little rough, this isn't for you. (It's a cultural things since it's original Japanese which I can look past, but some may not be able to)
[*] The characters can be hard to read, so it can be difficult to figure out the "right" choice.
[*] Minor words repeated in some text boxes (because I know that bothers some people, especially when you're reading all of what's spoken)
[/list]

[h1]Ending Thoughts[/h1]
If you're a fan of the genre, I think you'll enjoy this. I had my doubts because of negative reviews that I read, but I thouroughly enjoyed this game. I'll definitely be trying to get all of the acheivements in it. I'm curious how all of the other stories will play out in the different worlds.

The price for this game at the time I bought it was $2.99 due to the summer sale, but I would definitely have bought it at full price if I had the funds to support Idea Factory.

[h1]Ending Score:[/h1] [b]8/10[/b]

Overall, a very good otome game with amazing characters and art.

23985093.review:
This is an otome game and that means you have the possibility to romance the male characters Shin, Toma, Ikki and Kent (and an unlockable guy) as the nameless Heroine. Your choices will affect what kind of endings you get.

This is a very well translated game with few typos (compared to other otome games) and it's a port from the Japanese Vita version and is also available on PS Store for the Vita.

Ups:
+ Variety of guys (That you may or may not like. You don't have to like every guy and who you like, may be disliked by someone else.)
+ Both good and bad endings
+ Few typos
+ Pretty accurate translation

Downs:
- The mini-games didn't work on my laptop, and lagged a lot (so don't expect it to work well if your computer is older or not made for gaming)
- Some of the bad endings are really bad and there are a lot of bad endings for the entire game
- Some of the choices weren't obvious and some choices just led to a bad end for seemingly no reason

Neutral:
* You choose guy immediately after the prologue
* You can't romance Orion

I like this game and I think it's worth playing if you like otome games, but do take note of points I listed above.

23868251.review:
Given their eyes, I can only assume that everyone in this is secretly a cyborg trying to pass as a human being. This creates a much better understanding of some of the incomprehensible social decisions several of the characters make, and the main character's extreme lack of characterization until she interacts with everyone more. Best Artificial Intelligence. Clearly, the fairy is only there as a navigational system for the AI's judgment calls.

It has a lot of things going for it...and a lot of things completely not. As one of the initial otome games to be released stateside, I was eager to support more of a genre coming out and bought it the day of its release.

I'll try to encapsulate the pros and cons as succinctly as possible.

PROS:
- You play the cutest character in the game (or maybe that's not a pro)
- The game itself clearly thinks succumbing to the whims of a creepy stalking and controlling boyfriend is a bad idea, and tells you so if you actually get a certain character's good ending by questioning your taste.
- It's another otome in the market that's fun, even if it isn't stellar.
- The final route is pretty damn fun.
- Shin is probably one of the most refreshingly sensible characters I've seen in a visual novel when it comes to using his brain. I just wish he didn't look like a Hot Topic victim, though if he was the only one who did, it would make more sense as a style choice? Everyone dressing this way was pretty bizarre.
- Ukyo.
- I can only assume that every single character in this is secretly a cyborg trying to pass as a human, given their eyes.
- Has one of the most healthy relationships I've seen in the Clover route, though it's also one of the most boring routes to me ever. I would've much preferred it if the Clover route had more of a murder mystery going for it, with Ken being extremely helpful and aiding the character or...something. I dunno, that route REALLY NEEDS SOMETHING, but it still gets in the PRO section due to the rarity of a sane relationship in otome games.

CONS:
- TOMA. 
- TOMA.
- A lot of Ukyo's appearances are less intriguing than intended, even if I get the intention behind the portrayal, it's still a bit of a failure.
- Some of the style choices of the artwork itself is ridiculous, such as proportions and the like at certain angles. This is a preference thing and I probably wouldn't notice it as much if the men didn't look designed for the next Hot Topic Barbie Contest.
- Most of the routes are really, really, really uninteresting for me. 

Ultimately I think a lot of people will love Amnesia...and a lot of people really won't. Ultimately, I recommend going for better visual novels, or better otomes, if that particular subgenre is what you're searching for. 

Better Otomes in particular: Sweet Fuse for the PSP, Nameless on Steam, Hakuoki on PS3, VITA or PSP.
Better Visual Novels in general: Any visual novel with an interesting plot like Fate/Stay Night, Fruit of Grisaia (from what I've played; Haven't completed this one yet), or Nameless.

23861533.review:
Warning: This game includes very upsetting scenarios (I'm looking at you, Toma). I would not let impressionable, young audiences play it.

I should start by saying that the reason I bought this game is because I watched the anime (which is based off this game) and I thought it would be interesting to see the different adaptations and interpretations. I think watching the anime can give you a good idea of what to expect in the most extreme paths (Diamond/Joker worlds). 

In the game, each path leads to a full story, which makes it a lot easier to understand. The main character is still passive, which was the main complaint people had about the anime. Not every path leads to a healthy, happy relationship. I don't think anyone should play this game with the expectation of using it as reference for real life romance. That said, the CGs and voice acting are amazing. I also enjoyed the mini games, even if they're a bit buggy. 

The general storyline/world building is not that great, but I didn't buy an otome game expecting to get the next Game of Thrones. What's important is the special scenes and those were really nicely written. I managed to laugh and be torn in quite a few of them. 

My advice: if you want a mild, happy romance, this is not it (unless you stick to the clover world). Watch the anime first, then figure out if the themes are something you're ok with. If you are like me and enjoy comparing different adaptations of a single work, this might be an amusing game to analyze.

23822179.review:
Buy this game. Maybe it's not worth $30 (i got it for $3), but a very solid otome game nonetheless (i would buy it for 10-20 bucks). It took me about 4 hours to finish 1 of the paths and there are ~3 paths for each character. it took me 17 hours to finish all the paths for one character plus all the minigames ( this includes me leaving the game open and forgetting to pick choices for minutes on end).  If youre like me and keep going back into the game to see all the endings, you should save the game right before you pick the worlds while youre in the dream world, so you dont need to keep going through the intro everytime you go back to pick a character or redo a route. 

(I'll edit this review after i finish the game and all achievements)

TL;DR pretty cool game. Has it's bugs and can be contradicting. Choices dont really translate well so they seem similar. if you keep playing for all endings can get boring and repetative, however picking different chocies can lead to long interesting scenes which can ease your boredom when replaying. imo not as good as the ones you can get on your phone. (be my princess, thief x, My forged wedding, etc...)

Pros
--- Cute story

--- The routes, though they have similar aspects to keep the story going, all have different flows depending on the path you take so its not too repetitive like other otome games i've played. 

--- Nice art

--- The choices are good and things I would actually say

--- No misunderstanding in the choices (example. if the choice is 'I wanna go with you...' it wont turn into a i wanna go with you, but *some excuse why you actually dont want to*. It really will be I wanna go with you...)

--- Voices

--- You are the main character. Since she lost her memories and such you pretty much are her and what you think are her thoughts. Orion makes up for some things by being the voice only you can hear which is also nice.

Cons
--- slow start

--- Price (30 bucks is just too much for an otome game imo, but it really is well developed so if youre okay with paying this much go for it. it is worth it)

--- All voice acting is in Japanese. i was okay with it, but others may not be

--- Game crashes when you try to adjust the size of the window (sometimes)

--- You cant alt+tab to change (you can alt+enter, but it just makes it windowed and it bothered me a bit)

--- Had to be windowed in order to exit game (no button/option to exit)

Both
--- MC doesnt do much all talking is done by other character
                     I dont like this because i would like to have some characterization on the girl, but i do like it because it makes me feel more like i am the character in the game.

--- Even though the story is good i noticed some places where it wasnt very consistent. It would be like they forgot the choice you made earlier or just ignore it all together. Not too big of a deal though.

---you sometimes get similar options (yeah or yes) i was okay with this but i read reviews where others disliked this. In japan there are formal ways to speak to people and informal, so the yeah would be informal and yes would be formal. It made sense, but i understand wanting variety

--- sometimes you only get one option. This is because the options come up when the MC needs to talk or make any decision (which is understandable). this doesnt happen too often and usually only after making a 2/3 option decision.

23696827.review:
Amnesia memories is one of the few visual novels which I have completed. Often I’d start one but would end up losing interest half way through the novel but amnesia memories held my interest throughout the majority of the story.

I have to admit that the initial plot is average and is something that comes up quite often. As it centres around a girl who has amnesia and sets out to remember her past without letting others suspect her of her memory loss. It has a mystery plot with a twist [spoiler] which you’ll find out once you get to the joker route.	[/spoiler]  At that point it will start to make sense and it eventually comes to a nice conclusion.

Characters- you have your cliché love interests, the tsundere, the emotionless smart guy, the playboy, the yandere and the…I’ll leave the last guys personality up in the air, as he’s my favourite character and it’s best to discover what he’s like as you progress through the story. Furthermore each hero is unique and different enough to keep you interested. Side characters such as Mine and the manager seem to have a different personality depending on the route which keeps you guessing there motive and whether they want to hurt you or befriend you.

The soundtrack and voice acting is superb. 

At times their may have been moments where I wanted to scream at the heroine [spoiler] especially during Tomas route	[/spoiler] but I endured through them so I could get to the Joker route and get the good ending in that, I did not regret it one bit.

Overall I recommend this visual novel to those who are fans of the genre, want to get into visual novels or simply want something more and better than its anime adaption.

Cons:

23693051.review:
This game is the first visual novel I've ever played, and I must say that I'm quite impressed by it. I especially love how different the guys are from each other, but in some ways also quite similar. They can all be nice and cruel when they want to, but they all show it in diffrent ways. You can play in five different worlds, and you can swich between them whenever you feel like it. Furthermore, if you get tired of the game, there are two mini games that you can play as well: Airhockey and Rock Paper Scissors. However, I personally feel like I didn't get to controll the game as much as I wanted to. You don't really get to talk that much, it's mostly the other characters and the spirit (Orion) that controls the game. All in all I think this a very interesting and entertaining game. If you are a person that like good visual novels, this is a game I would strongly recommend for you

PROS
- In-depth plot and characters
- Unpredictable stories and endings
- Beautiful layout
- Conversations of different character; they can be both amusing, scary, sad, angry and unexpected
- Entertaining mini games
- You can choose between five different worlds
- It gives you clues about your past, almost like a puzzle game, so you can figure out what happened


CONS

- The air hockey can respond quite slowly, which makes it harder or even impossible to win
- Sometimes you only have one option to choose what you want to say
- Orion, the spirit, can be quite annoying (I was quite annoyed by how it got to decide so much in the game and just   assumed things, but that is just my personal opinion)

23685494.review:
so, first review! hopefully i can be of some help ;w;

[b]overall score:[/b] 10/10

[b]pros[/b]
1) gorgeous art and stunning CGs [which are also very plentiful! if i'm not wrong there are about 30 per route for the first four, so that alone is about 120...i can't speak for the hidden route, but i can't imagine much changes]
2) original premise and good storywriting; a predetermined boyfriend is definitely a change!
3) unique love interests who do have their flaws [perhaps some of them a little too much!] but are, in general, a refreshing change from the lovey-dovey, completely perfect boys found in other otomes
4) beautiful soundtrack and voice acting
5) great atmosphere and it's very easy to get very connected to the characters/situation

[b]cons[/b]
1) lack of english voice acting; personally this didn't bother me as i normally play in japanese either way, but i know that some people prefer english voice acting
2) the parameter system [affection/trust/suspicion and doubt in a certain route] is not ever really explained in the game, which can be kind of confusing
3) the game can be kind of slow to progress and a few days often go by without much happening
4) some of the characters are [i]very[/i] problematic [though this won't bother everyone]
5) super minor, but the air hockey game is super duper hard to play due to lag; if you're one for getting all achievements in a game, this will probably be a bit annoying for you! [tip: disabling all sounds before playing air hockey usually lessens the lag a little, but it's still far from ideal]

[b]general review:[/b] overall, i really had to struggle to come up with cons for this game; [i]amnesia: memories[/i] is quite possibly one of the most unique, well written otomes i've ever played and really sets the bar quite high for those to follow. the characters are all very well written, their development is shown very clearly and they really do feel much more human than a lot of the love interests in other VNs; to boot, the artwork, OST and voice acting is astounding. a real sense of mystery and tension can be felt in this game and i wholeheartedly recommend to those considering playing to buy it because you won't be disappointed; before long you'll find yourself falling in love with this comical, memorable cast.

[on a side note, kent is the best boyfriend]

Хотела написать большой обзор, но вот какая вещь. На самом деле, в плане сюжета тут как в Undertale -- чем меньше знаешь, тем больше впечатлений получаешь. Я серьёзно. 

Если вы пришли сюда после просмотра аниме-адаптации, то не переживайте -- как говорится, книга лучше. Если вы не смотрели аниме по этой игре -- не смотрите. Правда. Не делайте этого. 
---
Если по сути и без спойлеров: отомка ох как хороша. Графон тут на высоте. Единственное, к чему можно придраться, так это к глазам и бровям, которые просвечиваются через волосы. Но, знаете ли, насмотревшись на всякий графоний в стиме, эта придирка уже не играет особой роли. 

Сюжет и персонажи не блещут особой оригинальностью. У нас тут есть привычные в отоме типажи: тсундере, нёрд, Казанова, яндере и персонаж с тяжёлой судьбой. Но в каждом руте есть своя изюминка, которая разбавляет атмосферу. Например, у местного тсундере в руте присутствует сносная детективная линия (для отоме игры-то), ветка нёрда -- чистый ламповый slice of life и так далее. 

Короче, если вы любите отоме -- однозначный must-have. Если любите визуальные новеллы, то можете взять на свой страх и риск, ну а вдруг.

[h1] 8/10[/h1]

P. S. Будьте осторожны при выборе Diamond World'а. Я вас предупредила.

23572222.review:
[url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=fWIHf6QT0wc] Full Review on Youtube[/url]

A visually stunning, conceptually unique otome game with a haunting melancholic tone.

[b]Pros:[/b]

- An interesting and original premise
- Gorgeous artwork with subtly animated sprites
- Hauntingly beautiful music
- Charming side characters 

[b]Cons:[/b]

- Unintuitive, confusing "affection/trust/suspicion" system that's never explained in-game
- Achievements don't trigger correctly
- The guys' personalities are [i]very[/i] extreme
- Seriously, chances are you're gonna hate the hell out of at least [i]one[/i] route


[i]Amnesia: Memories[/i] is the otome game equivalent of Marmite. You're either gonna fall madly in love with it's awesome music, beautiful artwork and deeply flawed, but charming guys or you're gonna be disgusted by it's crawling pace, confusing choices and highly problematic relationship dynamics. 

As for me, I enjoyed this game despite its flaws, and I'd like to see Idea Factory bring over at least [i]one[/i] of the fandisks.

23093405.review:
I don't normally write reviews, but this visual novel has left an exceptional impression on me. Since this game is nothing but story, I'll try to keep it spoiler-free.

(Side-note: This visual novel has an anime! It's crap compared to the game though, so I don't recommend that)

Overall Positive Features:

Story - This is the most important part of the game, so respectfully it's the best part. There are five arcs to this game, each pertaining to one of the five main male characters. Even if you aren't the biggest fan of the main male character to the arc, the heroine's relationship to him is generally not the only focus of the story, so it's still enjoyable.

Japanese Voice-acting - the voice acting work of this game is well-done; character voices fit the personalities appropriately, and nobody sounds like an emotionless brick unless they're supposed to.

Character art and CGs - The design of the characters and the CGs are really nice in my opinion- even if you're really stingy about art, the designs are at the very least tolerable.

Music - The soundtrack of this game is fantastic and fits the mood extremely well. The song for the opening movie also has a lot of hype, I love it.

Things You May Find Iffy:

Orion - Orion is a character that is with you throughout the entire game and provides commentary on what's happening around you for the majority of the game. He's also extremely important to the plot, so even if you don't like him, you're stuck with him. Personally I like Orion, but his constant presence can be annoying to players. Since you can't 'disable' him, it can ruin the game for you if you don't like him.

Background Art - I'll level with you. There's only like three or four colors along with some gradient in them most of the time, excluding white. I personally don't mind this since it allows me to focus on the characters in front of me rather than being distracted by a super-detailed background, but you may find it a bit too washed-out for your taste (check the screenshots on the store page to see if you like it or not).

Bonus:

Endings - This game has A LOT of endings. Every arc has at least four endings: The good ending, the normal ending, and at least two bad endings, with a total of 26 endings.

Memories & Extras - Okay, so at some point, you will unlock the item "Memories" for the main menu. The Memories are little bonus scenes where the heroine spends time with that character at some point during the story. Next, there's the item "Extras" which you also unlock at some point for the main menu. These are basically silent thoughts from the main male of a particular arc. And by silent, I mean there isn't any voice acting, it's pretty much just pure reading.

CG Voice Clips: As you unlock CGs, you can review them in the gallery, which is pretty standard. Certain CGs (that is, CGs with a little red rose in the corner of the preview) will play voice clips when you ctrl + left click certain areas with about five different voice clips to each CG (this includes alternate versions of that CG, by the way). While it's a nice feature, looking for these things becomes a clicking hunt as there is no indication that you can actually click there (and for shorter voice clips, you're sometimes supposed to click on an area multiple times).

Mini-Games: Okay, now this is kind of silly, but this game has it's own version of rock-paper-scissors and air hockey. Rock-paper-scissors got turned into a reflex game where you have to "attack" if you win so you get a point, or "defend" if you lose so they don't get a point. Air hockey is, well, air hockey. You can play against the five main guys as kind of varying levels of difficulty, and you get an achievement for beating them all. The moral of this story is that if you're getting frustrated at one of the guys, you can just beat them at air hockey and rock-paper-scissors.

My Final Thoughts:

Overall I think this game is fantastic and while it's definitely not an experience meant for everybody (the heroine having a romantic relationship with one of five guys should have made that obvious) I personally believe that the story is enjoyable to anyone who enjoys romance (I do suggest however that if you're not of the intended audience you should just look up a walkthrough of this game, and again, don't even bother with the anime).

23044261.review:
When life gives you lemons, do you throw them at your friends? Maybe at a wall instead? Or....perhaps, do you squeeze the juice out and make lemonade? The possibilities are pretty much endless. Excuse me for my silly segue, but in an odd way Amnesia: Memories reminds us that life is full of possibilities - so, which will you take?

[h1]The Breakdown[/h1]
Amnesia (no, not the horror game that exploded in popularity on YouTube a few years back!) is a Japanese visual novel developed and published by Idea Factory under their "Otomate" brand. Now, if you're not familiar with the term "otome", that usually refers to visual novels with a female main character that dates males. If you don't recognize the term "visual novel", it's basically what it sounds like: a novel of sorts with accompanying visuals. 

The gameplay in Amnesia involves choices quite often, so it's more of a choose your own adventure sort of deal instead of just walls of text. Personally, I really liked this approach because the game has a lot of endings (20+), especially bad ones. The differences between "good" and "normal" endings are usually somewhat minor, but the difference between a "good" and a "bad" ending is huge - usually bad endings result in death, I was really surprised to see this from a visual novel, especially one about dating pretty dudes. Sure, a lot of the bad endings are silly, but some of them were genuinely creepy. The dark aspects hiding under the game's innocent front were a little surprising to say the least.

What truly surprised me though was the game's characters, especially the main 5 "dateable" guys. At the start of the game, you're given a choice between 4 worlds (Heart, Spade, Clover, Diamond), each of which has a main dude to focus on. Sure, in most of the worlds nearly all of the main cast is present (which includes coworkers, occasionally family members, and the extra friend or two), but clearly the male lead is what the game wants you to focus on. However, nearly all of the characters in this game are pretty interesting, from the bizarre manager at work to the mysterious Ukyo, the 5th unlockable "true ending" guy. There were a few exceptions, but I think that all comes down to personal preference in the end. Personally I didn't care for Shin or Ikki's routes much, while Kent (my favorite), Toma, and Ukyo all had pretty interesting routes with some nice twists and turns along the way. 

I loved Kent's route in particular because it was great to see him develop as a character along the way; he goes from being a serious, rational, analytical type of person with seemingly no emotions to someone who is very sweet and caring. Most of the main dudes also develop along their routes, but just to clarify - it doesn't ever really feel like the game is overly mushy-gushy or stereotypical for visual novels. The dialogue is cleverly written and it helps to make the experience quite enjoyable.

Well, mostly at least. There was one character in particular that bugged me to no end: Orion. "Who the hell is that?" you might ask. Well, he's the little guy who caused you to have amnesia in the first place. He's a spirit that follows you around everywhere, and I think he seriously could have been handled a bit better. Orion [i]loves[/i] to state the obvious, and he does so at every occasion. I think the entire game's length could be shrunk by an hour or two if Orion talked less honestly, though some of his dialogue is pretty important so I think he's still a fairly worthwhile addition to the cast.

Despite that gripe though, I really enjoyed my time with Amnesia. The visuals are lovely and the music is a good mix between emotionally stirring melodies and casual background tunes. Whether you're a secret anime boyfriend harem lover, a fan of visual novels, or even just someone that enjoys solid writing, I think Amnesia is certainly a great experience.

[h1]Pros[/h1]
[list]
[*]Superb writing, dialogue, and characters
[*]20+ endings, many of which are bad ones that may or may not result in death
[*]4 dateable dudes with an extra mysterious 5th unlockable one
[*]Takes about 20-30 hours to get all the endings (about 3-5 hours for each route), depending on how fast you read and how well you manage save files
[*]Lovely music + visuals
[*]Japanese voice acting
[*]Steam achievements, trading cards, and Cloud support
[/list]

[h1]Cons[/h1]
[list]
[*]Orion (the reason you have amnesia in the first place) can be annoying at times - he talks way too much and his voice isn't exactly easy on the ears after hours and hours of listening to him
[*]The outfits of the males (and 1 female) are a little ridiculous.....oh, who am I kidding? This is such a minor complaint. Just go play the game!
[/list]

Amnesia: Memories isn't perfect, but it's pretty damn excellent. For fans of otome (girls x guys) visual novels, anime, or just reading in general, this is an absolutely great game that shouldn't be missed!




Oh, and Kent is the best. Your favorite is the worst.

[h1][b]Final Verdict: 9/10[/b][/h1]

23031119.review:
[i]Sometimes, life gives us a new chance of starting new things or taking different decisions. This is the story of Amnesia: memories.[/i]

[h1]Introduction[/h1]

What if you have an accident and forget everything of the past months? What would you do? How would we start again? When you wake up there's no friends or family at that moment. But maybe you don't wake up in a familiar place but at another dimension. Then you meet someone who wants to help,a spirit - he said, called Orion. He explains what's going on, he's attached to your soul and also, he's gonna help you to recover your memories. And at the end, he gives you a choice, to back to your world. Which one? Several, infinite dimensions, but you have five. Just pick one, and the adventure begins.

If you love anime you'll love Amnesia: memories. Personally , I'm not a big anime fan but I use to watch some. And believe me, is even better than just watching a series. Here you are part of the story, in a sort of "choose your own adventure" with the condiment of romance and many other things. Things about life after all, and you won't regret to explore every way of choices ahead. Just be careful in what you say or do, things could be good or wrong. You are advised!

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]

Here you play with a girl, and you can choose her name. Personally, I'd love to play as a boy too but I think the game was conceived for visual novel fan girls. When I told you about the five worlds, that's because every world has a male main character and you will see the rest as secondaries. The worlds have a unique history and several endings, some sad, some great and some... spoilers!

How the game works? basically, you'll have several dialogues, and you Orion, this spirit will help you telling what to do, sometimes Orion could be a little bit irritating sometimes, but he is constantly helping us. Of course, he has his own opinions about what's going on around us. 

Old memories are lost but they will come, you have to achieve that, of course, will depend on wich path you follow and how you act with the people around your character.  This is the story of a girl, maybe many girls in many universes with different situations.

This game has something I don't use to see a lot, even in graphic adventures which I love to play: the voices. Every character has a unique voice and shows perfect their nature, along with the great storyboard that makes this game a jewel in the genre of visual novels. 

Music and graphics: lovely, they are so anime(ish), and all ambience, music, art concept, it's great. I repeat, a jewel in many aspects this game Amnesia: memories.

[h1]Extra Issues and final thoughts[/h1]

About playing... I advise you to save the game when you have the chance of pick one of the five worlds, so you can skip the whole conversation with Orion at the beginning wich is a little long for my taste. Also, save just in case, there are several save slots, use them! So you can go back just in case and let's see what happen if you pick a different dialogue option.

As an extra there are minigames you can play at the introduction, and also you have steam achievements to get.

Thanks for this game, it's really just awesome, maybe on of the best visual novels. Is like reading a book, but with choices, something very immersive. I'm sure you will enjoy playing Amnesia: Memories.

Thanks to the developers for such great game!

23022323.review:
I was annoyed with Orion, but overall I love this game. Orion annoyed me so much, I finally muted the game so I didn't have to hear his voice (right clicked volume in taskbar, opened volume mixer, muted game... in case anyone else wants to). I also wish there was a way to ONLY skip over Orion's dialogue, because all he really does is point out the obvious, and reiterate what we've already learned. He also asks questions that annoyed me, like "why is he acting different suddenly?" and I would heckel him the ENTIRE time, asking if he's even paying attention to the story or the datable males. If he asks a question requiring a response, the scroll wheel works to see what the question was when the options pop up.
I did experience the weird screen glitch where some green writing would be displayed for a split second, but it didn't bother me because it was so fast.

I finished this game in a matter of days (two, I think?). I stayed up after midnight just to finish one storyline. Each character took a few hours to finish, even if I was skipping through already read dialogue the second and third time around (this is with saves corresponding to a walkthrough). I got every ending, though I'm still missing a couple of pictures in the album. Each character has his endearing qualities, and not-so-endearing qualities, and each ending left me either disappointed or flying high. Definitely worth the play.

22971897.review:
While I enjoy dating sims as much as the next guy I found this game to really stand out. For two reasons. The first one (being a bit of a negative) is at least for me it seemed a bit too easy to get the “bad endings” with most (if not all) of the guys in question which made it a bit hard to carry on when you get invested in a character to basically be in full tears and just want to lay on the floor for hours like human trash. However at the same time this is a POSITIVE partly because it means you can get into the story that is unfolding enjoy to feel those endings and just to hate yourself and what causes said events to happen.

The seconds reason (which is a big positive) I like how they connect everything. By this I mean the characters and the stories all at once. (not going to go into detail because spoilers) Also all not only do each of the dateable guys seem to have completely different personalities and likes so do the outside characters such as friends and co-workers. Which really gives it a nice touch since it doesn’t feel like you're just interacting with Guy A or Guy B. When you talk to someone like Kent it’s different talking to him as it would if you were talking to someone like Ikki. 

The only other “Negative” that came up for me would be that Orion can get on my nerves. I think this is because after going after the same guy for roughly the fourth time in an attempt to get the good ending you kind of want to strangle him when you sits there just recapping what happened not even three minutes ago in game.

Overall though I deeply enjoyed this game, yes it has some rather adult themes and dark scenarios but I rather enjoyed it since some of them catch you off guard and end up adding something to the story and even making you re-think about some of the characters you meet when you go down different paths.

Amnesia is one of the games I played, because I've watched the anime.
The anime got me curious so I went to play it.
The game is like really gorgeous. Gorgeous graphics. Not so gorgeous when they zoom in though.
Each of the love interests has a different route. So you won't experience the same stories over and over again.
The (side) characters will change their personality too depending on the route you are taking.
Variety in the game is on point. The mini games though, I don't really get that, but it's just so-so. It looks cute, at least.
Yeah.. I would recommend it to people who like those cute love stories with a hint of mystery. 
And of course, cute guys !!
And at each guy you can get different endings, a good one, normal one or bad one(s). It all depends on the character how many bad endings you can get. So your choices definitely have some impact.
The only bad thing about the whole game is, that when you take a new route you need to go through the memory loss thing over and over again. In each world she loses her memory again in the beginning. And you experience the intro all over again, it's mostly a little bit different each time, but it's kind of the same idea rip. 
If you want a taste (or some preview) of the game, may contain some spoilers though, watch the anime. If you just want to take a look what the story is about, watch episode 1. The heroine in the anime is kind of annoying though, looks like she isn't capable of doing anything, in the game she (you) is much more fun :)
Truly a good visual novel. I liked every route. It didn't feel boring at all. 10/10 for me !

22895193.review:
Amnesia™: Memories è un otome game che vale la pena provare. Per i suoi disegni, per la bella trama, per i risvolti adorabili e, perché no, anche per quelli più inquietanti e macabri.

La protagonista all'inizio del gioco si ritrova in uno spazio indefinito, a cavallo tra diverse dimensioni parallele. È lì che fa la conoscenza di Orion, uno spirito che si è improvvisamente fuso con la sua mente. La presenza di Orion ha fatto perdere alla protagonista tutti i propri ricordi, fatta eccezione per il senso comune e per i ricordi legati alle sue funzioni vitali - come si mangia, come si dorme, come si respira.
La ragazza, per sopravvivere, deve subito attraversare una delle quattro [spoiler]o cinque[/spoiler] porte che si ritrova davanti: ognuna la condurrà in un diverso mondo, dove dovrà interagire con le persone che la circondano e cercare così di rievocare i propri ricordi perduti. Non può tuttavia andare in un ospedale (restare inattiva e lontana da tutti peggiorerebbe le sue condizioni), inoltre deve fare attenzione a non rivelare la verità sulla propria amnesia alla persona sbagliata, se non vuole rischiare che questa cerchi di approfittare della sua situazione.

Parlando del gioco in sé, l'ho trovato davvero molto godibile. Ho trovato i personaggi ben approfonditi - o almeno una buona fetta di essi lo è - e le storie sono tutte credibili, senza good ending o bad ending che sembrino forzate. Mi è piaciuto moltissimo il fatto che non ci sia una narrazione di ciò che succede, ma solo i dialoghi dei vari personaggi (con audio in giapponese), oltre a quello di Orion che, per quanto sia il personaggio che parla di più in tutto il gioco, non ho mai sentito come una presenza fastidiosa o pesante, come invece succede di solito con i personaggi del suo stesso genere. Ho apprezzato molto di più i design dei personaggi nel corso del gioco rispetto ai CG, ma questa è tutta una questione di gusti personali.
Se cercate degli avvertimenti più specifici per ciò che potreste trovare nel gioco, li scrivo qui sotto come spoiler.
[spoiler]Oltre a una quantità abbondante di momenti romantici e adorabili, nel gioco ci sono anche minacce di morte, assassinii più o meno espliciti e più o meno riusciti, cooldere, yandere, casi di sdoppiamento di personalità, possessione, elementi fantasy e tanto, TANTO drama.[/spoiler]

È un gioco che consiglio in generale, sia agli amanti del genere che a chi non ha mai preso in mano nessun videogioco come questo prima d'ora. Le good ending non sono troppo facili da ottenere e a ogni lieto fine corrisponde una buona quantità di bad ending in cui si rischia di incappare: posso dire che il gioco non si lascia concludere con facilità, ma proprio per questo mi ha dato un'impressione ancora migliore.

22868563.review:
I decided to check out this game after being viewing a few episodes of the anime of the same name. I'd found the art style beautiful but the main character flat. The game, I feel, is somewhat better than the anime, but not without it's flaws. The story is filled with anime/Hime cliches. However, certain storylines were compelling enough to make me continue regardless. In particular, I enjoyed the Heart, Diamond & Joker worlds. The characters, while nothing I haven't seen before, were fun & enjoyable, & all had their own unique personalities. I also liked that you're only romancing one boy per world, so there's no half-hearted romances with the other characters. The art style, as in the anime, in gorgeous, & I personally enjoyed the ability to skip dialogue you've already seen until you get to a choice or new content, which makes the inevitable repeated playthroughs much less tedious.

Overall, I recommend Amnesia: Memories for anyone who enjoys narrative-driven visual novels & gamers who are curious about the growing trend. But if you hate anime tropes or aren't a fan of the genre, this probably won't change your mind.

22814742.review:
Finally finished~ After over 60 hours, I got to witness every single ending this game has to offer and all the extra content.

I went into this game having already watched the anime, so I'm already used to the heroine being a very passive type, as well as some quirks of the other characters (I'm looking at you, Toma). So I don't really have any complaints in that regard.

Amnesia is a fantastic mystery-oriented, somewhat dark romance dating sim. You play as a heroine who wakes up with amnesia and you must try to hide your amnesia. This concept works really well because you as the player don't have any idea what's going on with the heroine's life. All the characters have their own charm and they're not stereotypical or flat. The UI is super smooth, the art is gorgeous, the music suits the mood and doesn't get too repetitive, and the voice acting...-it's really good. I got this game on sale and I felt like it was a great catch. This game made me question my choices and I actually learned a bit more about myself and how I would react in certain touchy situations.

Individual route reviews! Characters completed so far: CONTAINS SPOILERS 

[b]Toma:[/b] Toma was the first one I chose, and yeah, many people find his to be the most shocking route. In fact, I got the bad end as my first playthrough, ahaha. I find it diificult to like or dislike him. I...am aware of the fact that's he not quite right in the head, but...I'm ashamed to say that I really like Toma. Since he's not real, he's not a threat to my well-being. Although if he were real then I'd stay far away. But I was beside myself with mixed emotions when I did the happy end. Toma is a really pitiful character, his pain makes me feel sorry for him and I wish I could help him, so I guess the happy end did work out for me in the end, although some people might disagree. Overall, I actually like Toma (though a part of me is fighting it).

[b]Shin:[/b] the second character I decided to play. He has a really harsh personality, and he's younger than you, which makes him act even more harsh and independent because he wants to be on equal footing with you. He's pretty much the opposite of Toma; bitter on the outside, sweet on the inside. He does have a lot of swoon-worthy qualities, such as his sense of honor and his sudden kisses, and his bass playing in secret so he could surprise you and join your band, and he's also very human because he does have his weaknesses. It's easy to see why he's the featured character for the game. I remember his happy end made me cry because it was really sweet. Personally, his harsh personality isn't my type but he's a pretty likeable character.

[b]Kent:[/b] by far the biggest surprise for me. He is introduced as a very stoic graduate student who loves to disagree and argue with you. He's also very blunt and can say insensitive things. BUT. Kent is a very innocent and sweet character (once you get to know him later, of course). Having no experience in romance, he's extremely cute and honest. I do find his personality rather rare if not unrealistic. I absolutely loved his happy end (and I got it on my first try too). If you thought Shin's happy end was sweet, Kent's happy end was ten times as sweet. He's also the only one (I know, so far) that knows and believes Orion.

[b]Ikki:[/b] this is your playboy character. He's surrounded by fangirls and I initially thought it would be similar to Toma's route, but nope. The bullying was way worse in Toma's route. Ikki really isn't my type. He's sincere with you, so it's a matter of getting your character to trust Ikki. There were some quirks in Ikki's personality that I was surprised by...like how fragile he actually is (but not as fragile as Toma). He's also not very perceptive, unlike Shin and Toma who were super sharp and figured out you had amnesia on day 1 (Ikki finds out on the last day...gg). I thought the story would delve deeper into why Ikki wanted you to fall in love with him within 3 months (I thought it had something to do with breaking the spell put on his eyes, but I guess not). Overall, I found that it was pretty enjoyable, he's a smooth talker but I can never put much value on his words and I had a hard time seeing a logical progression of feelings. It could be just me, though.

[b]Ukyo:[/b] poor crybaby Ukyo, I cried too.

After all that, I can't decide who I liked best. I know Ikki comes in last (sorry Ikki fans), just because he wasn't my type. If you had to twist my arm and make me choose, I'll probably go for Toma...even though he's disliked for various reasons. ^^

Some minor complaints I have is that some scenarios aren't really consistent. It seems like only the good end route is the route that's completely consistent, while in the other routes the game seems to forget some details based on the choices you make. I also am not too fond of rereading the same text 4 times to get all the endings since there isn't too much variation in the story except for the end, but most VNs are like that. I also don't like rereading the prologue 50 times because it really doesn't add to the reading experience each time, I'd suggest adding a skip option for the prologue so the player can just get on with it.  It also bothers me that the lip flap movements don't sync up with the voice acting, especially when the speech is being dragged out (I'm looking at you, Toma's seiyuu), but it's easy to ignore if you're reading the text most of the time. I really love the character art, but when the characters look surprised, they actually look like they're terrified...but these are all pretty minor flaws.

Overall, this game is fantastic and I would definitely recommend playing if you're into dark romance dating sims!

Reading them is just hard at times is all and replaying to just make a few different choices can break the experience a little, though it's a minor complaint.

10/10 Not completely perfect, but leagues above others and only nitpicks that can't be against the game, just my own bad choice making it would seem. lol

22769097.review:
"Amnesia: Memories" to gra stworzona przed studio Idea Factory i wydana 11 sierpnia 2011 roku. Z początku była przeznaczona jedynie na przenośne konsole PSP, ale jej rosnąca popularność pozwoliła jej podbić również komputery osobiste i platformę PlayStation Vita. Światło dzienne na Zachodzie ujrzała 25 września 2015 roku, niemalże z miejsca zyskując status kultowej.

W grze wcielamy się w niej w postać młodej dziewczyny, która doznaje utraty pamięci. Przyczyną całego ambarasu jest Orion - uroczy duszek z równoległej rzeczywistości, który przez przypadek wpadł w umysł bohaterki, wypychając z niego wspomnienia. Kierowany poczuciem winy, postanawia pomóc jej złożyć wszystko w całość. Nie będzie to jednak łatwym zadaniem - nie tylko dlatego, że Orion nie może mieć żadnego wpływu na świat zewnętrzny (a więc do końca pozostanie jedynie głosem w naszej głowie), ale również dlatego, że musimy uchronić się przed ludźmi, którzy mogliby zechcieć wykorzystać naszą amnezję do własnych celów. W dodatku w tle grasuje morderca, który jedynie czeka na popełniony przez nas błąd. Musimy dobrze ukrywać swoje braki w pamięci i jednocześnie dbać o odpowiednią stymulację umysłu i doświadczanie dużej ilości bodźców, mogących naprowadzić nas na trop wspomnień. Nie będziemy jednak sami - w zależności od dokonanego na początku gry wyboru, powrócimy do świata jako wybranka serca jednego z czterech uroczych chłopców (wątek piątego z nich można odblokować tylko poprzez ukończenie poprzednich). Jednak jedynie od nas zależy, czy nasz ukochany rzeczywiście zostanie naszym sprzymierzeńcem, czy też przemieni się w naszego najgorszego wroga.

Należy zaznaczyć, że poszczególne wątki w porównaniu z innymi grami otome są raczej krótkie - każdy z nich można spokojnie ukończyć w 7-8 godzin. Jest jednak pewna rzecz, która je wyróżnia - korzystają z tego samego settingu, ale opowiadają zupełnie różne historie. I tak w jednym Toma może być naszym chłopakiem tylko po to, żeby w innym wskoczyć na miejsce starszego brata. W jednym szef kawiarenki, w której pracujemy, jest osobą ciepłą i łagodną, a w innym tyranem strzelającycm do ludzi laserami z oczu (chociaż na szczęście nie dosłownie). Jednocześnie fabuła każdego z wątków jest zaskakująco spójna, ciekawa i dosyć mroczna - ilość trudnych i kontrowersyjnych tematów sprawia, że gra może nie spodobać się młodszym osobom. Całość czyta się naprawdę dobrze i jeśli jedynie lubicie podobne klimaty, powinniście być zadowoleni.

Jest jednak w tej grze rzecz, która ewidentnie kuleje - kreacja bohaterów. Jestem przyzwyczajona do tego, że bohaterkami gier otome są zazwyczaj szare myszki, ale w przypadku "Amnesii..." mamy do czynienia z chyba najbardziej bierną protagonistką wszech czasów. Twórcy niemalże wymuszają na nas uległość względem innych postaci, nie pozwalając na zdecydowane rozwiązania i nie pozostawiając nam dużego pola do manewru. Chłopcy są sympatyczni i warci poznania, ale przyznam szczerze, że chyba żadna inna gra nie przedstawia tak dużej zbieraniny mężczyzn z zaburzeniami osobowości. Osobiście lubię, kiedy bohaterowie przedstawiają sobą różne typy charakterów, ale jednak zachowują się w sposób naturalny i swobodny. Lubię, kiedy mogę powiedzieć: "Z takim mężczyzną jak X na pewno związałabym się w realnym świecie". Tymczasem gdybym spotkała realnego Tomę, Shina, Ikkiego i Kenta (o Ukyo nie wspominając), to uciekałabym od nich jak najdalej. Być może problem tkwi tak naprawdę w różnicach kulturowych i zachowania, które podobają się Azjatkom, niekoniecznie muszą trafiać w gusta Europejek. W kolejnych wpisach postaram się przybliżyć Wam bohaterów "Amnesii...", więc będziecie mogli wyrobić sobie swoją własną opinię.

Na uwagę zasługuje również oprawa audiowizualna. Muzyka nie przytłacza i służy oddaniu klimatu określonej sceny w grze - nie wpada w ucho, ale również nie irytuje swoją powtarzalnością. Jeśli zaś chodzi o grafikę, to w przypadku "Amnesii..." zachodzi pewien paradoks - ilustracje wyglądają gorzej, niż przedstawienie postaci w grze. Przyznam szczerze, że w zasadzie żadna z ilustracji nie przypadła mi do gustu, głównie ze względu na mało proporcjonalne twarze bohaterów, a szczególnie protagonistki. Natomiast w grze postacie wyglądają naprawdę dobrze i są przepięknie animowane - grałam w wiele gier otome, ale to właśnie w tej urzekł mnie sposób animowania oczu i ust. Sam design postaci może się podobać lub nie - to oczywiście kwestia gustu. W mojej opinii bohaterowie są zdecydowanie za bardzo wychudzeni i nieproporcjonalni - ja wiem, że według japońskich standardów postać powinna mieć nogi aż do nieba, ale mi akurat średnio to odpowiada. Również ubiór naszych ulubieńców jest dosyć... dyskusyjny. Zdaję sobie sprawę z tego, że narzuca go sama konwencja gry, ale jednak wolałabym, żeby byli ubrani w normalne ciuchy.
Osobnym tematem są tła - proste, mało skomplikowane, utrzymane jedynie w paru odcieniach. Podejrzewam, że miało to służyć przede wszystkim konsolowcom grającym w o wiele mniejszej rozdzielczości.

Czy grę polecam? Generalnie tak, bo jeśli przymkniemy oko na dosyć ekscentryczne zachowania bohaterów, to otrzymamy naprawdę dobrą i wciągającą opowieść o poszukiwaniu własnej tożsamości. Jeżeli jednak wolicie lekkie komedie, to raczej będziecie zawiedzeni. Idea Factory często organizuje promocje na "Amnesię...", więc jeśli nie jesteście pewni, a nie chcecie wydawać ponad 100 zł, możecie zaczekać na odpowiedni moment i zakupić grę po obniżonej cenie.

22766191.review:
10/10 – worth every death to get to the end.

Amnesia: Memories is a visual novel that combines beautiful art with some of the best storytelling I've seen in a game in a long time. Do not confuse it with a Horror game of nearly the same name, because rather than leave you fearful, this title has the potential to leave you with a tremendous sense of awe, and almost sadness; not that the story is sad, but that it is over and you will never again experience it as you did that first time.

I 100%’d this game, something I almost never do, simply because I HAD to see all the endings, and the thought of being done with this game was more than I could handle. It is voiced (a big plus vs. other otomes) and keeps the story moving without burdening you with excessive side jobs to grind likeability stats.

I'll attempt to keep this as spoiler free as possible, but if you don't want to risk it, I will say this: get this game. This is the first game I have purchased where I wish I had spent MORE on it. I got this game on sale for $7, and I've seen it go under $5. It is worth full price. If you see it on sale, do not hesitate, grab it. This is a beautiful, smart and joyful game any visual novel fan should experience. Use one of the guides, I recommend Pie-inator’s, to help you get to each of the endings and enjoy. 

Possible Spoilers Below

Amensia: Memories is about a girl who loses her memory when as stray spirit collides with her head. Whoops. Now, instead of any sense of self, she has a friendly little guide by the name of Orion to help her get through life and figure out who she is, and who she can trust. After a brief introduction to Orion, you’ll pick your world, meaning, pick your guy.

The first choice is Shin. Shin’s path is a good mystery. He’s a pretty typical tsundere, and your childhood friend. His best quality is that he understands the MC and will do absolutely anything to help and protect her. This path’s main function is to introduce you to the cast of characters that will play important roles as you continue your journey to understand the truth about this world you have stepped into.

Next up is Toma. If you didn’t think there is a little something wrong, and dark, about your situation while playing Shin’s path, you will understand it now. Toma’s path is not overly unique for otome’s and visual novels, but it’s pretty twisted. Orion’s interaction with your character takes it to the next level, especially if you’re going for the happy ending. It’s pretty great making bizarre choices in a game and having someone actually call you out on it.  

Next up is Ikki, a playboy type who you think you have all figured out the moment you meet him. But this is the path where you begin to realize this world has some really strange things going on, far beyond the normal. Ikki’s path is very sweet and really turns all of your assumptions about the character around. By the end, you’ll probably have a little crush on Ikki, and that’s ok.

The forth path is Kent, a character who has mostly sat in the background in the previous paths. He is quiet and intelligent, and a bit harsh. As you begin this path, both you, Orion, and the MC wonder how it is that you are actually dating this guy. Your relationship is pretty rocky, to say the least. But the further you go down this path, the more and more Kent’s true character comes out. This is probably the most romantic path, and ends in such a sweet way that you may find yourself falling for this adorable nerd. 

Along the way, as mentioned, you’ll also be interacting with Orion. His presence up until this point is pretty much a mystery, though if you’ve been paying attention you’ve started to get some clues as to what’s going on. His company really elevates the entire experience so far through his adorable reactions and unwavering support of the MC.

If you’ve gone this far, you have also met the strangest character in the cast, Ukyo, and buckle up, because now that you’ve completed the other four guys’ paths, Ukyo’s is now available to you. This is where the story goes from strong to unreal. Ukyo’s path is the story of the world, the overarching plot that ties all other paths together and explains exactly what happened to the MC. It is heartbreaking and beautiful and very well may have you in tears by the end. Not to mention Ukyo’s path has a grand total of NINE different endings. 

Walking the path with Ukyo is dangerous and confusing, but leads to one of the biggest payoffs I have ever experienced in a game. It takes some time to get to this path, but to not experience this path is to not experience the game.
Overall this game is breathtaking, with beautiful art, fantastic music and an out of this world story. It is a SMART story, and doesn’t talk down to the player, but rather challenges you to accept unbelievable circumstances as truths. It is not your typical otome. There is a depth to this world that you would expect out of a big triple-A RPG, not a casual visual novel. It is a must have for any visual novel fan.

虽说是一碗Otomate的冷炒饭，但对于没有掌机而一直久闻Amnesia大名的玩家们而言的确算一个惊喜。游戏各个方面属中上乘水准，氛围的拿捏和节奏的掌控比较到位，普通路线铺垫充足、隐藏路线衔接顺畅。虽然世界观存在bug，剧情可能也略显狗血，不过还是很开心看到了乙女向vr在悬疑这一方面的努力和诚意。抛开这些不说，实际上Amnesia最直接吸引玩家的还是綺☆麗的作画吧？何况还是高分辨率的pc移植版，随便一个截图就可设为桌面壁纸。人设也很讨喜[strike]，完美迎合了不同需求癖好的人群[/strike]，在推线路时的确让人觉得赏心悦目。

可能是为了增强代入感，本作没有任何旁白，女主角在游戏前95%的部分一句台词也没有，各个角色的语音台词串联起了全部。有时我产生了自己是在玩一个可视化交互式drama的错觉...虽然声优阵容相当豪华，但这可能会显得有些咄咄逼人，也可能会增加长时间游戏体验的疲劳感。

但总的来说，Amnesia仍然是一部十分值得尝试的作品，尤其对于steam平台而言，各种同类型作品鱼龙混杂（而且还是投机货居多），如果你对otome向的vr感兴趣的话，我推荐你可以优先体验Amnesia。

22096663.review:
In a world lacking good visual novels (especially otomes) Amnesia's gorgeous art, well written routes and length of play make it stand out. The Japanese voice acting is stellar and there is a considerable amount of humour in the game as well. There are lots of other reviews that do an excellent job of pointing out the highlights of this game, so I would just like to address any concerns on the negative ones.

[h1]Toma's path[/h1]
As someone who has played many Japanese visual novels, read manga and watched anime, I can unfortunately attest to the fact that Japanese r.ape culture is surprisingly (or not?) bad. Part of the reason why I have trouble playing Japanese made visual novels is because of the rape culture (*cough*The Second Reproduction*cough). Off the top of my head, I can think of a few in the game that I've seen many other times in Japanese VNs/anime/manga: "Only I can see you in a swimsuit", "If you let me into your room alone, it's your fault if I do something to you", "All men care only about sex", "I can't trust you alone with another man", or literally anything that Toma says. Now, the sad truth is that this is not something that is necessarily problematic with the visual novel—it's simple ignorance apparent in many Japanese visual novels. I would recommend trying to look past this in order to enjoy the visual novel. I think Toma's path is very well-written, but as a woman (or as anyone, really) it's terrifying. What's even more terrifying is that some people who played that path actually enjoyed it! The path is disgusting in the sense that it's a tragic reality (perhaps not as extreme as what Toma did) that many people in abusive relationships face, and the fact that the game romanticizes it is awful.

However! Toma's path does not ruin the rest of the paths for me. In fact, it makes Shin's all the more satisfying. I still think it's worth playing because it provides lots of background information and is has the ability to make me keep reading, like how those nasty zit-popping videos I can't tear my eyes from. (Also, you need to play Toma's path in order to get the final path, soooo…)

[h1]Protagonist's Passivity[/h1]
I understand how this might frustrate some people who either i) don't play many visual novels or ii) are used to badass protagonists with a zinger around every corner. Admittedly, I enjoy badass protagonists, but the protagonist we're given is recovering from amnesia and is in a very vulnerable position. Hers is the personality to stay calm in extraordinary circumstances—that doesn't make her boring. I found it interesting to see her 'original' personality form, as well as new bits from her interacting with the world differently. The guys comment on it as well, and at the end of the game it's almost startling when the protagonist speaks for herself (to represent the memories coming back) in a way that removes choice from the player. It's only at the end that we (the protagonist, Orion, and us the player) see the protagonist's true personality. 

Overall, I would give this game a big thumbs up. The rape-culture is very cringe-worthy, and if you have had experiences with abusive relationships and/or sexual assault, I would steer clear of Toma's route. I did buy the game on sale (90% off!) and I'm not sure if I would buy it for $33—but then, when have I ever spent that much money on a game? My route preference was: Shin, Ikki, Kent, Ukyo… Waka, Orion, Sawa, Mine, Rika… uh, the heroine? The apartment, maybe. Oh, and Toma.

First time I played this I got a bad ending for Ikki, I thought he was a player and didn't trust him very much. He seemed two faced and a bit obnoxious. I told him I hated him and he took his fanclub out to karaoke, leaving me in the yukata and missing the fireworks show. What a prat. If someone had done that in real life, no matter how popular they were, I really would've told them to piss off. [spoiler]It ended with him bemoaning how lonely he was and implied that he was off to drown himself in the sea.[/spoiler]

Second time it went a little better. With Shin I appreciated his honesty and trusted him to the best of my ability, earning a normal ending. Sometimes I questioned his actions, but I knew in my heart that I could trust him. [spoiler]I thought I had done enough, but ultimately I couldn't unlock the true ending and didn't managed to confront Towa.[/spoiler] I was still happy with Shin, though. He was a good guy who said it like it was, even if it was sometimes a little harsh he had the best intentions. He reminded me of my partner in real life, having a less than ideal childhood and a few close friends. Very likeable once you get to know him.

Third time I romanced Kent. It was really difficult at first, as that over logical personality kept grating on me, but as the character himself admitted, he was used to being "disliked for this reason". I felt stupid around him, which is not an attractive qulaity. However, I persevered, and I grew to appreciate that he really was doing nothing more than trying his best. [spoiler]I eventually unlocked the memories he was so scared of me finding out and in the end, it didn't change my feelings for him one bit.[/spoiler] Being intelligent and logical isn't a bad thing, and in the end he found his emotions were more important. 21666364.review:
Estamos ante una novela que nos dará muchas horas de lectura con historias y personajes muy distintos entre sí, que estos últimos variaran entre ruta y ruta (principalmente los secundarios).

Si bien hay rutas mejores que otras (me quedo con la de Shin/Heart World y Kent/Clover World) son en términos generales bastante notables, ademas de que es un juego MUY rejugable porque tiene muchos finales (especialmente la ruta del Joker) por lo que tienes horas de lectura garantizadas si quieres ver todas las posibles variables.

Cabe decir que aunque no tenga un alto repertorio de personajes no le hace falta a la novela visual ya que en cada mundo o ruta, su personalidad varia como he mencionado antes y si bien en una ruta puede ser tu mejor amigo/a, en otra puede hasta matarte (dependiendo todo esto de las decisiones que vayas tomando claro, conseguiras un final u otro).

El diseño de personajes es sobresaliente desde principales a secundarios, una pena que el vestuario no varie demasiado.

Música con temas muy notables, muy acordes a las situaciones que se nos presentan.

Viene con las voces originales japonesas, asi que doblaje perfecto.

Como contra decir que hay algunos errores de traducción y el hecho de estar en inglés tirará para atrás aunque no tiene un nivel muy alto asi que es accesible con saber un poco.

Tambien cabe decir que sin guia es complicado sacarse todos los finales aunque por suerte en steam podemos encontrar guias de todas las rutas.


En resumidas cuentas, si te gusta las novelas visuales y concretamente los Otome, esta compra es OBLIGATORIA aunque recomiendo pagar como mucho alrededor de 10€, no más.

Aquí os dejo una reseña más extensa y detallada realizada por mí: http://legiondejugadores.com/todos-los-analisis/analisis-amnesia-memories/
