21506388.review:
Ох, давно я ждала случая поиграть наконец в визуальные новеллы, по которым было снято аниме, и Amnesia: Memories была одной из приоритетных в списке. Моей радости не было предела, когда я увидела именно это отомэ в стиме, и, надо сказать, теперь, когда я закончила прохождение, моей радости ни капли не убавилось.
Несмотря на то, что всё отомэ построено целиком на диалогах ("авторского текста" здесь нет), текста действительно очень много. Но это и хорошо, потому что кроме красивой картинки в визуальной новелле должно быть интересное наполнение, и Амнезия может похвастаться и тем, и другим.
Картинки просто офигительные! Спрайты детализированные, они моргают, у них меняется выражения лица, и они "разговаривают" (пусть и невпопад, но всё равно смотреть приятно), все CGI-иллюстрации как на подбор хороши, от них просто глаз не оторвать.
Сюжет тоже не подкачал. Конечно, с поправкой на то, что это отомэ, сделанное в Японии, соответственно, для обычного европейского человека реакция "Япония, какого хрена?!" может присутствовать сполна XD Так что если условная "японская логика" вас отталкивает, то сюжет этой ВН вам вряд ли понравится.
Точнее даже 5 сюжетов, один из которых, на мой взгляд, является истинным, даёт ответы на вопросы, которые остаются после первых четырёх рутов, не зря же он скрыт))
Собственно, коротко по сюжету, чтобы не вдаваться в спойлеры - мы имеем изначально выбор из 4 миров, в каждом из которых базовая концепция остаётся похожей, но отличаются детали и то, кто является парнем нашей героини, потерявшей воспоминания. В мире Сердец это цундере Шин (на самом деле очень-очень милый парень, и его детективный рут весьма хорош), в мире Пик - плейбой Икки (неадекватный фан-клуб и страдашки прилагаются), в мире Треф - рациональный Кент (саааамый милый парень из основной четвёрки, и самый slice of life рут, на котором душа отдыхает), в мире Бубен - "старший брат" Тома (вот уж где творится черт знает что... яндере типажи, они такие).
После прохождения всех этих миров на хорошие концовки, откроется возможность попасть в мир Джокера, где... а вот не буду спойлерить, но рут, безусловно, самый волнительный и однозначно "истинный".
Помимо этого есть две мини-игры, доступные из меню, забавные, но не более того)
На полное прохождение (открытие всех концовок) уходит, конечно, очень много времени, даже если идти по прохождению, а не тыкаться наугад. Но, тем не менее, именно полное прохождение позволяет лучше понять героев и проникнуться всем сюжетом. А он здесь всё-таки есть, именно как глобальный сюжет, распространяющийся на все параллельные миры... но довольно спойлеров.
В общем, отличное отомэ, любителям жанра должно понравиться, да и для тех, кто с жанром не знаком, может стать неплохим, пусть и слегка запутанным, началом.
P.S. больше известных отомэ в стиме богу отомэ XD

21405376.review:
Amnesia: Memories is a bit different, than it's namesake from Frictional Games. Good for me, because I'm a loser when it comes to horror games. Travelling in a world filled with beautiful, thoughtful yet stubborn men was an experience I was happy to have. 

The thing is, almost all of the men seem to be too unrealistic for my taste. There're many personality disorders, anime stereotypes: you have your tsunderes, overly self-confident guys and everything you can imagine. Considering that this is a "date simulator" - it's completely understandable, that the game developers have wanted to make the guys appeal more desireable and mysterious. The game itself can carry on the story pretty well, but when it comes to your playable character - everything seems to fall apart. 

Our protagonist, you, doesn't really have any type of thoughts - besides this mysterious Orion-bugboy, who says everything you supposedly think out loud to you. You won't have any monologue by yourself throughout the whole story - Orion will be the one to take care of that. To be honest that was a bit of a disappointment for me. 

Otherwise, the game is fun and you get emerged into the story pretty quickly. 

PROS of this game are... 
+ The graphics are beautiful and I really like the voice actors in this one 
+ You've got a variety of supporting characters with pretty interesting personalities. So you don't always have to talk to the guys. 
+ Every milieu is kind of connected and you get to see the different roles of the people on different storylines. This makes everything more interesting and surprising. 
+ The game shows which options you have already chosen, in case you decide to play one "world" again. 
+ You also get fun mini games and screenshots, linked to your actual gameplay. 

CONS of this game are... 
- The characters aren't really that original and some of them aren't even good looking. (To me, at least) 
- The achievements are easy, but it's very difficult to know how to get the good endings. I've only managed to get two bad and "average" ending. 
- Some of the parts are the same (obviously) and it kind of boring. 
- The storylines aren't that long, so if you're a fast reader - you'll get through of them quickly. 
+/- You don't get to choose your gender.

My overall experience was fine. I liked the game, it's fun and it's a great way to kill time. I actually had a little crush on one of the main characters, so I think it worked out for me quite well. It's worth the money, so don't be afraid to get it.

21297698.review:
POUR
-Des routes super différentes et qui complètent bien notre compréhension des personnages. En faisant la route du Perso B vous apprendrez des choses sur Perso A qui ne seront jamais dite dans la route du Perso A.
-Grande variété de scénarios : mignon, triste, suspense,...
-Des personnages sympathiques et loin d'être parfait, j'adore tout particulièrement la meilleure amie.
-Les musiques sont sympa. Elle aident bien à l'ambiance sans pour autant être essentielle (sauf sur une route mais *spoiler*).
-La dynamique du jeu est plutôt bonne. Bien qu'on recommence toujours la même chose (on refait le mois d'août selon différente routes) on ne s'ennuie pas.
-Assez difficile de savoir quoi faire pour être aimée/détestée la premirèe fois. A chaque fois j'obtenais le résultat inverse ! Donc c'était amusant.
-Un très bon équilibre dans les histoires malgré le fait que les personnages soient les mêmes. Le changement de scénario entretient la curiosité. 
-Un peu d'humour. J'ai rigolé deux trois fois à causes de réactions totalement inconvenue ou de répliques amusante.
-Plein de fins alternatives.
-Plein de "mauvaises" fins or c'est ça le meilleur. Ne niez pas !
-Une bonne mécanique : on peut passer rapidement tous les dialogues où seulement ceux qu'on a lu, j'aime ce choix !
-Deux mini jeux.
-Des extras en masse (illustrations, spin off, souvenirs...)
-Des extras dans les extras (j'ai mis du temps à comprendre qu'il y avait des dialogues cachés différent sur une même image...la honte)
-La route bonus, aussi connue sous le nom de "si tu meurs pas, chapeau bas !". J'ai adoré.
-Un design vraiment agréable, très beau dessins, tout bien conjugué sur ce niveau là.

NEUTRE
-Voix Japonaises, sous titre anglais. Moi j'aime, d'autre peuvent être rebuté. A prendre en compte avant l'achat.
-Pourquoi il n'y a pas de route Manager ? J'aime le Manager ! ♥ Mais ile me fait peur également...

CONTRE
-Pas de route Héroïne/Meilleure amie. Dommage.
-Oui, ça manque cruellement de romance autre que hétérosexuelle. D'autre Otome moins développés arrivent à en intégrer alors...
-Certains aspect très cliché Shojo Manga mais ça passe..
-L'histoire numéro 4 n'est vraiment pas, mais vraiment pas quelque chose à promouvir. Non mais vraiment ! Autant c'est mon personnage préféré, autant on ne peut pas envoyer le message "ouah, il m'a fait subir tout ça mais je l'aime".
-Très paternaliste. J'aurai aimé un scénario avec une héroïne plus rentre dedans, qui prend les choses en main.
-Trop prude. Des sous entendus mais je n'aurai pas dit non à plus. (Sauf dans une scène grave mais ça c'était bien, ça rajoutait de la peur.)
-Un petit bug graphique : il arrive que la lèvre inférieur des personnages ne bougent pas quand ils sont de profils. Ou que leur tête vibre. Léger défaut qui casse l'ambiance dans les moments sombre.
-Le jeu est très légèrement lent lorsqu'on passe d'un menu à l'autre... Mais ça peut provenir de mon ordinateur. Ce n'est pas gênant, juste pas parfait.
-L'un des mini jeux n'est pas très souple. Or y gagner apporte un bonus mais vu que c'est raide c'est difficile.

Je l'ai acheté en solde. Je pense que son prix d'achat de départ n'est pas une arnaque mais en dessous c'est forcément mieux.
Je me suis bien amusée dessus, j'y ai bien joué et parfois je recommence une route pour voir quelle différence il y a dans les dialogues.

21212108.review:
Amnesia is one of those games that I heard about years ago and became desperate to play because of the art quality. It was a very highly received title in Japan as well.

Based on other otome I've played, I think this is... sort of junk food. Lots of people like it, but that doesn't make it good. Even from a graphic novel standpoint, it's not especially well put together. That said, if you like the premise and you like the fetishes the routes offer, of course you'll overlook these flaws. I'm the same way with other games.

My first issue was that you have to choose a route at the start of the game. There's no 'let's get to know the characters' thing before you choose a route, which is why I preferred when this sort of mechanic was used in Nameless. 

As others said, you have a passive heroine. Normally, this would be ok, since most otome heroines are self-insert anyway, but she is notable among the genre for her debilitating lack of agency. Based on dialogue which hints at your pre-amnesiac self, it seems that you were a bit of a selfish, needy and demanding person before. The guys generally express a sort of relief with this new, placid 'you'. So, basically, the guys like you because you're pretty, regardless of how you act. There's not even the pretense of personality here and for me, that their standards are so shallow makes me like the bachelors way less. I can't even say it's misogynistic either, since your heroine also doesn't have much reason to like these characters besides their looks.  

You get a good ending if you're agreeable, a bad ending if you're not. You start the routes essentially already in a relationship, so for me, that already negates one of the most engaging aspects of these sorts of games.

Both the characters and the storyline are borderline satire. The smart guy's shtick is that he's like a computer; the 'big bro' shtick is that he's crazy obsessed with you, but seems normal; the crazy guy is laughing maniacally one second and remorseful and moe the next; the story keeps making excuses as to why you can't just do the reasonable thing for the sake of pursuing romantic interests. One step more and this game would have gone into Hatoful Boyfriend territory with the ludicrous nature of it all.

In total, the game caters to the fetish of 'helplessness', which has seen growing popularity in both Japan and North America. Basically, you have determined love interests (no need to search), in pre-selected routes (no risk of not getting guy), where you have no memory (not accountable for past errors or responsibilities) which is caused by a supernatural force (no concerns over actual medical problems), who takes responsibility over not just your memory, but your relationship status (no need for hard decisions) and your boyfriend(s) routinely put in you in a position where 'they will take care of everything' and restrict your agency. There's segments in all the routes which basically have your heroine wait in her room for days at a time, with occasional visits from one of the bachelors. 

For me, there are other English otome that did most of the elements presented in Amnesia much better. It's a shallow game that caters to the right niches. I don't condemn it for that - I just wish it had catered to mine!

20840282.review:
[b]An otome VN with a rather hefty amount of endings and choices you can make with four boys's routes you can choose and start up right from the beginning (a 5th route will be unlocked if you get all the good endings for the first four boys).[/b]

It's a decent enough PC port when going through the VN just so long as you actually look up and learn the controls although the window resolution for me doesn't like staying as it was whenever I closed the process last.

The artwork is pretty excellent especially for an otome. The background colors are often kept to a bare minimum but that's not really much of an issue if at all since I think they give enough detail of the current setting and the main focus is on the characters.

I took a pretty heavy interest with how the stories go in this. Each route starts out practically the same way; the protagonist wakes up as an amnesia victim at the start of August and  her only companions for this is a spirit who can't leave the protagonist's mind until she regains her memory. The spirit helps her try to regain her memories bit by bit whilst trying to keep her amnesia a secret to everyone for special reasons. The more she regains her memories the more separated the protagonist and the spirit become until she can no longer see him. Each route you choose from in the beginning is basically like an alternate reality you pick where, down to the core, practically all the characters are the same in personality but the circumstances differ greatly, like maybe one character has a job in one route or maybe they're unemployed in another.

With typos kept to a rarity I thought it was a great otome where you get to know each character a lot more the more routes and endings you strive for.

20798793.review:
[b]If you have come here for horror...[/b]

Prepare yourself, because you're on this week's episode of 1000 Ways to Die!

[i]Amnesia: Memories[/i] is an otome game, meaning it's your goal as the protagonist to make it through the story alive and fall in love with your perfect anime husbando. Amnesia: Memories doesn't want you to make it through the story alive, so you have to work your butt off to not die while on the prowl for your big strong man.

[b]Review[/b]

Sound: 10/10 -- Game is fully voice acted in Japanese with a beautiful backing soundtrack. I don't mind that it's repetitive in nature, it's a studio-quality soundtrack. Atmospheric and easy on the ears.

Art: 8/10 -- I personally enjoy the blurry, hand-drawn look of the backgrounds for each scene, but I know not everybody would agree. Also the outfits on the boys take me to the lawlacaust.

Story: 7.5/10 -- Overall the plotlines in each route are at least tolerable, though the protagonist can be [b]incredibly[/b] frustrating and downright stupid. Holes in different places. Not Swiss Cheese holey, but still holey. 

Boys: 7/10 -- For what we get to see of them, the boys whose emotions we get to know the most intimately are Shin's and Ikki's; both of these boys have powerful feelings that come through without them always having to say it. Toma and Ukyo both felt out-of-touch for me, because their characters were a bit outlandish. Toma felt far more troubled than he let on and Ukyo had lost his fucking marbles. I'd have liked to learn more about them. The most "alive" of the boys, for me, was Kent. Kent reminded me of a very close friend I used to have and I'll say his characterization for prickly-intellect was spot-on. 

Characters: 10/10 -- THE CUSTOMER IS THE ENEMY!!!! For real though, I enjoyed the supporting characters and how you saw them treat the protagonist in each route. It always changed depending on the love interest and I think it made them more human.

Overall: 10/10, Senpais noticed me

[b]Routes[/b]

[i]Hearts:[/i] Shin is the dream bad-boy of a girl that never grew out of her "edgy" phase. He's an insensitive ass-hat at his worst and a loving protector at his best. The plot of his route is overwhelmingly melodramatic with a super-secret-agent-spy-detective-mission. By the time you get to the conclusion of the mission your heart is achy and confused. Your [spoiler]animu best friend tried to kill you[/spoiler]. This is the childhood romance stuff that's so cute I could puke. Shin is a great character and feels like the "canon" route [spoiler]aside from Ukyo[/spoiler].

[i]Diamonds:[/i] Toma is attractive, intelligent, and protective of the protagonist [spoiler]even if it means locking her in a cage[/spoiler]. His route follows [spoiler]preventing the protag's imminent death and harassment from Ikki's fan club.[/spoiler] Toma would do anything for the protag because that's what he feels his responsibility is as an older brother and oh my god this whole route made me want to strangle the protagonist because there needs to be a "tell Toma how you feel" option WAY early on. All the BS could've been avoided.

[i]Clubs:[/i] Kent is a hyper-critical young man with a hard gaze and soft heart. His social awkwardness will melt the ice on your heart. His logical processes behind every action he takes will make your eyebrows raise up. Kent's route [spoiler]is about learning to live life before he leaves to study abroad.[/spoiler] He is [spoiler]the only male that communicates with Orion throughout the game.[/spoiler] His character really pulls on the heartstrings with his long thoughtful walks and desire to spend time with the protag. He feels like a real person.

[i]Spades:[/i] Ikki is a gorgeous playboy with a fanclub full of stalkers. You're the only girl that his [url=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Diarmuid_Ua_Duibhne#Magical_love_spot]magical, hypnotic eyes[/url] never fully worked on. To win this beautiful boy's heart you have to [spoiler]not fall victim to the fan club's attempts to kill you, take advantage of his gentle heart, or lie to him about your behavior being different after your accident.[/spoiler] Ikki is a wonderful, loving young man that hasn't had the chance to fall in true love because of his [url=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Diarmuid_Ua_Duibhne#Magical_love_spot][b]cursed magical hypnotic eyes[/b][/url]. Let him love you. Please. He's so great.

[i]Joker:[/i] Everything is out to kill you. [spoiler]Even Ukyo.[/spoiler] It's do-or-die in the final route of the game, and your memories of your [spoiler]original world true love[/spoiler] are hazy. Who is this strange guy with green hair predicting the future? Why is he trying so desperately to keep you safe? Why does he get so emotional over something as simple as you wanting to see him? And why, for the love of god, does he pull an Edward Cullen every five minutes? "I love you. but you can't be near me. I'll hurt you. Don't hate me. Forgive me. Still love you."

[i]Good news! You're going to find out![/i]

[i]Bad news! You're probably going to die a dozen times to get there![/i]

[b]Conclusion[/b]

All-in-all this is a super enjoyable visual novel. I got it during the Steam holiday sale but would happily pay full price to have the same experience again. This is exceptionally polished work, although I'm always going to wish I had more backstory on the boys. Recommended for visual novel fans that like a quirky story and weird characters. The only Mary Sue in this otome is you.

20753220.review:
It's not often that you'll hear me, of all people, make a statement like this, but I genuinely feel bad that I got this game at such a high discount. I bought Amnesia when it was 90% off for the winter sale, and it's certainly one of the best visual novels I've ever played. 

For one thing, this game is just incredibly well-made. Now, a good 90% of the visual novels I've played have been freeware ones I've found online across various forums. None of them have had particularly high production values or anything like that; at most they've feature a couple of CGs and a bonus scene or some questions answered by the creator about their game, but besides that they're pretty basic. To get a game with so many CGs, which are remarkably well-drawn and colored; voice acting; an awesome soundtrack (I may or may not have gotten about 60-65% of my playing hours for this game by just leaving it open while I did other stuff on my computer in different windows, just because I really liked the music); mini-games (albeit ones with rather poor controls in several cases, though that may be due to my mouse being particularly terrible);  and over 20 different endings is a completely new experience for me. It's been somewhat hard for me to go back to playing games without most of these nice features, or at least where these features aren't as well done as they are in Amnesia. I feel like I stole something by getting a game this nice for only three dollars.

But speaking of all of those endings I mentioned, let me discuss the actual routes and characters, since they make up a bulk of the game's experience. The routes are set in different alternate 'worlds', each of which is named after suits on playing cards. Please note that you should probably play the routes in the order they're listed as choices; I made the mistake of playing Toma's route first, since he was the only character I was curious about going in, and I can't help but feel like I would've enjoyed the game that much more if I had just chosen his route last. (In Shin's route, at least, things become a *lot* more predictable once you know the sort of stunts Toma's capable of pulling.) Each route has a good end, a normal end, and several bad ends. Note: there's 5 routes to play, not 4, but the fifth is only unlockable after you've done the others.

Now onto the characters themselves. For the most part, I thought all the romanceable guys were pretty likeable and well-portrayed. Not all of them strike me as 'boyfriend' material, but nonetheless, every one of them was quite interesting in his own right. While the guys are essentially stock otome love interests- we have a blunt tsundere with a heart of gold, a chivalrous playboy whose only *sincere* romantic interest is in you (the heroine), a logical and seemingly cold (but entirely adorkable) nerd, and a yandere willing to do anything to protect you- they're all either played to perfection or with an interesting twist on the usual 'type'. 

My personal favorite character is Ikki, which says a lot, since I typically dislike the 'playboy' type (if I don't ignore them as an option altogether). But Ikki was sweet and had quite a bit more depth to his character than I was expecting, and several times I really wanted to hug him because I felt so badly for him. That said, I don't think I actually disliked any of the love interests, at least not in retrospect. Some of them made me very frustrated, and some of the routes were outright morally compromising (I'm looking at you, Toma), but they were really enjoyable overall. Hell, Toma's route was the first one I wanted to replay- I don't like him as a love interest, particularly, but he was damn entertaining.

And while I haven't said anything about Ukyo, he was a different sort of character than I've dealt with in any otome game before. I'm still not quite sure what to make of his route. I will once again offer a bit of advice and say this: DO NOT LOOK UP ANYTHING RELATED TO UKYO UNTIL YOU'VE PLAYED THROUGH HIS ROUTE AT LEAST ONCE. Once again, I made the mistake of spoiling the twist with him before I even unlocked his route, which took away a lot of his charm for me. Instead, playing through his route was something of a drag because I didn't have to piece together any of his cryptic statements or anything.

This whole review has turned into one long TL;DR, so I'll say this in conclusion: Amnesia was a thoroughly enjoyable game. Even the characters who I didn't particularly like as love interests were quite entertaining regardless, and this is certainly the most professional, well-presented otome game- or visual novel in general- that I've ever played. I probably would've liked it even more had I not spoiled some major aspects of the story for myself, but even given that, Amnesia totally won me over. I'd love to see more on Steam from Idea Factory in the future.

20667513.review:
I mainly got this game because I've been researching several different kinds of visual novels and point and click games.

The graphics and music were amazing. The characters are very well made and it's nice to see such details put into a game. 

I really am inspired to write better because Amnesia has very good storytelling and keeps you guessing. I would say if this was a mystery game instead of a romantic game, I would give the game a 10/10 because I couldn't figure how where things were going to go half the time. Visuals and sound 10. But if I added the love aspect of the game in it would be 6/10 altogether. I appreciated that each route was pretty different from one another and mysterious.

I was drawn in by the mystery in Shin's route. Trying to figure out if Ikku was a playboy or not actually was enjoyable when I usually hate characters like him and ended up liking his character anyways, surprise, surprise. Toma's route was terrible for me, I was bored but I completed it anyway. I didn't want to start Ukyo's route at all because I hated him (since he kills you so many times in other character routes) but I ended up loving his storyline the most because it connects the whole storylines together in a way. Kent is still my favorite character route to play I suppose because he is the most realistic out of all the guys in the storyline. I have to give many stars to the creators or writer of Amnesia because it is a well written, imaginative story.

For romantic storylines?
As for the belive-ability of the love stories, I would rate it a 4/10. There were times that I got really bored with the direction of love the story was supposed to be taking. I don't know why I am picky about that. I believe part of it was because the main character herself didn't have much of an interest to me, but then again it's not her fault since she has amnesia. But even when she did recover her memories I didn't like her in most of the routes. The love stories were unique though I have to say. The only ones where she was endearing to me as a character were Kent and Ukyo's routes. Surprise, surprise! Good thing Orion is there to help move love plots along, or else I think I would have hated the love stories in other routes even more!

I recommend this game if you are into most love otome games. If you are not, the next good appeal about it is the mystery and figuring out what's going to happen which was the major score for me. I recommend buying it at a lower price, but I guess the quality of this game is worth the full price for some people.

20555142.review:
Steam sorely needed another otome game made by a studio that's been in this business for years.  Since Steam's change in discount policy, Amnesia has been on sale for $3 after 90% discount.  That alone should be enough to invest at least 3 hours of your time in a guy you're interested in.  [i]Side note, you can't just call off the relationship with a guy in the world you pick, because this type of game is built with the assumption that you intend to pursue these guys.[/i]  It's $3 worth of silly writing, romance, and good-looking guys.  Now... Reasons why $3 is worth your time...

[h1]Likes[/h1]

1.  Character and CG art are done well.  The artist does a good enough job with mixing up different viewing angles of the scene, but the placement of hair or other parts of the characters makes the viewing angles of their faces look weird (i.e. their noses seem to disappear).  Similarly to CG viewing angles, it was a nice touch to have character sprites facing the player in order to convey a sense of direction.  Likewise, these additions add to some imagination that two characters are directly looking at each other.  There's also lip movement when characters talk so the player isn't staring at stiff mouths all the time.

2.  Plots for 4/5 guys are done well in the sense that it's not romance-focused, but more mystery-focused as the player pieces together what happened before the heroine lost her memories.  At the same time, the player has to take care to not max out the suspicion parameter lest that triggers bad endings or characters may take advantage of that.

3.  Each guy has a distinct archetype so the player can freely pick any to start.  Overall, Shin and Toma are the childhood friends (i.e. romantically aggressive and romantically a doormat, in that order); Ikki, Kent, and Ukyo (<- unlocked after playing the other 4) are the older guys roughly ages 21-26 (i.e. not-typical-playboy; stoic, logical guy; and aloof romanticist).  [b]Word of advice[/b]: Don't pick Toma's route (Diamond world) if you're not familiar with an archetype made popular with Mirai Nikki.

[h1]Dislikes[/h1]

1.  [b]Whoever wrote Orion's lines needs to be suspended for a while[/b].  A lot of people hate hearing Orion, and I agree in that Orion was the weakest link.  Although I appreciated Orion's hinting of how to respond to specific situations, his role as the heroine's voice and partner-in-crime was horrible.  The game's rated T for Teens, but Orion's regurgitation of really obvious information and constant attempts to get you to doubt everything were patronizing at best, and very insulting at worst to the average 13-19 yr old's reading and problem-solving skills (or am I giving teens too much credit?).  Furthermore, taking his advice seriously in Ikki's route(Spade) can get you the bad ending quickly.  Likewise, Orion forgot to remind the heroine to read her diary in Toma's route (Diamond) which would've saved a lot of headache.

2.  Beyond Orion, writing is [b]very spotty[/b] in Toma's route and a bit in Ikki's route.  Logic was missing and anyone who understood dramatic irony can piece together the mysteries quickly, which makes Orion's remarks even more irritating.  Overall, the heroine is written so then she only has more lines [i]after she regains her memories[/i].  Before she gets all of her memories back, she is practically silent except when picking dialogue choices.  I'm sure people don't stay silent all the time just because some memories are missing, especially if it's a survival issue of not letting others know they have amnesia.  Something to keep in mind is that the almost-silent heroine exists [u]because it's a common storytelling device to allow the players to project themselves onto her[/u] (e.g. Persona 3 and 4's silent protagonists... except they had personalities too...).  While I wouldn't mind it in an otome game, this storytelling device was done poorly and if you want a voiced otome heroine, look to [i]Hakuoki: Demon of the Fleeting Blossom, Code: Realize, or Norn9: Var Commons[/i].  The wording of the dialogue choices can be frustrating sometimes, because there are the obvious ones and the less obvious ones that boost the trust and affection parameters.

3.  A minor dislike in the backgrounds.  Although stylistic and doesn't clash with character art, the resolution was noticeably awful when zoomed in for the purpose of perspective.  Not only was the resolution bad, but the backgrounds don't look like they were manually drawn and look like filtered photos.

4.  Getting the air hockey achievement wouldn't be so bad if the devs just optimized the friggin' game.  The lag is intense and there has already been a major thread providing self-taught solutions to minimizing the lag so the mini-game can be tolerable.

[h1]Final Say[/h1]

For $3, you can't go wrong with purchasing this game if you're into the otome visual novel genre.  Just think of it as a discounted game that can provide you with a light story and some laughs along the way.  Be aware that this game was released a couple of years ago by the Japanese company, Otomate.  Why emphasize the "Japanese" part?  Because there are plenty of non-Japanese gamers who were instantly turned off by a silent heroine and some of the things the guys say (e.g. "Watch your surroundings full of guys oogling your bikini", "Don't you know it's dangerous to invite a guy to your room when living alone?", "I don't know if I can control my urges" etc) because part of the writing is influenced by Japanese storytelling targeted at Japanese women.

20459456.review:
Visual Novels have always been a guilty pleasure of mine, taken in a large concentrated dose and then forgotten for months on end before the itch ever resurfaces. Usually I'm pretty satisfied when I drop the VNs that I've been working on regardless of completion status, but it's a first this time that not only have I completed Amnesia within 20-25 hours across the span of two short days but that I still want [i]more[/i]. 

Five paths. All unique. All satisfying. I loved how the characters tied back into each other across parallel worlds, picking each subsequent playthrough based on the character that intrigued me the most in the previous. Perhaps it was just a mark of how well things were done that I felt that with every playthrough I found out more and more about the overall storyline with no extraneous or repetitive revelations (so regardless of order, the sentiment would be the same) or that I somehow managed to pick the one best combination for optimal satisfaction: [spoiler]Ikki > Toma > Shin > Kent. The revelation about the girls at the end of Ikki's route really helped when I met them in subsequent routes. And Kent just ended off everything with the sweetest note.[/spoiler]

Sinful voices. Gorgeous character art. Memorable personalities. And happily ever afters that I just want more of. Some of the paths are a little counterintuitive (to my personality) but there isn't really any choice that doesn't have plenty of clues laid out if you're paying attention. If I have one complaint is that there isn't more of the side characters; you do get more of them when you pursue Bad routes, but I'd have liked it more if the MC could've had both guy and friends, y'know? [spoiler]I felt awful about the lack of attention that Sawa got for the most of the game if you were trying for the Good ends; you needed to ignore her so many times![/spoiler]

Still. If you like VNs and you haven't played this game, please do. If you like anime, give it a shot since everything is fully voiced anyway, so you could technically just set it on autoplay, kick back and enjoy it. 10/10 would play again. Confession? I'm considering doing another run through of all the Good endings so I can end it on an Ultra high (since I had to work out all the Bad endings).

20435460.review:
I played the PSP version of Amnesia when it came out years ago, so I was curious about the translation and how it would "feel" to play it in english and in HD-- it was €2,79, so why not?
I love the game itself, both the plot and the graphics are great. The mystery evolves very smoothly, and the more you go on the more you want to know what happened to the heroine or what the other characters are 'hiding'.
Some people may find the fact that the heroin doesn't actually talk till the very end of the game weird or irritating, but I didn't mind it 'cause Orion was always speaking for her (sometimes I wish he would just shut up lol).
The minigames are very easy, and I think they were...Unnecessary, maybe? Idk, I played them just to get the achievements, they were pretty boring.
Every character is interesting and none of the routes are boring. Well, I already knew about THE THING in Touma's route, so it made me laugh lol. Yeah, maybe that was avoidable. Oh, my favorite pg is Ukyo btw, but his route is full of feels and I actually liked him more in the fandisk (Amnesia Crowd for PSP). I can't decide who gets the 2nd place between Kent and Shin, they were both cute~
The translation was very well done imho. I play games in japanese all the time, and translations aren't always well done so I was a bit worried about Amnesia, but I was pleasantly surprised. There were, however, some lines that didn't match at all with what was being said, or lines where the subject of the sentence was wrong, causing a bit of confusion (I remember noticing this near the end of Ukyo's route: the written lines didn't make sense and were a bit confusing, so I ignored them and listened to his voice instead). The lines that didn't match were for the most part minor parts (like insults or short sentences), so it didn't affect the quality of the game. PS: I'm not talking about things hard to translate: they were "normal" sentences which could have been easily translated. I wonder why you do a nice translation and then make such avoidable mistakes or totally change the meaning of a line. 
So, to sum it up: I LOVE Amnesia, and if you don't understand japanese then this is perfect for you. I bought it when it was €2.79 and, honestly, if I had to buy it now at full price I wouldn't, because I like japanese games more and bought this just out of curiosity. Amnesia is worth its price tho. It's well done, it has VERY nice graphics and a good plot. If you like visual novels this has to be in your library!

20411338.review:
An official Otomate game on steam that should be played by every otome player. This isn't an indie title or an OELVN, this is one of the most popular otome titles in Japan by one of the largest otome game companies localized for PC. The game goes for $80+ or more in Japan, so $30 is more than worth the price of the game's content. It also gets a lot of discounted sales, so there is no reason to not buy this.

If you haven't watched the anime, I would suggest playing the game first. Also, consider using a random playing card generator to pick your route order, it was really fun for me lol. Playing in the order from top to bottom is best though.

+ Art is top notch quality and absolutely beautiful. Gorgeous colors, complex character designs, and a multitude of CGs. Although the backgrounds are a little weak, you don't spend too much time in one place.
+ Japanese voice acting is and always will be an A+ for any game. Personally, I put the text speed to 0, so the text could match up with the spoken dialogue length.
+ The routes are long. Multiple endings add a lot of replayability.
+ A great choice system that applies to you (the player) and the heroine's personality. The consequences do matter as you could put yourself into a bad ending. Getting the good endings without a guide was extremely satisfying for me. The effort to reach all the endings don't require walkthroughs (though tempting), it just requires a lot of patience (a quick save/load function would have been appreciated).
+ A strong mystery story and good use of the amnesia trope. The routes cover entirely different storylines with an overlapping mystery that is revealed through the final route. The story reaches a satisfying conclusion, although bittersweet, and should answer all questions.
+ Strong character personalities that go beyond otome stereotypes, I was thoroughly surprised that Ikki became my favorite guy when I had written him off as the player type.
+ A lot of extras such as short stories, minigames, and nice CG rewards for being a completionist
+ I prefer a balance between story and romantic scenes, which Amnesia does right. There are cute moments and sexual tension scenes. Ikki managed to make me blush after trying hard not to. I felt satisfied with each world's relationships *except Toma's
+/- The minigames in the menu aren't utilized in the main game at all, even though there are scenes where the minigames could have been used. For that reason, they felt more like an afterthought as an extra. Also, the air hockey minigame has unexplainable lag, which makes it frustrating to beat, but not impossible.
+/- Music is so-so. It sets the mystery (with a bit of horror) mood, but no tracks really stood out to me.

*A note for achievement advice: the gallery has a hidden minigame. The rose stickers on certain CGs have voice clips hidden in several spots of the photo (follow the controls). [u]I can confirm that you must do this in ONE SITTING to unlock the achievement.[/u] Thoroughly click all over the pictures because there is about 6-7 dialogues each (don't forget the variations and zooming out).

Overall, Amnesia has become one of my favorite otome games and I really hope the other titles (Crowd, World, and Later) can be localized.

20243621.review:
I played the game and I'm attempting to finish Toma's route for dayyyys now. I didn't know much about the game before hand since I only decided to play this when I saw a friend tweet about it. Good thing I bought it on a discount. 

Overall it's a nice game to waste your time with. The character art is so pretty.The routes that I liked at most part was Ikki's and Kent's but barely (one reason why I liked the other is because there's an option to break their kokoro hahahaha). The plot is interesting at the start, but for some reason I end up fast speeding throughout the game. I think Kent's adorable, but he's a jerk. Well, most of the guys are really. 

The plot would have been great if it was executed properly and it maybe it showed us more about the MC's inner struggle instead focusing on her rude male leads. Like maybe add drama to how she felt personally. I'd like to see her looking through old pictures of friends/family and feeling sad. Or how would she react if she realized that her family isn't in good terms? Or wondering if the her before was better than the her now.

I didn't like that most of the guys were passive-aggressive or sexually aggressive to the MC. I can't believe she can't even call the police even though that is the most reasonable choice. Or go to her family. Find her relative's address. Get ideas from her classmates/workplace instead of trailing along strange guys who you happen to be "in love" with in your pre-amnesia days.  

Most of the guy's weren't nice at all, especially Toma. If you guys are suffering from a past abuse it'll probably trigger  some bad memories. Love can't alone can't cure someone. In the end, you have to cure yourself. And right now, I think I'm just probably forcing myself to finish the game for the sake of the trophy's. 

The game itself feels like it's forcing you to be a submissive, "innocent" and guy-pleasing girl. Most of the time I had to wince while the guys manhandle the poor heroine. I wish there was an option which allowed the heroine to break up with them and find her own way of solving her amnesia without relying to some strange guy who says he "loves the heroine" meh. [spoiler] I never felt so happy when the heroine broke up with Ikki it was really satisfying especially throughout the whole time I forced the heroine to handle those scary fangirls. [/spoiler]

Lastly, I wish the female lead had more voice. She's so passive. So quiet. Why can't she talk back? Why can't she disobey the guy? And why is she blushing when obviously what the guy is doing to you is disturbing, degrading and embarrassing? Why does she have to listen to Orion when some of his advises aren't reasonable at all? 

 I don't hate the game. I just really am frustrated about it. The story would have been good if they added some emotional moments centering on the heroine instead of her current love problems. Ditch the guy and be your own hero!

20206078.review:
Now, I'm updating my review after many more hours on the game that might be more helpful to those who are deciding to purchase it or not.
General Gist: 
Amnesia: Memories is an otome game, meaning it is directed at a female audience, with the style of a dating sim. However, this is not your average VN because of its dynamic complex plot where a "spirit" named Orion bumps into you and you get the option to choose between worlds to enter and live. In addition, you remember nothing other than your name and are doing your best not to raise suspicions among co-workers and friends. Your family are who-knows-where.
Needless to say, you start each world with a different boyfriend and different realities or personas between characters. Take "Manager" for example, the guy changes his behavior between each world.
There is a hidden theme in the game (spade...clover...Diamond...Heart... and I'm not sure what was the fifth one they made represent the fifth / Ukyo )

Coming from Con Vs. Pros.
Pro: 
-Somewhat unique storyline -- I mean you still have amnesia throughout all of it, but the boys have different backgrounds you will have to go through and learn about. (( (Slight spoiler) There is a yandere & someone with split psycho behavioral disorder amongst the five. ))
-Voiced -- Not everyday will you get a completely Japanese voiced Otome game for a reasonable price based on the quality of the game given.
-Beautiful Illustrations -- Many of us know that this is as high quality as it gets. / Hot as hell. / Even the simply backgrounds give a sense of professionalism
-Five Long Routes & multiple endings. It does have some replay value if you don't get the good ending on the first try, but if you are like me and after doing four rounds of Ukyo and not doing so hot, you'll have to rely on guides. It's impossible unless you have a million hours to spend crashing and burning. However, if you're also like me, I fear bad endings so it's been a tough ride. The endings are also satisfying to an extent. I mean, no one has babies or anything too drastic, but you do get a peek into their future. I highly recommend Kent because well, he's simply cute, but many tend to like Ikki or Shin (no matter how mysterious that guy is.) If you look at my hours now, which should surpass around a day's worth (I took breaks in between routes) , that is how long it'll take to finish four routes (depending if you don't get short bad endings) & by looking at the guide, it feels like I'm just going to constantly get spooked by Ukyo for an eternity. It has taken me about a night and evening to finish a route so I'd say about 5-7 hours per route on good ending, but it really depends on your speed. I like to immerse myself and understand the storyline before continuing panels so I might be one of the slower readers. 
*Trading cards
*Cute CC's / Wallpapers
*Minigames

Con: 
-Price I think the hardest choice for me was judging whether the price was worth it. As mentioned above, the quality states that is definitely worth it, but I bought it on a really high sale. I believe it is a definitely good buy.

The graphics are pretty. The guys are relatively attractive. Most of the stories are detailed and interesting. However, I ended up not recommending the game due to Toma's story. 

Toma's story is extremely awful. It involves abuse, Stockholm Syndrome, and r/a/p/e threats. No kidding. I honestly am not sure who in their right minds would think that this would be a good romantic story. It's a romance story turned into horror. All of the guys do problematic things at one point or another, but they're usually small things that can be overlooked and one can still enjoy the story. Toma's story is just wrong in so many ways that it's sickening that it was even in the game. Honestly, the best part about Toma's story was the normal ending, because the main character gets to escape him.

In one of the bad endings, [spoiler]Toma has the main character in chains, literally just a bunch of chains. Her memory is completely gone and she's dressed in a maid outfit. There's also the insinuation that he does whatever he wants with her, probably including r/a/p/e.[/spoiler] Just to give you an idea of how horrifying this whole thing is.

If you get the game, please get it on sale and if you have experience with abusive relationships, I truly don't recommend going through Toma's story.

Otherwise, the game was interesting and fun to go through. It's such a shame that such a good game has been tarnished by one story in it.

20158073.review:
For once, there's actually a VN side character that I dislike/hate as much as Umbridge, and that's saying something, [spoiler]Rika, I'm looking at you. Especially in the majority of the routes.[/spoiler]

General Overview: You play as an amnesiac heroine thrown into a world with established relationships. It's up to you, with the help of a spirit called Orion to navigate and try not to get yourself thrown into the explosions of Bad Ends.

If you're expecting full-on fluff and all, this VN won't be for you. There're some fluffy moments, mixed with slight comedy but otherwise you're on the mystery/thriller/emotional rollercoaster train. This VN explores some dark elements in terms of human nature, as well as the struggles between doing what feels right and what doesn't, whether to follow your heart or your mind.

All the routes differ from one another, but overall there's actually a hidden connection between all of them which makes it all the more fascinating.

So far I'm thoroughly enjoying it. The writing is interesting, though it can be a little slow-paced in a route or two but otherwise it's very well-written. Especially the Joker route. Thanks, Otomate, I totally needed multiple trips to the feels train...

Good endings completed...now the normal and bad ones...

Most memorable line as of far:

"I don't think you can call it deception when the people you're dealing with are stupid." - [spoiler]Shin[/spoiler]

20135830.review:
Amnesia: Memories takes one basic plot thread and weaves four major narratives from a single concept into four compelling worlds to take you on an unexpected journey. Having a basic plot concept retold in four different ways with multiple endings gives this VN excellent replay value.

I initially had no expectation because I had only played one visual novel prior to Amnesia. I'm glad I went in neutral because I was pleasantly surprised at what I got. While I've only conquered three endings so far, I plan on finishing more. It's rare for me to sit through one playthrough let alone multiple playthroughs of a story-rich, dialogue-heavy game. Different worlds, different relationships, different levels of creep.
That'd have to be the easiest way I could define this.
And this isn't even a horror game.

Having played all three of the games, I was really glad to see this make it to Steam. This is one of the better Otome games out there, having various elements that actually make the gameplay interesting and not only sticking to lovey-dovey stuff (but worry not, there's plenty of that~).

Each of the four (cough, five) men that you get to pick have their own stories, their own hardships, their own strong personalities. I must remind you of what I said earlier though, every single one of them is a creep in their own way -cough- cage, murder, math (because seriously, why math....), over-the-top playboy or more lies than I'd probably ever told.

And yet you still choose to love and date those creeps because you're no better than them, with your adorable little spirit that's teaching you how to deceive others to hide your amnesia.

This is life at its finest, ladies. Possibly gents aswell. I hope you all enjoy the ride as much as I did.

I bought this game a whim for $2.99 during a Steam sale and thoroughly enjoyed it.

You play as a woman who lost her memories when a spirit smacked into her by mistake (long story but the spirit in question, Orion, is amazing).

You then have to uncover said memories by interacting with characters around you, some of whom may be trying to manipulate you. Like we're talking "oh, this guy seems nice...... Welp, I'm trapped in a cage now."

There's multiple different playthroughs and each playthrough has at least one good, one normal and one bad end. The voice acting is still in Japanese but there's subtitles. The voice acting is great though and I love the animation style.

There's also air hockey and rock, paper scissor mini games.

I played through most every route and loved it.

5.	Мы преданы только женам. Пока ты не одела на меня кольцо – я как милый песик. В смысле, для меня всегда найдется хозяйка, как только она увидит, как я с такими глазками могу ртом искать косточку в ее персике.

7.	Мы не умеем считать. Вот прям сейчас спроси у ближайшего к тебе самца сколько будет 760+740 и он включит калькулятор в телефоне. Проверила? То то же.

20104243.review:
Amensia memories is a great otome game thanks to the beautiful art, developed characters, decent voice acting, and the good writing. But more importantly, this game really shines as a whole. A lot of visual novels try just go with the different routes being unconnected so that you get a different experience with each, but not too much of a whole story. Amensia memories is able to provide the unique experience of multiple, separate routes while all braiding back together into a beautiful story. 

The characters are also incredibly well done. While it is true your boys have this tendency to monologue at you, I rarely found myself wanting to skip through it. Often, I would say man, I wish there was a route for the girls in this game just because they too are well done and I would love to see more of them. 

The final detail that makes Amesia Memories unique is the story telling is refreshing because of one lovable spirit. Orion takes the role of the narrator, guide, and friend so while the protagonist is not entirely robbed of her own voice and personality, it puts her on the back burner from having to forcibly describe every scenario and feeling. Often, visual novels get into an awkward form of story telling where the protagonist fails at "show, not tell" and painfully details every thought and feeling. Instead, we have Orion asking your opinion and formulating plans that show how the protagonist, and subsequently the player, feel about it.

You will laugh, you will cry, you will spend the night in a dog cage, and you will die plenty of times. It's a wild ride, but it really is worth it. I highly recommend finishing each possible ending to get the full extent of its value. Like I said, this visual novel is at its best as a whole, so if you pick it up, be prepared to devote some time to getting the big picture. It will be worth it.

20059093.review:
I bought this game during the 2015 Autumn sale. I've never watched the anime, but I heard bad things about it. But since the game was insanely cheap during the sale, I decided to buy it and I didn't regret it.

You play a girl who has lost her memories. And depending on which "world" you choose during the prologue, you're the target attention of a certain guy. Your goal is to try and recover your lost memories without letting anyone on to you having amnesia. 

There are 5 guys, each with their own route. In order to unlock the 5th guy's route you have to get the "Good Endings" for the 4 other routes. 

The guys in the game are pretty likeable. At the start of each route, I was like "wtf who the fuck are you" but by the end of each route, I ended up really liking each guy. 

Each of the guys have their own personalities:
Shin- The guy who acts like he doesn't give a shit, but he actually does give a shit
Toma- The guy who acts like your older brother, but secretly wants the V. 
Ikki- The ladies man
Kent- The nerd who is awkward as fuck in a relationship
Ukyo- The guy with a double personality. 

Personally, Shin is my favorite (and so is his route). 

The art and music are both BEAUTIFUL. 10/10 

There's also 2 mini-games you can play (by selecting them on the title screen): Rock-paper-scissors and Air Hockey. Unfortunatley, the air-hockey doesn't work for me because it lags a lot :/  The rock-paper-scissors is kinda fun, but I only played it to get the achievements. :P

Overall, I enjoyed the game. I did find some of the routes a bit boring, though. I really liked Shin's, Toma's, and Ukyo's route, but I found Ikki's and Kent's a bit boring at times. I still did enjoy them though. :) Now I might try watching the anime series because I heard it's not as confusing if you've played the game.

TL;DR buy this if you want to date a bunch of hot animu guys

20055939.review:
7.5/10
Estimated play time per route: 3:30 hours
Estimated full game time: 18 hours
Recommended route order: Kent, Ikki, Toma, Shin, Ukyo
Most in-depth route: Ukyo
Most lighthearted route: Kent
Darkest route: Toma

Pros:
-Edgy characters
-Stunning character art
-Smooth Japanese voice acting
-The secrets to uncover are different in each route
-Lots of unexpected, exciting endings (8 bad, 4 normal, and 4 good endings)
-No two characters are alike 
-Orion. Even though he talks a bit too much, he adds a lot of needed personality to the game


Cons:
-Toma
-Romanticizes toxic relationships 
-Sexist. The male protagonists treat the heroine like an item who can’t fend for herself and blatantly don’t respect her (Something I don’t exactly fancy in general otome)
-Not enough original thoughts or insight from the heroine. I understand that the heroine is supposed to be a self-insert, but it would be nice to give her a bit of in-game personality. It felt like I was controlling a lifeless doll.
-Predictable, limited in-game choices. You can tell a bit too obviously which choice is “good” and which is “bad”
-Not enough slots to save and bookmark 
-Vague parameter system	
-Pointless, boring mini games


This isn’t the type of game I’d usually play, but after reading good reviews and finding out it was on sale for a good price, I decided to try it out. When push comes to shove, It's nothing that special. If you like otome games and gorgeous art, you’ll enjoy this game. The translation has its flaws, but it’s much better than most of the otome games you can buy on mobile nowadays. It’s also less expensive, since you don’t have to spend $2.99 to buy each chapter. If you want to play this game but have no prior knowledge of visual novels, I would definitely recommend playing some low-key, less intense games before buying this one. I can’t imagine going into this game without being familiar with anime tropes and the culture behind its gameplay, since some of the characters and places can come off as odd or unsettling. The key is to not overthink the story flaws (even though they’re in abundance) and just play it for the romance routes. If I wasn’t a person who relied heavily on story growth and world building, I would have given this game a higher score. It’s not terrible, but with these types of games it's hard to impress me. 

10 times better than any Voltage Inc. game, though.

19805452.review:
[i]"I love you. I love you so much, I start to think I'm some idiot."[/i]

Mein zweites 'visual novel' Spiel. Nur gekauft weil mir die Bilder gefielen.

Mein Pro und Kontra gleich mal zuerst und danach das lange Blabla:

+ Liebesschwüre en masse - [i]"No matter what happens, I won't let you go ever again."[/i]
+ gibt auch n Anime dazu, den aber nicht zuerst gucken
+ Bishies
+ zum sterben schöne Bilder
+ tolle Bilder
+ wunderschön gezeichnete Bilder
+ teilweise wirklich süße Bilder
+ überwiegend einfache und dennoch effektive und bequeme Bedienung
+ super Guides über die div. Enden in der Community hier
+ Möglichkeit die GUI auszublenden um sich die schönen Bilder anzugucken
+ schönes Drama der Gesamtstory
+ die Bilder sind auch nicht zu verachten

- Liebesschwüre en masse - [i]"I love you. Today, tomorrow, 1 year later, 10 years later... forever."[/i]
- Cosplay Klamotten (Was zum Geier, wie sehen die denn aus? Was denken die sich morgens vor'm Spiegel? 'Heute zieh ich den Mantel mit den vielen fetten Schnallen an zum Matheunterricht')
- Startet im Fenstermodus
- 'Secrets Revealed' Errungenschaft ist 'a pain in the arse' (googeln, dann findet man in nem Playstationforum Bilder mit Markierungen - für's Login ins Forum -> Bugmenot)
- Keine Möglichkeit eine getroffene Auswahl rückgängig zu machen. (Neiiin, falsch geklickt, Ende im Arsch)
- Orion sabbelt zuviel - 50% davon offensichtliches, 30% Wiederholungen nur in anderen Worten

Hab mich vorher nicht über den Spielinhalt informiert und bin irgendwie davon ausgegangen dass ich im Laufe des Spiels diverse Erinnerungsfragmente meines Lebens sammeln/freischalten muss.
Aber eigentlich geht es in dem Spiel nur um Teenieromanzen, nichts anderes. 
[i]"I love you. I doubt I'd be able to go on without you, and only you."[/i]
Freunde - pffft - no need. Familie, wer? 
Letztere ist bequemerweise sowieso in keiner Welt anwesend, ausgenommen eine kurze Stippvisite von Herrn Papa bei einer Welt.

Was mir aber recht schnell, also schon bei der zweiten Welt, auffiel, war wie übertrieben dramatisch Gefühle ausgedrückt wurden. So richtiges Teeniedrama eben ala "Ich würde sterben für Riley!" (Wer das nicht kennt muss mal Pixars 'Alles steht Kopf' gucken).
Wer gerne dahinschmilzt muss es sich unbedingt anschaffen. Die englischen Zitate hier sind alle aus dem Spiel und stellen nur eine kleine Auswahl dar.
Die schnulzigsten Stories sind auch gleich die 3. (Clover) und die 2. (Spade), genau die die ich auch zuerst spielte (erst Clover, dann Spade; mit Heart - erste Welt - wollt ich nicht anfangen weil ich dachte da wird's rosarot und schnulzig, wie falsch ich doch lag).
So im Nachhinein wäre es aber dennoch besser die Welten so durch zuspielen wie sie dort gelistet sind. Wenn man, wie ich, erst die dritte spielt, dann wird einem schon was vom Love-Interest der zweiten Welt gespoilert.
Auf keinen Fall mit der vierten Welt (Diamond) anfangen. Die ist ein wenig kränk.

[i]"But I'd be okay if you kept touching me forever."[/i]

Überdramatische Wendungen (teilw. schon Klischees) hat jede Story. Nachdem man die vier durch hat schaltet sich eine fünfte Welt frei, Joker, in der die universelle Verbindung zum Vorschein kommt. Auch wenn ich es mir schon im Groben zusammengereimt hatte, fand ich die komplette Storyidee am Ende klasse, inkl. der überdramatischen Teeniescheiße. Es war herzerweichend. Am Ende war ich doch zutiefst gerührt vom Gesamtbild.

Wer nicht genug von den Liebesschwüren bekommen kann, der kann in der Galerie noch Bilder mit versteckten Audiohinterlegungen anklicken (sind mit ner Rose markiert) oder sich noch diverse Erinnerungen angucken/durchgehen die nicht in den Hauptstories eingebettet wurden.

Spiel startet im Fenstermodus. Muss mit der Maus erst maximiert werden zum Vollbild (wäh?). Die Welten sind alle mit dem Controller spielbar. 
Die Minispiele und die versteckten Tonausgaben der Stillbilder in der Galerie müssen mit der Maus bedient werden. Wer nicht auf eine 100% bei den Errungenschaften aus ist, kann beides aber komplett auslassen.
Zum beenden des Programms musste ich aber immer Alt+F4 nutzen.

Außerdem bietet dieser visuelle Roman nen Automodus bei dem sich die Dialoge selbst fortsetzen in normaler Sprechgeschwindigkeit (Start am Controller), und auch ein Skip-Modus wo bereits bekannte Dialoge in rasender Geschwindigkeit abgehandelt werden (X Button beim Xbox Controller) und nur gestoppt wird wenn entweder gehandelt werden muss (Auswahl) oder noch ungelesene Dialoge auftauchen. Vergangene Dialoge kann man sich auch anzeigen lassen (linker Joystick -> hoch; beim Controller).
Find ich alles klasse. Besonders wenn man die Welten wiederholt für andere Enden.
Schlecht find ich dass man eine Auswahl nicht rückgängig machen kann, hab mich 2x verklickt bei ner Option und musste dann von vorne, bzw. letzten Speicherpunkt nochmal anfangen. Bleh

19703208.review:
One nice thing about this game is that it supports the use of my Xbox1 controller.

The game is very linear with endless dialogue before you can pick an action to change the path of the story. There is a strange creepy vibe and after playing about 2 hours it gets really weird. 

Artwork is pretty good- the lanugauage is all Japanese with subtitles. I enjoy watching some anime and this game makes it feel I am watching a show but I can pick some options while playing the main protaganist. 

I don't really like the one dimensonal view of the game. It's the equivalent of watching someone play Pong, but with cutesy anime characters. At some points I think playing Atari would be more interesting instead of listening to the characters drivel on and on and on as I keep hitting the action button.

You'll need patience and a genuine interest in the story line to play this game. If you are the type that enjoys anime AND the Twilight Saga (aka: Tween/young adult)....then by all means check it out. 

I'm glad to have helped out the developers with the purchase of an indie game and hope in the future this game will be more interactive.

Would I pay full price? Nope!
I waited until it was on sale.

19680066.review: This game was even more than I could have hoped for. Not only were the bad endings BAD - something that I feel I was spoiled with by DMMD, man are those endings horrible - but the normal endings are sweet and heartfelt and the good endings are perfect for each of the boys. I loved everything about this game, from the voice acting to the art to the story itself. It was a very fun read and I definitely plan on reading through it all again sometime! And I really hope that the other games get translated at some point too, because I just NEED more of these characters (and that Orion route, please please PLEASE).

19674560.review:
Sehr gute Visual Novel.
Ich hatte bereits gehofft sie irgendwann erwerben zu können, seit ich die Animeadaption gesehen hatte.
Obwohl ich sie für 90% off erhalten hatte, hätte ich auch ohne zu zögern den vollen Preis bezahlt :)
The Routen sind alle ähnlich aufgebaut, doch viele Details und Veränderungen von Charakteren auch sehr unterhaltsam.
Ich persönlich habe auf Ukyo hinaus gespielt, da er von Beginn an mein Lieblingscharakter war, jedoch auch andere Charaktere sehr liebgewonnen, die mir zuvor nicht allzusehr zugesagt haben (Kent).
Jeder Route war sehr schön gestaltet und hatte eine schön ausgearbeitete story, die durch erhalten aller Enden immernoch weiter ausgebaut wurde, da man durch diese weitere Details erhalten hat.
Die Unterschiede in den verschiedenen Choices, die man machen kann sind oft sehr subtil, verändern das zu erreichende Ende jedoch teilweise stark, was mir sehr gefallen hat. Es hat einen richtig dazu gebracht auf jedes Detail zu achten :)
CGs und Artwork overall waren auch sehr schön, hach, ich liebe diesen Artist einfach xD
-
Die japanische synchornisation war auch immer sehr angenehm, die Voiceactor haben alle wundervolle Stimmen und tragen auch immer angemessen der Atmosphäre bei.
-
Es wa die erste Visual Novel, die ich bis dato gespielt habe und ich muss sagen, jetzt liegen meine Ansprüche vermutlich sehr hoch xD Ich habe das Spiel innerhalb von einer Woche durchgespielt und würde es auch mit Sicherheit einen zweiten Run starten.
------ Achtung, ich gehe auf die Routen ein; es können Spoiler vorkommen, auch wenn ich mir nicht 100% sicher bin xD -----
Shins Route war die erste, die ich gespielt hatte.
Um ehrlich zu sein war das Suchen nach dem Täter nach einer Weile etwas eingefahren, weil ich von Anfang an bereits eine Vermutung hatte, jedoch wurde es sehr schön umgesetzt.
Alle Enden an sich waren irgendwie toll, außer ein Bad End. Um ehrlich zu sein finde ich, es hat auch die Bad Ends anderer Routen sehr schön vorhergesagt haha xD
Good und Normal End waren beide gleichermaßen zufriedenstellen. Natürlich, das Good End war das beste, doch auch das Normal End hat mich mit einem guten Gefühl zurückgelassen.
Shin ist einfach ein toller kleiner, manchmal bösartiger Tsundere.
Ich liebe sein Charakterdesign und seine Art und Weise der Heroine seine Zuneigung zu zeigen.
Seine Shortstory war auch ungemein niedlich, alles in allem wirklich eine sehr schöne Route.
-
Ikkis Route war mein zweiter Spieldurchlauf.
Ich weiß auch nicht, ich habe im ersten anlauf irgendwie nur seine Bad Ends bekommen.
Es war eine Route in der mich wirklich nur das Good End befriedigt hat. Sein Normal End war okay, hatte jedoch einen recht bitteren und ungewissen Beigeschmack.
Seine Bad Ends sind alle irgendwie tragisch.
Hachje, allerdings ist sein Charakterdesign tiefgründiger, als man auf den ersten Blick erwarten würde.
An sich aber auch eine sehr schöne Route :)
-
Kents Route hatte mich überrascht.
Sie war wohl von allen die niedlichste Route, wenn ich ehrlich bin.
Ich habe sie sehr genossen, und auch das Characterdevelopement sehr angenehm empfunden.
An sich eine tolle Route. Alle Enden haben mir auf ihre Art und Weise gefallen.
-
Tomas Route war....
...naja speziell. Es gibt bestimmt Leute, denen sie gefällt doch für mich persönlich fühlte sie sich sehr unangenehm an. Ich wollte ehrlichgesagt nur, dass sie schnell vorbei ist xD
Das Einzige Ende, das irgendwie okay war, war sein Good End, alle anderen Enden waren für mich weniger als zufriedenstellen. Hm..naja, jedem das seine.
-
Ukyos Route war mein persönliches Highlight.
Sie war schön gestaltet und hat alles in allem alle Fragen, die in anderen Routen aufgeworfen wurden beantwortet.
Seine Bad Ends haben mir persönlich auch sehr gut gefallen xD
Tragisch fand ich persönlich, dass von den 8 Enden, die man in dieser Route erreichen kann lediglich eines ein gutes Ende für ihn ist.
Sein Charakterdesign ist meiner Meinung nach sehr schön, und rundet das ganze Spiel angenehm ab :)

19671483.review: If you are a fan of otome games this is a good one. Though not as good as Hakuoki which is by the same creaters, it still is a beautiful game. When I tried the anime I felt like it was missing something and that the game was probably better. I was right. I like that you can get different endings depending on your choices. Plus the art is gorgeous.

19670043.review:
TL;dr: For an otome, it is quite dark. So things get crazy pretty quick. You have many hours that you can put into the game, depending on how fast you read, it may vary. The characters are all unique in their own way, some more unexpected than others. The Art is very beautiful, followed along with very well chosen voice actors. The stories all can get you very involved and wanting more. Only bleh is some achievements suck and Orion constantly yappin'.

Recommend: To those who like Visual Novels, unique characters, romance, engaging stories, and pretty art.

-----------------------------------------------
Game: There are lots of hours that can be put into this game which is good when seeing the price on this game. You get also a lot of unlockable additional content which makes it more worthwhile.  Such as memories and short stories in the boys' perspectives. Oh and mini-games which are pretty fun if you aren't in the mood for reading. Good amount of save slots, but in the end, I was wishing for more for Ukyo ~ n ~  Also is great that you can choose how it is read. You can turn on and off the V.A.'s, put it on Auto, Speed through text, show text and previous text all together, etc... Made it definitely a good experience. AND to make things better, if you're trying to get a different ending and playing through again, if you speed through, it will stop and play if there is text that you have previously not read in your other playthroughs! And it will highlight which answers you've already inputed. No trying to remember now :3


Achievements: Some of these achievemnts are literally so annoying I just gave up -.- One is where you have to click the image multiple times just for the guy to say a couple things. Looked up where to click and it still does absolutely nothing.  Everyone, but Kent's, I have had difficulty getting one part of their picture to work, It is seriously the dumbest thing ever. >_> The others are easy to obtain.

Anime VS. Otome: I found out about the anime first then the otome. I'm happy I came across the otome because now I realize how BAD the anime is. The anime doesn't cover really anything, Like the first 5-10 mins of the boys' story in the otome, so it was nice to really get to delve into these boys stories way more than the anime ever did.  Only thing is I kind of liked in the anime that Orion wasn't there 24/7. The otome he just literally drove me bonkers @ n @

Art: The art is very beautiful and definitely draws you in.  Their character design is actually very well thought out and you see a bunch of tiny things that really bring everything together, Also with their personalities, it ties in with the design. They have different poses which are good as well. The only weird thing for me is how large some of their hands were... But the style and coloring is very pretty. The gallery has lots of pretty images that are saved from your specific route and you can even move around the picture and check out different areas of it. There was a lot of variety and ones you unlock just from completing certain acheivements. Though that stupid ctrl-left click thing for their "hidden" message things were annoying. I'd click and it would end up going to the next image instead. I had an immensley hard time trying to get parts of an image to register. No matter how many times I clicked Toma's fist in the 2nd variation nothing happened, Shin and Heroine picture variation 2, her face would not react at all, Ikki and the heroine at the theatre, the hand wouldn't register. I've looked this stuff up to see if I'm just clicking slightly off, but I am clicking where I need it. So that part gets a 0 in my book because it was just frustrating.

Music: The music wasn't distracting and pretty good for the most part.

Characters: The characters all had variety and interesting endings, though some just seemed completely random at times. I wish there could have been more choices to choose from and Orion would STOP making decisions for me -.- I'm looking at Toma's route heavily when Orion becomes really annoying. Speaking of Toma, [spoiler]I wish we could have learned more about why and when he started to have yandere tendencies. Just seeing his past with the heroine, it just seems odd that such a sweetie would now go nut-so if you ask me [/spoiler] I liked the guy characters because they all had their set personality making it fresh when you go to a different route. And many of the stories were very interesting to go into. I don't want to go into too much detail so this will be spoiler free.

Shin-> He is such a tsun tsun but  a sweetie ^ u ^ Oh and suprisingly the smartest guy out of the bunch in the end. I guess seemed a bit more realistic to me than the other boys.

Toma-> I personally really liked his character, he's definietly not for everyone. I just liked he was really out there compared to the other characters. [spoiler] Though I think the Heroine shouldn't have been all okay after what he did to her @ m @ [/spoiler]

Kent-> He starts off a total meanie-poo but like Shin he really isn't that bad. He goes off onto a lot of tangents of things like math and what not. But he was an amusing character.

Ikki-> The "playboy" or "pretty boy" character but reading his story, there is so much more to him than on the surface.

Ukyo-> Prepare for the feels! His story is so bittersweet. You can't help but like this guy T w T

Based on the characters themselves and how much I liked them:
[b]Toma>Ukyo>Shin>Kent>Ikki[/b]


Based on stories I found the most interesting are in the order: [b] Ukyo>Shin>Toma>Ikki>Kent[/b]. Ikki and Kent's story didn't interest me as much, I guess they just felt, I guess more like slice-of-life, while the others seemed to be a bit crazier with their stories, drawing me in more. (However, this is just a personal preference)

Story itself: I found it a quite interesting premise, though I wish you could voice up more, Orion ends up taking the brunt of everything, which kind of ruins the effect for me. But  [spoiler] unraveling the mystery in some character's stories for why you have Amnesia were actually quite interesting, some were very dumb though...) [/spoiler]

Voices: The characters' voice acting is very good @ w @ I really enjoyed them. I especially liked Shins. Haha. But I think they all fit the characters very well.

~Overall. I really enjoyed the story and the characters in  it.  It was an enjoyable experience overall and would recommened to anyone who likes visual novels and an interesting set of characters.

19664090.review:
When I first watched the anime I never could've expected the game behind it to be as good as it turned out. Not only is Amnesia: Memories refreshing, sweet and aware of what it's doing, it's also extremely entertaining. Even though I can think of a particular route in which the heroine made me wanna rip my hair out, most of the time she ended up feeling close to me, like I could relate somehow (which I figure is her whole purpose). There's also the fact that although every character starts off from a cliché, they all end up being a lot more than that. The characters that I love had so much development I pretty much fell head over heels and even the ones I didn't like didn't remain static.
Overall I'm beyond pleased that this game was localized and I can only pray for the rest of the games in the series to be localized as well. At least on my part I can say that I'd pay for every single one of them.

19663231.review: When I saw Amnesia Memories on Steam I got intrigued. I watched the trailer and got intrigued even more (not to mention that amazing song playing in the background). I went for Kent right away and I had so much fun dating him. I went to bed way past 2am, still hyped and determined to play it again. I really like how the game's made. It's got amazing voice acting and great visual style. I love the way the characters were drawn. The funny bits really cracked me up and I found myself grinning at the monitor, thinking 'awwww, ain't that cute?'. Today I chose Toma's storyline and it's quite interesting too. I actually like Amnesia so much that I googled a walkthrough for every character and I'm planning to try all possible endings :) P.S. While googling Amnesia-related stuff I found out that it's based on an anime dating back to 2013! I watched all 12 episodes (+OVA) today and it was so good. I can honestly recommend both the game and the anime :)
