19576203.review:
What can I say about [i]Amnesia: Memories[/i]? What a strange ride this was. It was my first 'real' otome game and I bought it on sale for around $1 and all I can say that it was more than worth it! I loved it so much that I even bought another copy for my PS Vita.

[u]Art[/u]

The art in [i]Amnesia[/i] was gorgeous! Although some of the character designs were a bit more eccentric for my taste, they were all so detailed and fun and certainly fit into the strange world that [i]Amnesia[/i] is set in. There were varied character sprites for given situations and helped emphasize the characters' moods. CGs were generally varied and detailed. I don't remember there being any 'lazy' CGs, although there were eyecatch CGs that you could get. I don't really count them necessarily as proper CGs though. Sometimes faces of the heroine was a bit awkward, but it didn't detract from anything.

The only disappointing thing about the art in this game is the how little effort was spent on the backgrounds. The backgrounds are basically nonexistent. While the game was good enough in every other area for me to overlook it, I think some fully realized background art would have greatly helped in the immersion of the story for the player. I can't decide if backgrounds were done in the strange minimal way they did because of budget, laziness or somehow to fit their theme of needing to remember their past/[spoiler]days getting colder/perhaps less realized because of the whole multiworld thing going on[/spoiler].

[u]Story[/u]

When I went into this game, I kind of just expected something fairly cheesy and while it was certainly cheesy, it was also a mystery/psycho-thriller of sorts! Most of the routes revolve around a bit of a mystery and puts the heroine in dangerous situations. I felt like I was often doubting the truth of the situation and who to trust. I actually played Ikki's route first without knowing anything about who I was picking in the hub world and was it certainly a shock when [spoiler]I got pushed down a cliff and Ikki goes to avenge me by murdering (???) his fangirls[/spoiler]. 

Each character route is pretty much its own contained story and all of them were engaging in their own way. I played Ken's route last and that was a nice break from all the craziness of the other routes. 

You don't really get to know the 'real' story behind the game until you play the hidden route, but it reveals some fun things that explain more about the heroine's situation and all the strange things going on in her life.

Individual character routes can be hit or miss depending on what you like in a story. I haven't gotten all the endings for all the characters, but the replayability of this game is pretty high and I will probably try to tackle that at some point in the future. 

The writing was generally good. I don't remember any glaring typos or grammatical mistakes. There were a few lines here or there that were a bit strange, but the translation overall seemed sound and very readable. 

[u]Characters[/u]

All the characters were pretty likeable - some moreso than others. As you change routes, your relationships to and with certain characters may shift a bit and this changes how they act towards you as well. The 4 main bachelors were all interesting in their own regard and I won't go too much detail into what each are like, but here are a few sort descriptions:

Shin - Your childhood friend in most routes and is one year your junior. He is pretty loyal and kind of hotheaded. He really, [i]really[/i] wants to prove himself to you.

Ikki - Super flirty and has his own fanclub of girls. He was the first route I played and I pretty much loved him, even if [spoiler]his "problems" were non-issues[/spoiler]!

Kent - Highly intelligent and socially stunted, Kent doesn't really understand how to vocalize emotions and ends up just appearing to people a bit like a robot. It's up to ~you~ to help him out of his shell.

Toma - Toma is the "older brother" figure. He's overprotective [spoiler](that is the biggest understatement of the year!)[/spoiler] and does everything in his power to keep the heroine 'safe'. I hates his route the most, but it was also the weirdest and most surprising route? If you like [spoiler]yanderes who treat you like a living doll[/spoiler], you'll love Toma.

Hidden Route - You'll know who it is when you play the game! This will unlock after you get the good endings for all the other guys. [spoiler]At first I felt a bit dubious about how I would like Ukyo, but after learning about what happened to him and the heroine in the "originating" world, I found him very sympathetic and I actually liked him! Although he was pretty much a yandere too, I thought his route explained his actions much better than Toma's. Toma's just felt really scary to me! I know some people like that, but it just freaked me out.[/spoiler]

Side Characters - 

All the side characters were fun and added things to the story. Orion, the stand-in for the heroine, as the heroine is more or less mute in this game, was also pretty great! He brought a lot of comedic relief to an otherwise dark story. Orion also was pretty much the voice of reason when the heroine made stupid decisions (I know, I know, I made them [i]for[/i] her, but the game gives me no choice in the matter if I want a certain ending!). It was fun having some sort of company on this strange, wonderful journey of trying to remember if you were in love with a certain boy or not!

[u]Choices and Replayability[/u]

Unlike some other otome games (which I have been obsessively playing after playing [i]Amnesia[/i]), you can pick your character route right away from a hub world. You aren't told who you are picking per se, but are given a choice between worlds named after card suits. Each suit is affiliated with one of the guys and you just pick a world and boom, you're already on your way to woo the guy of your choice. 

Once you are put on a route, you can see some affections meters. There are a few meters you need to keep your eye on and the choices in the game really made a difference. I think I got two variations of Ikki's bad endings before looking up a walkthrough and getting his good ending! With at least 3 endings for each bachelor and little variations in between, I felt like your choices did have an impact, even if you didn't necessarily see it straight away. The deviations in how a story concludes isn't too different between the endings but I think they are different enough to merit seeing all of them.

As there are so many endings, the replayability is pretty high for this game! Like it said at the beginning, I will probably end up replaying this at some point to get all the endings. I only have the bad endings and normal endings left though so I will probably feel a bit said when I reach them.

[u]Overall[/u]

This is a pretty fun game to spend a good chunk of time on. Using a walkthrough will definitely help speed up the process of getting the route you want. The art is gorgeous and the story is engaging! If you haven't tried playing an otome game before, I would definitely pick this up. It is 100% worth the full price of the game, but it often goes on sale for a few dollars on Steam. If you're unsure about the game, pick it up then, but I still think it's be worth it if you like visual novel type games with a good chunk of mystery and suspense.

Suggested route orders I've seen end up being a variation of:

Kent > Ikki > Shin > Toma > Hidden Route

With Kent being first as it is the leasty spoilery.

My route order (as this was before I knew there might be spoilers in one route for another) went:

Ikki > Shin > Kent > Toma > Hidden Route

Shin and Toma's routes kind of spoil each other's I'd say. I played Shin's route before Toma's and I kind of knew what would inevitably go wrong in Toma's route! I played Toma's route last because I knew I would be freaked out by it!

19542349.review:
Part of the reason I played Amnesia: Memories - my first Otome game - is because of an early GameCenter DX episode. Shinya Arino was challenged to win somebody's heart in [i]Angelique Trois[/i], an entry in a highly-regarded Otome series. Despite spending 13 hours, following guides, and doing seemingly everything right, his confession of love to Seiran was met with: "It's 1000 years too soon for you to make fun of me. Wash your face and try again." Working so hard only to fail has to be absolutely heart-wrenching, and yet...strangely exciting. 

The strength of a game is in its ability to engage everyone outside of its target audience. On the surface, an Otome game involves romancing attractive men, which to a straight male gamer like myself, doesn't sound all that enticing. However, by utilizing a compelling narrative and/or intriguing game-play elements, I'll find myself immersed in every aspect of the game. Despite my inexperience with the genre, I believe Amnesia: Memories is a fantastic game. It couples a strong plot with great characters, and the few game-play elements bring everything together.

Due to the meddling of a strange kid named Orion, you've lost your memories. As pay-back for the mess he's put you in, Orion offers to guide you through five parallel worlds. In each world, you meet the same characters, but their personalities - as well as yours - are different. Moreover, the world you choose determines which man you could have a serious relationship with. There are other events that can occur, some funny, some dangerous, but all worth experiencing. Whether you find true love, see the story to its conclusion, or even meet a miserable end, is all determined by what you say and the actions that you perform.

As in real life, the lack of communication can ruin any relationship. Due to your amnesia, you won't know the right thing to say, so you'll have to pay attention to conversations and keep track of the details. While it would be very easy to use a guide and guarantee the best endings, I think actually putting in the effort to know someone is far more rewarding. On the other hand, my initial play-throughs mostly resulted in failure, so maybe I'm not cut out for videogame relationships. The point is that the less hints you have to work with, the more likely you'll become attached to the person you're interested in. 

As your story progresses, a handy chart tracks your relationship with the male lead, as well as suspicions due to your lack of memories. It's amusing that one of the few distinctly "game-like" elements actually isn't all that effective. For one, it isn't always clear whenever you say the right or wrong thing. Orion or one of the other characters may chime in, but sometimes you're left in the dark. The charts are more likely to shift when your attention is elsewhere, not when you're saving, reloading, and looking for the slightest change in your "does he love me?" gauge. Furthermore, this is all the more reason to not refer to a guide early on. After all, real relationships aren't forged through the use of cheat-sheets.

As for the guys themselves, I think the writers did a fantastic job giving them plenty of depth. I mean sure, they're attractive enough, but that's to be expected. The most appealing aspect is finding out what they're really all about, and discovering just how much they care. These guys know exactly what to say and when to say it, so those special moments really have a lot of impact. The average story takes about 4-5 hours to complete, and if you're really into someone, there's going to be those few times where he'll really turn up the charm. I'll admit, I get a little light-headed whenever Shin blushes. On the other hand, a couple of the storylines are more intriguing and disturbing than they are romantic. If you've browsed the community hub, or read some of the other reviews, you'll know exactly what I'm talking about. If not, then my advice is to play through the stories from top to bottom, exactly as they're listed in the game. In any case, there are more than enough dark and mysterious elements that make for very compelling entertainment. 

This game also benefits from having high production values. Aside from the heroine, everyone is fully-voiced, and the acting is more than serviceable. The CG scenes are very nicely drawn, and the soundtrack is decent enough for setting the mood. The fast-forward system makes replays a breeze, and the mini-games are an amusing diversion. The backgrounds are a little washed-out and bland, but they're the last thing you'll notice when playing the game. Again, this is my very first experience with the genre, but I can tell that the developers really cared to deliver an appealing product. Although, I did notice a few typos in this localization. It's nothing major, especially considering the size of the game, but all the same it's worth mentioning.

All in all, Amnesia: Memories is a superb example of an Otome Visual Novel. Not only are the stories well-told, but the characters are endearing, and everything looks and sounds wonderful.. It'll take 25+ hours to experience all of the content, so anyone out there wondering if they'll get their money's worth doesn't need to be concerned. Still, I have to admit that I'm a little frustrated with myself. I played through all of the stories and not once was I able to get a good ending without a guide. There was always that one moment where I treated the guy I was dating as a third wheel, or didn't appreciate his gestures of affection, or failed his math test. Ahh...if only relationships were as easy to understand as [i]Dark Souls[/i].

[i]If you liked this review or want to see more recommended games, be sure to follow our curator group: [url=http://steamcommunity.com/groups/Original_Curators_Group#curation]Follow Original Curator Group[/url][/i]

19523867.review:
The biggest killer for this game is the price point, for my personal run in is snagging this title for only $3 on a steam sale (might be worth a shot then) there are other VN titles out there with more intriguing situations that will better suit a read be it for story or an emotional experience.

The concept is interesting in regards to throwing the player as an amnesiac (overly used RPG trope) and you are to interact with her most recent boyfriend (which the player gets to choose which route at the start of a play) to try to remember what  key events lead you to being in a relationship in the first place (which will solve your amnesia if you can manage the standard or good end for the route)

the ISSUE lies in the execution and weather or not the reader is "ok" with relatively passive Japanese young woman as there silent protagonist.

For its full price, there are many other worthwhile VNs out there that will create more authentic "feels" than this, but if you can get it for a bargain price and aren't too serious about reading what amounts to VN twilight (note there are no sparkling vampires, but there is a spirit in your head for a different fantasy cue) and enjoy the work for an ironic reason then Amnesia might be worth it for an unintended laugh.

Als Amnesia: Memories dann zufälligerweise im Angebot war musste ich zuschlagen und im nachhinein habe ich bereut nicht den Vollpreis bezahlt zu haben!!
Normalweise kostet das Spiel 27,99 € und ich hab es für 2,79 € kaufen können.
Ich bereue es auf eine Art und Weise, weil das Spiel so interessant, atmosphärisch, intensiv und fesselnd ist!

Amnesia: Memories hat definititv einen bleibenden Eindruck in mir hinterlassen und ich werde vermutlich noch lange daran zurückdenken wie das Spiel die unterschiedlichsten Emotionen in mir hervorgerufen hat, weil der gesamte Storyverlauf in allen Routen die du wählen kannst äußerst emotional und unglaublich ist.
Ich hab mitgefiebert, mitgeweint, mitgelacht und mich mitgefreut - alles zur selben Zeit wahrscheinlich :D

Die Geschichten sind alle auf ihre Art und Weise vielschichtig, doch hat man stets ein warmes, fast schon nostalgisches Gefühl wenn man die anderen Charaktere wieder trifft, wenn man zuvor schon eine andere Route gespielt hat.
Denn egal welche Route man spielt, es tauchen immer wieder die selben Charaktere auf, nur stehen sie im anderen Kontakt zu dir.
Beispielsweise war Person X in Route A noch deine Feindin und hat alles versucht um dein Leben zu zerstören aus Eifersucht. In Route B ist Person X eine gute Freundin von dir die viel von dir hält und dich stets schützt.
Am Anfang des Spiels wird dies auf jeden Fall genauer erläutert.

Ihr wacht bei jeder Route am 1 August auf und das ohne jegliche Erinnerung an eure Vergangenheit und müsst ohne Verdacht zu schöpfen zunächst durchs Leben kommen.
Denn wenn ihr allen erzählen würdet das ihr eure Erinnerung verloren habt, weil ein Geist mit deiner Präsenz kollidiert ist und dieser Geist in dich eingedrungen ist und deine Erinnerungen ersetzt hat... naja man wird euch als Verrückt einstufen und ins Krankenhaus bringen.
Leuchtet wohl ein :')
Die Hauptaufgabe besteht darin euer Gedächtnis wiederzuerlangen, aber vielmehr auch herauszufinden welche Art von Gefühlen ihr für den Mann empfunden hattet der euch in den jeweiligen Routen am nächsten Stand.
Das allein ist schon schwierig genug, denn ihr habt viele unterschiedliche Antwortmöglichkeiten die euch auch schnell zum schlechten Ende führen lässt.
Und so müsst ihr euch durchschlagen um am Ende glücklich zu sein, so dass der Geist euch wieder verlassen kann.
Das ist gar nicht mal so leicht!

Ich hab auch nach meinem ersten Durchgang ohne jegliche Hilfe angefangen ein Guide zu benutzen um alle möglichen Endings sehen zu können.
Bis zum jetztigen Stand habe ich beinahe 31h gespielt und habe 5 gute Ending, 2 normale Endings und 3 schlechte Endings gesehen, das verdanke ich zum einen den Guides die ich benutzt habe und zum anderen auch der Tatsache das ich an vielen stellen einen anderen Spielstand angelegt hatte, um da dann eine andere Entscheidung zu treffen!
Ansonsten hätte ich noch gar nicht "so viel" an Endings sehen können.

Das Spiel hat durch die verschiedenen Endings (5 gute, 5 normale und 16 schlechte) einen hohen Widerspielfaktor.
Wenn ihr 4 gute Endings in den ersten Welten erreicht habt wird die letzte Welt freigeschalten und durch eine aufmerksame Spielweise wird einem auch schnell bewusst weshalb es so viele schlechte Endings gibt.
Indem ihr auch ein gutes Ending in dieser Welt erhaltet bekommt ihr die letzten Informationen die euch fehlten um alles zu 100% zu verstehen und das ist ein sehr zufriedenstellendes Gefühl, nachdem alles immer so verworren und durcheinander war!

Leider bin ich noch nicht mit den positiven Aspekten des Spiels durch, denn die Musik im Hintergrund ist stets stimming und passend für alle jeweiligen Situationen gewählt.
Ich bin wirklich ein Fan von der Musik geworden, kann selbstverständlich auch nicht aufhören die Musik dementsprechend rauf und runter zu hören.
Liegt aber wahrscheinlich mit daran das ich mit jedem einzelnen Musikstück eine gewisse Erinnerung nun verbinde.
Sowas gefällt mir bei Spielen immer sehr gut, wenn die Musik ebenfalls einen bleibenden Eindruck hinterlassen hat!

Ich hoffe sehr das Idea Factory ein weiteres Otome-Spiel veröffentlichen wird und es wieder so grandios werden lässt wie Amnesia: Memories ♥

19511036.review:
As like many Otome games, there is obviously a lack of realism. However, trudging through some of the weird premise that all the boys love you without any memories, you'll find a pretty intricate foundation for the world of Amnesia. I found it pretty fascinating in the aspect for world building. I've always been interested in a visual novel that basically goes backwards (due to amnesia).  Story-wise, it's a lot deeper than it appears. It may seem shallow at first, but once added together it has some depth and darkness. It's eerily dark and convoluted for an otome, actually.

A note: Unfortunately, I wouldn't recommend it to a male audience. I imagine it would be well welcomed by girls (because it's made for girls). The game is also based on Japanese culture, so some parts may not relatable to a Western audience(?).

Game-wise, while I enjoyed the routes to some degree, half of the characters lacked the development they needed/deserved in their respective routes. A lot of issues especially with Toma and Ukyo are shoved under the rug rather than resolved in a constructive and healthy way. I'm assuming that this may be addressed in the sequel games (Amnesia Later).

I really like the characters themselves! Possibly the only reason I continued to read. Their relationship web, aside from the MC, made them a lot more likable. I'm also a sucker for reminiscing in any medium.

19500300.review:
[b]TL;DR:[/b] 4/5. One of the best otome game I've played so far. I highly recommend it! 

---

[b]Warning:[/b] This review may contain [b][u]spoilers.[/u][/b]

In Amnesia: Memories, you first open your eyes to a vast empty space which - you soon learn - is the gateway to many parallel realities. You then meet a spirit (Orion) who basically tells you that he's stuck inside your consciousness; his collision being the cause of your memory loss. The first major choice you make in the game is to pick which reality/world you came from: Heart, Spade, Clover or Diamond, i.e. according to the motifs associated with each of your love interests. There's also an unlockable world (Joker) you can only get after achieving good endings in the other realities.

[b][u]Story:[/u][/b] (5/5)
Unlike many other visual novels in which you gradually form a relationship with your chosen love interest, I find it refreshing that in Amnesia: Memories you're already in one at the very start. The five routes (worlds) have a similar theme of you having some sort of relationship issues (plus the memory loss), but the plot in each is very different - giving the game a [b]high replay value.[/b] Some of the minor characters even have completely different personalities: most notably, Waka, the manager of café you work at. Each route took me about 5-7 hours to complete and the game, around 30 hours.

While there are some internal monologues at the end of each route, you are entirely silent unless making a choice. Because of this, I feel that it is [b]easy to get immersed[/b] in the story. It's like you're holding a conversation (although one-sided) with Orion throughout the game. Don't worry though, he knows when to make himself scarce during the more romantic scenes.

The story itself is lighthearted at the beginning, but around the halfway mark it becomes more suspenseful, tragic and even creepy in some storylines; [spoiler]Toma's (Diamond) route in particular (and Ikki's fangirls). The whole incident where he drugs you and put you in a cage made me very uncomfortable; and the fact that we're (as the main character) expected to just forgive him to get the good ending left me really baffled.[/spoiler] Other than that, I truly enjoyed the other routes with Kent's (Clover) and Ukyo's (Joker) being the stand out. At least Kent's route provides some reprieve from the craziness of [spoiler]Ikki's fanclub.[/spoiler] And Ukyo...I can probably write an essay on how I feel about his story but I'll just say it's worth experiencing for yourself.

There are also a few things I feel that aren't as clearly explained [spoiler](e.g. the wishes, Lord Nhil and the world Orion came from)[/spoiler] but overall it's [b]very well-written[/b] with only a few, minor typos. I also want to mention the various instances where characters tease you with obscure(?) hints (spoilers really) of what can happen to you in the other routes. I find these very amusing especially if you only realize it after playing a few times.

[b][u]Gameplay:[/u][/b] (3/5)
The game [b]plays like a basic VN[/b] with dialogue branches and unlockable CGs. There are unfortunately [b]only 24 save slots[/b] in the game. I would've much preferred to keep all my saves instead of having to overwrite each time I start on a new route. If there is a way to watch the complete ending scenes again, I wouldn't mind as much. But since there's not, I think the game could do with unlimited save slots.

The game provides you with a [b]'Parameter' system[/b] (shown on the 3rd screenshot) to check the status of your relationship and maybe which ending you get in the end(?), but I think it [b]is a bit unnecessary.[/b] The 'Suspicion' meter, in particular, maxes out at some point in the story no matter what you do anyway.

The 2 mini games available are simple, short and somewhat enjoyable. What I do appreciate about the Rock-Paper-Scissors mini game is the Hit 'N' Guard mechanic that ensures it relies less on luck and more on your reflexes. It does make the mini game way easier however.

There are also a few extra content unlocked after finishing the game including short stories told from the perspective of the love interests that I find interesting. I recommend reading at least Ukyo's.

[b][u]Controls:[/u][/b] (3/5)
I was pleasantly surprised to find out that the keyboard (and gamepad?) [b]controls are re-bindable.[/b] Although I don't think I would ever need to re-bind anything for this particular game, I do appreciate the devs putting that feature in regardless. [b]I do wish there was an option to skip the story after picking a choice,[/b] but other than that, I have nothing bad to say about the options menu.

[b][u]Graphics:[/u][/b] (5/5)
Practically [b]every character in the game is gorgeously designed,[/b] and every voiced dialogue is accompanied by effective use of expressions and eye blinking. The [b]stylized backdrops[/b] with little tints of color suit the game in my opinion and [b]makes it look very surreal/dream-like[/b] in its simplicity. A close-up of the curtains at the Shinano mountain lodge in a few conversations, however, looked very messy and amateurish but that's just me nitpicking.

[b][u]Sound:[/u][/b] (4/5)
The [b]voice acting for all the characters are done very professionally[/b] by accomplished voice actors. There are no English voices but the high quality of the Japanese voices more than makes up for it. The [b]lip syncing is just okay[/b]; it's a bit distracting when their mouths move even when they're not actually saying anything. Tracks used for the background music are generally soft and tranquil but slightly repetitive. I can listen to the opening song all day though and to a lesser extent, the ending song as well.

[b][u]Conclusion:[/u][/b]
A must try for [b]fans[/b] of the genre. I can't say if it's worth it for $30 since I bought it on sale. But for $3, I would definitely recommend buying it.

19470879.review:
General Review: 

As someone who plays countless of Otome Visual Novel style games, this one was absolutely beautiful and I would recommend this game if you love otome games that have bad endings or if you're a crazy person that loves getting 100 percent achievements out of a VN/Otome. This one isn't quite as amazing bad ending wise, as other Otome games but - There still were many bad ends with several CG's, and it allows for further interactions later.

1) Music: 8/10. The music Looped really well, and I didn't get annoyed with it despite playing the game continually from start to finish. 
2) Voice/Translation: 10/10. The voices came out really well and I actually liked all of the male actor's voices in this. In the story, and the "extras" which I won't spoil. There were no bugs or typos in the translated to English version.  
3) Artwork: 10/10. This was beautiful. All of the CG's/Artwork was impeccable with this. I didn't find any weird looking scenes or anything off with any of them. All of the characters looked like themselves, and MC looked pretty in any of them where you see her.
4) Characters: 8/10. There's a few things I didn't like which I'll place in spoilers, ordered by who I liked best (A), to who I didn't like much.(E)

A. Toma [spoiler]Not yandere enough. He only went full blown yandere even in what is arguably the "scariest" ending for Toma in Ukyo's route.  Toma didn't get maniacal enough on any of the bad paths in his route so it made that one end on Ukyo's route, creepier. Oh, and the fanclub thing. Toma handled it better than Ikki which made me like Ikki less.[/spoiler]

 B. Shin [spoiler] I couldn't figure out his character typing. Somewhere between kuudere and tsundere. That annoyed me, he also had a few wtf  choices to get his "true" path or all CG's. I also didn't like how Shin confronts Toma at the end for the True End. I get that he's not a criminal but it seems a little tame to just let Toma go with a punch to the face.[/spoiler]

 C. Secret Path [spoiler] Ukyo was kind of a cry-baby, I'm not into that type of character either, but at least he had no math and a ton of endings lol. Ukyo's related bad ends in other guy's routes either as they weren't dark enough to make him appear as disturbed as he's portrayed in his own route. Also a couple of his bad ends were similar. I think that there could have been a few more alternate ones added, to tie up what he says to heroine for "advice". I think it would have been an interesting bad end to get between Shin and Toma since Ukyo tells you not to, but you really only see Toma lose his mind and go crazy whereas Shin doesn't do anything.[/spoiler]

D. Kent [spoiler] If I recall correctly one of his bad ends literally made me have blank stare face, since It was that predictable too. Not to mention the rival confusion which was MC's boss (yikes.). The math questions... WHY??? Those were not fun to work out in my head when I was just interested in getting the story. To pair all of it off, out of all the guys, Kent to me was the least good looking character model. His hairstyle threw me off, and I didn't like his attitude. It was only later on in the path that I found him okay and I liked his True end. He didn't appear to be as "book-smart" as Shin, although he was the character is meant to be mathematical - so that didn't make sense to me. I get that he's supposed to be the intellectual guy but Shin seemed smarter.[/spoiler]

E. Ikki [spoiler]I seriously didn't enjoy this path. At all. I actually found his paths to all be boring to find/get. He didn't seem to have any emotion when MC was being threatened by the fan club at first. and he seemed like a huge coward/paper boyfriend. A few of the options for his true end seem wrong, and it was not that romantic or sweet. I wasn't a fan of the CG for his true end either, and I hated Ikki's personality. This could be bias because I hate the "player" type in these games. They have similar "fanclub" problems, which gets annoying. It didn't seem like Ikki cared a whole lot, and he didn't give his fanclub a harsh enough punishment for doing what they did to MC. >_> *tosses him in the trash* [/spoiler]


5) Story: I haven't watched the Anime Entirely yet, so I'm not certain how much of this comes from the Anime or if the Anime was made based on this game, BUT - The storylines here get pretty deep and they all have at least one or two things in common. I do think that overall the story was really good, but it had a few places where the story seemed to be a little slow, or a few extra days where they weren't really adding much to the story. I also want to say that some of the bad ends I would have prefered to see CG's on. They didn't really seem to have much "closure" and the fade to red thing seemed a bit cheap, given how hard some of those ends are to find.

Things I liked:
*CG Menu. 
I liked the fact that you have the cg with ability to scroll over and see the whole image as some of the cg images are rather huge. I also liked that they're organized by the character's name, as it makes it easier to browse though. 
*Extra stories/Minigames:
I liked the extra stories that you can unlock, as well as the minigames. At first you don't realise that some of the things are only unlocked by playing these.
*Bonus True Ending: TL;DR: That path ties everything together and makes the game make sense. 

Things I didn't like:
* No ability to Replay Endings from the Endings menu. 
I didn't like this because while it is fine to replay a game, It's really hard to remember what the right choices were if you have "already seen" answers highlighted. 

Advice on what I would do differently:  If you could have the ability to re-watch the full story with an ending that you already unlocked. Then have the game just let you click/confirm the choices for you since you've already unlocked the path. That's something I haven't seen in any other otome game. 

*MC wasn't voiced. I don't like this because in auto mode, if MC says something, it skips over it instantly.

*Spoiler for CG's: [spoiler]Point and Click - CG Game. This sucked. To get literally every single CG done, there's no icon change, or any sort of way of telling which picture you have left to click through. It made getting that harder than it needed to be.[/spoiler]

Bonus: 
The Secret Character path... Spoiler alert:[spoiler]This was my third favorite path simply because of all of the bad endings. I wished that all of the other characters would have equally as many bad paths, especially Toma. I don't know if that's related to the anime, or whatnot however so I understand why that is. (Still other guys were not as "bad" as they could have gotten on the bad ends.) I sincerely loved the "true ending" on the Secret path because it filled in a few of the "gaps" that the story left out in the other worlds.[/spoiler]

19455615.review:
This is a game for Twilight fans. However, I strongly advise against buying this game for and by young people.

First of all, although some of the game plots are interesting, some of the ideas in this game are just plain wrong and often illegal. This is a game promoting violence and objectifying women and glorfying the image of ever timid, submissive and forgiving lady. You invite a boyfriend to your flat for tea - you are asking him to "have his way with you". You are walking alone in the evening - "you are putting yourself in danger and asking for it". The guy turns insane, holds you in a cage, tries to rape you - the good ending is to "show how much you still love him". Another crazy dude is killing you in the most elaborate of ways on various occasions - "forgive him and be truly happy together". Most of your boyfriends treat you like crap; to one you are like an item that needs to be protected, another one calls you an idiot most of the time, yet another treats you like shit in public. And the good ending to all of that - be timid, don't complain, let them do what they want and be completely forgving and understanding when they hurt you. Otherwise you won't even hear an apology. This is game makes toxic relationships look romantic and "fixable with the power of love". The whole message is so wrong on so many levels that only adult people that already have some life experience and their own opinions should play this game.

The game is quite passive; a lot of it is just talk talk talk that is basically redundant. The translation is ok at best, there are many grammar errors and weird constructions. The artwork and audio are quite good, though I must admit that in certain CGs or positions the characters look quite "derped". Some of the plot ideas are interesting; for example, Shin's mystery line is quite interesting. Some are really, really dumb - Ikki is pure Twilight. He is also dumb enough not to figure out your amnesia. All in all, this is a 6/10 game for adult audience.

However, Amnesia is fantastic; the art is lovely, the story is engaging, and I definitely feel immersed. I've currently completed two stories with their various routes completely (heart and spade world), and I'm on to the third. I have a good sense of who everyone is, and it keeps me asking questions; I started playing and now I'm finding it difficult to stay away. I thoroughly recommend it to anyone who likes a bit of mystery in their visual novel too.

19385978.review:
Un jeu vraiment sympathique et prennant.

Je connaissais déja l'otogame de nom et j'ai également vu l'anime inspiré de l'univers.
C'est pour cette raison que je n'ai pas hésité à acheter ce jeu (qui était en super promo, soit dit en passant).
J'apprécie beaucoup ce type de jeux et j'y joue régulièrement, c'est pour cela que je devais absolument partager mon avis sur Amnésia.

Ce titre est vraiment original pour plusieurs raisons:

- La bande son qui vous plonge en immérsion dans l'univers.
[spoiler] J'ai vraiment flipper par moment dans l'arc de carreau grâce à la musique inquiètante xD[/spoiler]
- Les illustrations vraiment magnifiques et animées pour certaines. (Les nosebleed ou saignement de l'orteil sont à prévoir!)
- Une fin multiple pour chaque monde emprunté
[spoiler]Enfermée dans une cage par Toma ca fait grave flipper xD[/spoiler] 
En général, dans les otogames la trame principale reste la même, la seule variante réside dans le choix de la personne. Dans Amnésia c'est totalement différent de ce que j'ai pu rencontrer auparavant. 
En effet, c'est le scénario entier qui se trouve changé grâce au choix de l'arc. On ne se retrouve plus avec une histoire avec 5 fins différentes, mais avec 5 histoires à fins multiples.

Pour moi si vous êtes férvants de ces jeux il ne faut pas passer à coté et je vous le conseille vivement. 
Certes, il est en anglais et ca peut faire peur à certains (dont moi). Mais j'ai été surprise de voir à quel point il était facile de comprendre sans être un dieu en anglais. Puis si on hésite il y a toujours google traduction xD 
La langue n'est pas un obstacle si certains hésitent. 

Amnésia, Une expérience à faire au moins une fois!

This visual novel is great! The art is beautiful, the voices are so cool too and the storyline is better than the Anime. Though the anime is cool, this visual novel is better. 

You get to be up close and personal, actually feeling what the character you play feels throughout it. In the anime, the main character seems dull and boring, since she doesn't really have memory to have a personality. But in this visual novel you can choose what sort of personality your character has! 

Though the personality you give your character can lead her to trouble, eg Bad ends, it's nice to be yourself or follow a certain personality trait you like and see how that develops with characters! 

Like with Kent, it was my first playhrough of the game, didn't know how it worked yet and decided to be myself in it. My character then had her first happy end! I was very happy with Kent. I think I like the intellectual (sp?) type - especially the ones who seem cold and distant, they seem lonely, and before I knew it I started falling in love with Clover! 

I did think that some of the storyline from the anime was going to be in the visual novel, which it is was, so I knew what was going to perhaps come with every character. So I prepared myself for the Diamond world... lets just say I got a bad end. :p

18915718.review:
A fantastic Otome and one of the best I've ever played.

The mystery and drama surrounding all of the characters is enough to draw in even those who are not into the romantic aspect of it, but do be warned it is in fact heavily based in romance.

It is a fairly linear game, but it makes up for it by having three ends (good, neutral, bad) for every guy and a lot of unlockables.

The character art is fairly good but the rest of the art is pretty lacking. You'll be seeing a lot of the same blurry backdrops over and over, but the engaging story more than makes up for it.

Unravel the mystery of who you are and fall in love over and over again.

I strongly recommend this game to anyone and everyone as long as you're able to get it at a reasonable price. I can fully understand why $30 for an Otome may seem like a lot to people not familiar with the genre.

18838931.review:
Only started playing the game yesterday and so far I achieved one normal (Shin) and one bad ending (Ikkyu). 

To be honest I only bought this game because I was bored, wanted something new to play and really liked the artwork. I have neither watched the Anime nor even knew what the story was about, though I could obviously guess part of it thanks to the title. Given the fact that this an Otome game I didn't really expect much, story-wise at least. I thought I'd get some fun hours outta this, with too much cheesy talk and some bishounen without any character depth, so when I actually got into the game I was really happy to discover how wrong I was.

Sure, for people who look for a game with much gameplay, who get tired of reading pretty easily this would probably be torturous to sit through and there's no denying it's still an Otome game that fullfils some cliché aspects, but I like how much content and character depth is actually provided, especially compared to other games of the same genre.
For once, it actually does have a story (that's NOT predictable).
You get to play 5 routes and can achieve over 20 endings. The first two endings took me about 6 hours to achieve, so based on this I'd say you get to play a minimum of 60 - 65 hours. 


Anyway, this is definitely one of the best Otome games out there and might even be fun for those who are not particulary fond of the genre. Tbf I even think that this is one of the very few ones that even guys could enjoy and it is very much worth the money.

TL;DR:  If you're into mysteries, psychological drama, and romance and cool with your character being murdered a few dozen times as you figure out how to navigate the stories you explore, this is a great game!

---

[b]Overall Impression[/b]: I was surprised at how much I enjoyed this one. I wasn't very impressed with the anime (it was gorgeous, but just wasn't that great otherwise) and the initial pre-release reviews for it weren't that exciting. But once I completed it, it became one of my favorite VNs/otome games. I think it's well-worth being a game in your collection, even if you're not normally interested in otome.

[b]Content[/b]: Disturbing themes. As I said in my tl;dr, expect to be murdered a few times. As a minor spoiler, one of the love interests could easily fit under the 'yandere' (sick-love) type. The images never get beyond about PG-13 (for sexiness - you see very little or nothing in terms of violent images). As long as you're prepared for murder and yandere, you should be able to handle what the game throws at you. 

I will note that one of the endings was so disturbing I had to walk away for a few minutes. Several of the Bad endings are actually quite disturbing, so while I kind of enjoyed it in the thriller sense, some people might not.

[b]Translation[/b]: Seems quite good! I didn't have any issues understanding what was going on and it reads quite well.

[b]Editing[/b]: A few minor issues. A few typos here and there, but nothing to really disrupt your enjoyment.

[b]Art[/b]: Really top notch. Plenty of gorgeous CGs, a wide range of character sprites, and a really cool style overall. This is absolutely a game you could buy just for the art and be satisfied by if you like what you see from the screenshots. (Granted, it's not flawless, but it is very high quality.)

[b]Character Design[/b]: I personally enjoy it quite a lot. It's a shame you don't see the Heroine very much since I really dig her design, but all of the characters are quite nice to look at. (Okay, it's over the top, but it seems to be normal in their worlds, so it works for me!)

[b]Story[/b]: Have you ever had one of those dreams where you're dropped unprepared into a situation? Like, for me, I get dreams where I have to take a test I didn't know about, or I'm given a role in a play right before the curtains rise, or I'm being put on the field for a ColorGuard performance and have to rely on my memories of doing it in high school. Imagine that, but "for real". At least the Heroine has a cute and friendly Orion to help her out a little bit.

You need to figure out what your life is like in the world you choose and what your relationships are like with the people you meet. Eventually, you'll come to understand you're in a relationship with a guy in the world you're dropped into and balance trusting him and giving him the benefit of the doubt with not letting on too much too soon about not being the woman he knew. 

This delicate balancing act is the heart of each story and I personally found it interesting every time. The individual stories are a little linear, so the first part of a story route is pretty well the same, but it does branch out towards the end, meaning multiple distinct endings for each hero. 

For the most part, I enjoyed each hero's routes. (The "yandere" hero, not so much, but I can't say his route wasn't [i]interesting[/i], just not one I'd experience for romance purposes.) I think that most otome fans will find at least one hero they'll really enjoy.

[b]The Heroine[/b]: A blank slate - pretty literally, too. She has almost no text dialogue in the game and you have to simply infer she says something. This means a lot of monologuing on the part of the heroes - which is great if you're digging the voice actors (personally - I love them), but it does feel a little awkward sometimes, especially if the other characters point out that the Heroine is silent. It's clear from the flashbacks and comments from the other characters that she [i]had[/i] a distinct personality of her own before her amnesia, so I'm willing to give it a bit of a pass. Once she gets most of her memories back (assuming she does, that is), she starts having lines of dialogue, so I infer that means she's in full control of her "self" again, so the lack of real personality of her own before then feels fine to me in a story sense. 

[b]In closing...[/b] I highly recommend the game and hope you enjoy it too!

18436452.review:
Amnesia is a surprisingly good otome game and visual novel.  I went into the game figuring the game would be standard otome fare, but I was pleasantly surprised to see that it's actually very well written, supplemented with good art and sound.  Each of the routes had their own particular charms, which surprised me, and my own expectations of which routes I'd prefer turned out to be totally wrong due to the strength of the story and the characterizations.

Localization for the game is very good.  For me, poor localization, typos, and awkward phrasing completely breaks immersion for me in visual novels.  In Amnesia, I can't even remember any awkward phrases, and I found only two typos during my entire playthrough.  

The game does suffer from situations where the protagonist's actions (or lack thereof) defy common sense, though the use of Orion, her onboarded spirit, actually does help.  Orion tends to embody a lot of the inner dialogue (and outrage) of the gamer, embodying sentiments such as "how dare he say that!" that the protagonist unfortunately doesn't really ever act upon.  Amnesia also suffers from the common visual novel ailment where as the player it can be virtually impossible to know how to avoid bad ends.  There were thankfully less of these than in some other games I've played, but I did find it often frustrating how a single choice led to a bad end that the game gave me no reasonable clues to predict.  Similarly, I found the good ends frustrating to get because they didn't really follow obvious choice paths.

Overall though, Amnesia is definitely worth the asking price.  It has many hours of gameplay and for any otome fans out there, it's one of the highest quality otome games I've played here in the West.  When playing, I couldn't put it down and basically marathoned the game for a week, and was left wanting more.  (Please bring the sequels to the West, Idea Factory!!).

18363484.review:
I highly recommend playing this fantastic otome/visual novel game! It's a must have for people who like these sort of games!!

After watching the anime back in 2013 and finding out that this game would come out in 2015, I was extremely happy... so after managing to 100% the game, I have to offically say that this is one of my favorite game series of all time! (Now hurry up and release the sequels for us impatient fans!! [Later, Crowd and World]).

With this being my 2nd otome game that I'd play and with this game already having very high praise from Japan, I was very excited to jump into this new and exciting world where I will finally get the whole story of this universe. Oh how I was impressed with the way this game gave off a very care-free choice option off the bat.

Want to be serious and make a good and believe able example of yourself as the MC of this otome game, or do you want to be as unserious and awkward as possible and make your boyfriend suspicious of you? The choice is all there, especially when you get to chose between 4 (actually 5) worlds off the bat!

I was actually a little anxious that the MC would be one of those annoying, way too obvious or innocent type of girl... sure she is in the beginning, but once she remembers more memories and gets to understand how her boyfriend acts, she manages to remember her personality and is actually very likeable (you even get to see this by the options you have to chose to interact with different people).

Because of the free reign, it made the story progress very smoothly. There were no unnesecary moments/fillers (if there were they were either fluff moments where the boyfriend is acting all cute or comedy moments to shake off a little drama when it became too much) when playing through the different worlds, which again made each route and ending very enjoyable. And since it's a straight up visual novel, it makes the game very relaxing to play, as if you were going to watch an anime.

Finished all the routes? Why not go for ALL the possible endings? ...Still not enough? Then go ahead and go to your gallery and get some secret messages when you Ctrl+click on rose images where your chosen dream boyfriend whispers sweet-nothingness into your ear as they keep complaining about you clicking on them. Wow, still not satisfied when you have clickable boys and extra fluff memories? Well then air hockey and rock-paper-scissor might just be your thing!

The ammount of work, time and passion which went through with making this game is unbeliveable to grasp compared to how other games today are released. And this game was released in 2011 in Japan! I still can't thank Idea Factory enough, I couldn't help myself than to buy their limited edition box of this game to support them even more.

Anyway, to sum it all up:

PROS:
* Characters
* Beautiful Artstyle (especially the unique eyes)
* Pro voice acting
* Very interesting and good story for each of the characters
* Music
* Mini Games + extra CG/Gallery hidden story (extras unlock once you get every ending!!)
* Achivements

CONS:
* Minor visual/gameplay bugs when quick speeding (but this almost never happened or it recently got patched)
* Too few save slots
* Can't replay any kind of endings on the good/normal and bad ending list

Overall score: 9/10

18213963.review:
Overall I really enjoyed this game, but like a lot of otome games it has some problematic aspects along with the good ones.

First, the art is really beautiful even if the characters' outfits are completely, hilariously absurd. All of the sprites and CGs are really pretty, and the backgrounds are sort of a muted colors with white.

Unlike some otome games where you spend the first part of the game getting to know the characters and then figuring out which ones you want to romance, this game makes you choose immediately and then you are locked into that guy's route and can only succeed or fail (spectacularly) at it.

The good part about this is that the stories for each guy are very different, and as your character starts with amnesia (like the title) the mysterious and unknown parts of your life are different between routes. The relationships you have to the love interests and other characters change, which is really interesting and gives the game a lot of replayability since each route is basically its own thing.

The stories are all very engaging, but there are some definite yandere aspects to some of the relationships, so if that isn't your cup of tea you may want to look into which guys have that before playing so that you can avoid those routes. Or choose them, I guess, if you want to be locked in a cage by a possessive crazy person. :)

The bad ends definitely kill you, and since the MC has amnesia, she does tend to fall into the otome heroine trope of being fairly passive. There's a story reason for it, obviously, but if you're looking for a spunky MC with her own personality you won't find that here. MC has a few moments, but she's clearly intended to be pretty bland so that you can read whatever you want into her.

I recommend this game, it's a beautiful game with an engaging story, but it's definitely a Japanese otome game in a lot of ways which can be a good or  bad thing depending on how you look at it.

My favorite route was [spoiler]Ukyo’s—I honestly found it very emotional and it reminded me a lot of a shoujo/otome version of Mirai Nikki. Which I’m not complaining about, since that’s my favorite manga & anime series ever.  [/spoiler] I’m so glad that Amnesia: Memories was localized as it was the otome game I’ve wanted to play the most and hope this means more chances for other games to be localized *cough*Diabolik Lovers*cough*. If you’ve enjoyed games like Sweet Fuse and stories like Mirai Nikki, you should give Amnesia: Memories a chance. It’s a very entertaining game and has a ridiculous amount of content. It’s well worth the price!

18130587.review:
I am not sure if I can recommend this or not.
PROs:
- [b]Long gameplay[/b] - A lot of content. Already have 19 hours on it and I have not finished the game yet.
- [b]Gorgeous graphics and CGs[/b] - The graphics are extreamly colourful and beautiful. There are a lot of CGs, placed at the right place and and very emotional.
- [b]Mini games[b] - the games are very simple and can be beaten fast, but I highly appreciate them being there. Also rewards you for complition.
- [b]Emotional endings[/b] - you have 3 types of endings. Good endings are entirly satisfying; normal endings are positive yet not compleatly satisfying; bad endings go from a standart bad ending (the two characters don't end up togehter) to death (main character dies). I was never disapointed by the endings.

CONs:
- [b]Bad stories[/b] - I still don't have a story I was not bored of. It starts interesting but gets very old in the middle of it. That is due to dragging out plots that are not made for long gameplay.
- [b]Too long stories[/b] - a path is 8 hours (listening to all the dialogs and no breaks), The stories are not made for such long playthoughs so they drag out. The first story (shins) drags out unnessesary long and I was left with the impression 3 times that it was suppose to end.
- [b]Orion[/b] - Orion is a character that from now on became a definition for this problem. The little spirit that is to serve as narator speaks too much and takes too much of the screen time. He always states the obvious and repeats what the player already figured out. Add an option to disable him, would make the best game ever.

Edit: I just finished the game and all the stories. All what I said up stands plus:
All the male characters are psychopaths, and the protagonist can get the biggest idiot and a give up on all common sense in order to gain the good ending.
The joker conclution of the story is very satisfying with a sick ending.

18118163.review:
An extremely well-made otome game with intriguing storylines and gorgeous artwork. In this, you play as a young woman who has lost her memories. With the help of a young spirit, you must navigate the world around you in order to figure out who your enemies are and who you can trust. 

This is a wonderful game and I sincerely hope that we start to get more translations of popular Japanese otome games on here. Every route in Amnesia is completely different, so at no point was I bored reading through the stories. Highly recommended.

The Romance Options:
-Diamond: Toma - aka Mr. Yandere, was extremely disturbing. Not my cup of tea, but the other routes made up for his storyline.

-Heart: Shin - a childhood friend and a storyline that plays out like a detective story. This one was my favorite out of all the stories. I loved Shin, which was unexpected. Going into the game I had expected to like Ikki the best.

-Spade: Ikki - a playboy who has a "condition" where anyone who looks into his eyes falls in love with him. An interesting story that I enjoyed, even if I wanted to shake Ikki most of the time.

-Clubs: Kent - aka the Vulcan option. If you think Spock is hot, then Kent'll be right up your ally. This is probably the one route that was straight romance without a major plot thread involving murder mysteries, supernatural abilities, or crazy yandere boyfriends.

-Joker: I don't want to give much away for this route. All I'll say is that I enjoyed this one a lot. It ties together all of the storylines you've read by the time you get to this point.

18043678.review:
•Sipnosis

Un peculiar espíritu llamado Orion, comienza a llamar a Heroine al comienzo de la partida. Éste le dice que sus espíritus han chocado, y debido al shock, la joven protagonista ha perdido sus recuerdos. Le pregunta cuál es su mundo y le advierte que no debe ir al hospital bajo ninguna circunstancia, ya que su amnesia no es algo psicológico, por lo que debe hacer lo posible por recuperar sus recuerdos sin que nadie sospeche que los ha perdido.  

•Gráficos y Jugabilidad

Al comenzar, tendremos que elegir entre distintos mundos: Hearts world, Spades world, Clovers world, Diamonds World y Joker world (el cual permanecerá bloqueado hasta que completes todos los Good endings de los mundo anteriores). Cada mundo tiene como chico principal al personaje con el que más interactuaremos a lo largo de la ruta, manteniendo con él una relación romántica. Cada mundo no solo se diferencia por los distintos chicos, si no que el entorno, los personajes y las circunstancias también varían entre sí. Existen diferentes parámetros, desde la sinceridad y fuerza de la relación, hasta el nivel de sospecha del chico sobre la amnesia de la protagonista. Tus respuestas y elecciones alterarán dichos parámetros, llevándote a diferentes finales. El juego consta de más de 20 finales diferentes. Y, a diferencia de muchos otros otome game, el peor final no es una mala relación con uno de los chicos. La protagonista se enfrentará a serios peligros, como amenazas de muerte e intentos de asesinato, lo que hace que la historia tenga un buen punto de misterio y suspense. Por supuesto, no revelaré más para evitar spoilers. También tiene varios extras, como historias adicionales de cada personaje y dos minijuegos. Uno de ellos trata de hockey de aire, el cual consiste en marcar X cantidad de goles para derrotar a varios de los chicos que elijamos. El otro (el más entretenido a mi parecer) es el clásico piedra papel o tijera. Si ganamos, se debe golpear al oponente. Si se tarda un instante, éste se protege y no obtenemos puntos. Si eres de los que quieren ver todos los finales de cada mundo y quieres volver a jugarlo, tienes la opción de pasar a cámara rápida los diálogos que quieras, haciendo el juego aún más llevadero para los que quieran repetirlo. En cuanto a los diseños de los personajes, son fabulosos. Muy coloridos, pero sin perder la seriedad y esencia de cada personaje, además de un muy buen estilo de dibujo. Sus expresiones faciales cambian según la conversación, lo cual puede guiarnos en ocasiones para hacernos una idea de qué pueden estar pensando o cómo se han podido tomar un comentario. Los escenarios son de un solo color, cambiando el susodicho según la hora del día. 

•Banda sonora y sonido

Las voces están en japonés, lo cual les gustará a las personas amantes de ésta cultura (hablando claro, al 95% de los que compren éste juego). La música no es nada especial, pues consta de  un gran repertorio de música tranquila, a excepción de algunos momentos de tensión y peligro, pero nada que pueda sea recordado notablemente.

•Lo bueno

-La profundidad de los diferentes personajes

-La gran cantidad de finales

•Lo malo

-Únicamente está en inglés.

•Conclusión: Es uno de mis otome game favoritos. Jugué por primera vez en la PSP en japonés, y ahora he tenido la gran oportunidad de poder tenerlo aquí. Para los amantes de éste género, ésta debe ser una de las joyas de su colección. Es complicado que los buenos juegos de éste género salgan de Japón, por lo que ésta es una gran oportunidad que no debes desaprovechar. 

•Nota personal: 7’9

18034021.review:
As I've played the game in its original language, I can say that this english version has lost much of its unique puzzle portion in translation. Politeness levels in speech are found in Japanese and not English, so, half of the satisfaction in reading and decoding the social atmosphere and returning the correct polite/casual answers without raising suspicion is gone. 

Despite its shortcomings, uncovering of the individual stories and the overarching plot is still very much enjoyable, and this game's format has taken great pains to preserve the feeling of natural conversation as one of its unique points, from the way the dialogue is written to the way the speech is presented in game as speech bubbles and not text boxes.  

The HD graphics upgrade compared to the tiny resolution of the PSP is a big plus as well. 
Although there is some minor quality fluctuations (the blue swirly background at the beginning has artifacts leftover from upscaling for example) in this HD localised port, it's of little importance compared to the gloriousness of HD beautiful boys and sexy Japanese voice acting that they kept. 

Drool away, ladies, and don't forget to find the numerous drama CDs and character songs if you can understand Japanese (and also the three to four spinoffs in this series that they haven't translated).

When I bought Amnesia: Memories, I knew I was in for a treat. Having heard of it in Japan I never believed it would actually get a release overseas. To my great surprise and delight it of course did. 17999718.review:
Amnesia™: Memories is an interesting and addicting adventure. You follow the main character on her quest to retrieve her memories. In order to do that, she visits 4 different worlds (1 you unlock later) each with different distinct story line. However, in each world you have a different man as the main characters boyfriend. As you play you have to make different choices that in the end, affect the outcome of your story. It is truely a beautifully written game. 

You grow to love all the different guys and you get addicted to their story line. "Just 5 more minutes!" you keep saying to yourself but you find yourself unable to pull yourself away. Each guy is different and unique in their own way. My personal favorite has to be Kent, though Shin is right behind him. Both have an amazing story line. Ikki's story line is fun but you (as well as the main character) feel the frustration. I was very worried about Toma's story line and I would have to say it probably my least favorite. As for Ukyo's, I actually enjoyed his story line and it had one hell of an ending. Overall, I loved the unique story lines and it really pulled me in. I have only gotten the good endings and I look forward to getting the other ones as well.

They also made an anime which is very beautiful and I would recommend watching after you play through the story lines if you really love the game and wanna see it animated!

9/10

17977494.review:
Amnesia Memories is the best Otome game I played so far. The character graphics are splendid and you even have animation of the mouth when the characters are talking. This happens audio-wise in japanese but you do have english text in a textbox. I really like the size they picked for the text, but if I remember correctly there was even an option to scale that.

So in this game you pick the Route you want to go in the beginning of the game. Each Route leads to a different love intrest with an own unique storyline. Each Storyline plays in 30 ingame days, starting the first of August. As the title suggest your character suffers from amnesia and your ultimate goal, next to romance is to get all your memories back.

I won't go too much into the spoilery area, but the love intrests you have are of different character types: The cool guy, who has been your friend since childhood, the superstar, who gets all the girls but falls in love with you, The efficient logical nerd guy, who is a tad socially awkward and the protective big brother type yandere character. You can have many different endings on each on this character routes, from the bad endings, to the normal endings, to the good endings.

There also is one bonus love interest character, that you get if you finish all other routes with best ending.

17972941.review:
(So, das Ganze nun doch etwas ausführlicher):

Story:
Im Großen und Ganzen spielt man ein Mädchen, dass seine Erinnerungen verloren hat. Unterstützt vom Spirit Orion soll sie nun ihre verloren gegangenen Erinnerungen wieder zurückholen. Natürlich ist es nicht ganz einfach, sich zurecht zu finden, wenn man sich nicht daran erinnern kann, wo man wohnt, wo man arbeitet oder wer Freund oder Feind ist. Man befindet sich zuerst in einer Art mystischen Raum, in welchem man entscheiden kann, in welche Welt man eintauchen will und je nach Welt gibt es eine andere Geschichte, einen anderen Mann, dessen Herz man gewinnen kann (oder auch nicht), jede Entscheidung hat auf längere (oder kürzere) Sicht eine andere Auswirkung, man kann sich nie sicher sein, ob es richtig war seinem Kindheitsfreund zu vertrauen oder mit dem mysteriösen Mann von der Straße mitzugehen (ihr macht das natürlich NICHT!... oder doch? Was hatte Mami doch immer gesagt...? :D).

Sonstiges:

Man sollte das Spiel auf alle Fälle mit Ton spielen, da es eins der stimmungsvollsten Soundtracks hat, die ich je gehört habe. Je nach Situation variiert die Musik, auch Hauptmenü und die einzelnen Unterpunkte haben Musik. Die Synchronisation (japanisch (übrigens englische Untertitel)) finde ich auch sehr passend für jeden Charakter. Es gibt auch ein kleines Minispiel-Feature, wo man gegen alle 5 Jungs Air Hockey oder Rock-Paper-Scissors spielen kann, jeder Mann steht auch für einen anderen Schwierigkeitsgrad. Es gibt 26 Erfolge, die meisten gibt es zu den verschiedenen guten, normalen und bösen Endings. Wer Schwierigkeiten hat, alle Endings zu bekommen, sollte es mal hier (https://welcometowonderland.wordpress.com/2015/08/26/amnesia-memories-shin-walkthrough/) probieren, die fand ich ganz gut, weil man auf einige Sachen auch manchmal nicht kommt. Probiert es aber erst mal ohne, man bekommt relativ leicht mindestens das normale Ending bei jedem Chara außer Ukyo und da es auch auf alle normalen Endings einen Erfolg gibt, ist das auch nicht verkehrt.
Das Artwork erinnert an den Anime, es gibt sehr viele Parallelen, nur, dass das Spiel eben mehr Tiefe hat als der Anime, was aber verständlich ist, schließlich hat man in einem Spiel mehr Zeit, die Charaktere und Geschichte kennenzulernen.

Schwierigkeitsgrad:

Ich fand jetzt alle Spieldurchgänge machbar, ich hatte mindestens das normale Ending bei Shin, Toma, Ikkyu und Kent. Wer es hier ein wenig schwerer macht, ist der liebe (?) Ukyo. 

Und wer soll dein Herzblatt sein?

Wie schon gesagt, ihr könnt verschiedene Geschichten spielen, aber wenn ihr im Voraus schon euren Favoriten haben wollt, dann hier ein paar kleine Einblicke:

Shin:
In der Heart World könnt ihr an ihn euer Herz verlieren und wer auf den geheimnisvollen, ruppigen Typ steht, ist hier richtig. Harte Schale, weicher Kern, das passt gut auf Shin und er ist auch immer wieder für eine Überraschung gut.

Ikkyu/Ikki:

Ihr steht auf den Mann, der euch jeden Wunsch von den Augen abliest und euch die Welt vor die Füße legt... allerdings müsst ihr ihn euch mit dem Rest der Frauenwelt teilen, denn Ikki kann sich vor Angeboten nicht retten, da seine Augen MAGISCH sind. Wenn ihr damit leben könnt, dann ab in die Spade World.

Toma:

Ihr kennt ihn seit Kindheitstagen, er ist immer für euch da und scheint alles im Griff zu haben, aber irgendwie verliert er bei euch die Kontrolle, vor allem, wenn ihr Unterwäsche kaufen wollt... wie weit das geht, erfahrt ihr mit Toma in der Diamond World.

Kent:

Er ist schlau, er ist logisch, er ist gut in Mathe und er hat seine Zukunft geplant... aber Frauen sind für ihn ein großes Rätsel. Das ist Kent, der große Starke mit der Brille... und er sagt, dass ihr ihn hasst O_O... warum? Findet es heraus in der Clover World.

Ukyo:

Ihr mögt den unberechenbaren Typ, bei dem man oft nie weiß woran man ist? Zwar kann er ganz nett sein und wahrscheinlich seid ihr ihm wichtig, wenn er euch warnt. Aber warum warnt er euch vor sich selbst?... Findet es heraus in der Joker World (und speichert viel :D)
Ihm könnt ihr euch erst nähern, wenn ihr alle anderen Welten gemeistert habt (Wichtig: ihr braucht alle guten Endings!).

Fazit:
Eins der besten Visual Novels, die ich je gespielt habe. Die Geschichten sind glaubhaft, überraschend und auch witzig und süß. Was mir noch gefallen würde, wäre, wenn man den Charakter, den man spielt, selbst gestalten könnte. Die sieht nämlich neben den ganzen hübschen Männern irgendwie langweilig und blass aus. Ansonsten ist das Spiel echt klasse, gerade diese Vielfalt an Geschichten finde ich super und die vielen Möglichkeiten (soooooo viele Endings *o*). Der Preis ist natürlich etwas happig, aber im Vergleich zur Spielzeit ist es das wert. Außerdem ist die ganze Zeit Sahneschnittenalarm, wenn ihr versteht, was ich meine ;)

17945862.review:
Не различаю иногда что есть спойлеры, поэтому, наверное, они здесь есть.

Пока я ждала посылку с Hakuoki: Stories of the Shinsengumi Limited Edition - для PS3, у меня, так сказать, случилась Amnesia. 
Уже неплохо познакомившись с новеллами Idea Factory я уже знала что по крайней мере картинка и озвучка будут на высоте, да и сюжета  можно ожидать выше среднего. Но это...  сказать что я очарована - значит ничего не сказать. 
Такой подачи я никогда не видела. 
И таких противоречивых чувств от новелл не испытывала, а их мной пройдено уже чуть больше 30 (95% отоме, конечно же ^^).
Вместо привычного построения отношений по схеме: знакомство-выбор спутника-начало отношений-развитие отношений-концовка мы получаем выбор из нескольких параллельных миров по названию которых можно смутно догадаться кто будет в центре рассказа. Затем мы попадаем в ситуацию, где остается только догадываться о выборах, которые героиня сделала до нашего вмешательства. Каждое возвращенное воспоминание готово перевернуть всю историю наизнанку и заставить сомневаться в каждом кого видишь. Амнезия героини отлично обыграна - все ведут себя подозрительно в очень точных моментах еще больше накаляя сюжет. 

Иногда концовка наступает весьма неожиданно.

Каждый открытый CG так же вызывает новые ощущения. К трепету от близости примешивается паника и смущение. 

Обычно после второго-третьего пройденного героя примерно представляешь что будет в следующем руте, но нееееееет, с Амнезией это не так. Она постоянно меня удивляет.

Каждый из пяти главных героев по-своему прелестен:

Шин - хладнокровный ангел войны, но его чувства подобны раскаленной стреле, а  история настоящий детектив.

Икки - парфе из злости, ревности и обиды политое очарованием. Волшебство и проклятье. И никак не покидающее ощущение - какого черта я здесь делаю?

Тома - преданность на грани безумия, нежная и душащая, переплетающая историю в настоящий триллер. Только кому от кого надо прятаться?

Кент... вы любите математику? Охохохо, как сказала бы Рика. Он выделяется на фоне всех остальных своей нормальностью (?), поэтому мне наименее интересно о нем писать. Но ведь за безумцами сюда пришла только я одна, да?

Укио - мой пир во время чумы, черт из табакерки и настоящее сокровище... из-за моего упорства и нежелания подглядывать в гайды, он убивал меня больше 30 раз  =\ Я думала у меня сердце разорвется. И все равно я всегда выберу его. Тут мне сложно писать потому что плакали все: Укио, героиня и я. [strike]Я - больше всех.[/strike]

Плюсы сей новеллы:

- Отличная анимация героев, оригинальная японская озвучка со вздохами и придыханием.
- Сюжет, потому что амнезия!

17937918.review:
Amnesia : Memories is a wonderful visual novel that I highly recommend. The basic premise is that you as the main character are suffering amnesia, as well as basically a spiritual possession, and are attempting to regain your memories  and free the spirit from your mind.  

There are 5 total romanceable characters, all male.  The first 4 are available as soon as you start the game, the fifth one unlocks after finishing the good endings for the first 4 characters.  All of them have 1 good ending, 1 normal ending and between 1 and 7 bad endings.  They are all very well defined characters, with elaborate stories and very very different personalities.  You have a tsundere, a popular/playboy who yearns for real love, an intellectual who's aloof and bad with emotions and socializing, and 2 yandere characters that are on opposite ends of the yandere spectrum.  Each one of their stories take place on alternate dimensions, so even though the basic story premise is the same for each, the stories themselves are completely different and the side characters will sometimes have vastly different personalities in each route. As a fair warning, if you are someone who needs trigger warnings, you may have problems with one of the routes.

Getting the different endings requires making different selections during the story branches.  Each selection will either raise, lower, or leave your attributes in their current level of accumulation.  There is no stat raising or grinding, it's just a matter of selecting conversation options to raise or lower your trust, relationship and suspicion with each character.  There are quite a lot of branches, and it felt like there should have been more save slots available because of how many choices you have available.

The art is absolutely beautiful, the music and voice acting is great and fits in very well, the stories and characters are well written, and the translation is very accurate - though there are a very few spelling and grammar errors, it doesn't stick out horribly or detract from the experience.  After beating all the stories and endings there are also mini games, additional memories and short stories that follow up with the characters, leaving a huge amount of content in this game, it's really surprising how much content the game offers.

Pros:
+5 very different romanceable characters
+so many endings
+mini games
+unlockable bonus content
+art
+music
+story
+a 12 episode anime series you can watch elsewhere if the game isn't enough for you

Slightly Irritating:
~a few spelling/grammatical errors
~no obvious exit option in game 
~while you can customize controls, it doesn't tell you what the buttons do
~for some people the achievements aren't working (IF is currently working on fixing it)
~a character who goes too far
~could use more save slots

Cons:
-I can't really think of anything outright negative about this game.  :)

If you like anime and/or visual novels I really recommend you pick up this game, it is definitely worth the money, even at full price!

17886219.review:
Amnesia™: Memories is a fantastic game. Truly an otome game after my own heart, portrayed in a way that's great for those who are not generally fans of the gaming genre or looking to play their first one. Possessing beautiful graphics, an A+ storyline, as well as characters each with their own distinct opinions, feelings and identities, this game was well-worth the time I put into it and hopefully the start of many more otome games to come (to Steam). 

I found this game to be unique in it's large cast of characters and the relationship dynamics between them, both romantic and platonic. As well as the heroine there are three other girls, Sawa, Mine, and Rika (plus Ikki's crazy fangirls), who each have unique relationships between eachother and the heroine, and of course Waka, the manager, the authority figure of the group who while his personality might change from world to world, his essence does not. The verisimilitude of this game brought about by these dynamics was truly a breath of fresh air. 

Of course, no game is perfect. There seem to be issues with recieving the Steam achievments for this game (hopefully that will be fixed, the game is still quite new), I found Ukyo's good end to be a little anti-climatic (I'd already seen the anime, so that probably had an impact), the backgrounds were somewhat underwhelming (pointed out to me while I was broadcasting this game to a friend, though I think it helps to not distract from the characters), Orion was used a [i]little too much[/i] to portray the characters thoughts and feelings (of course, due to their bond he would know all about them), and I was a little concerned about how in Toma's good end [spoiler]after escaping the cage, kissing and making up with Toma, the topic of Toma's mental health and his extreme actions in locking the heroine in a [i]cage[/i] for her [i]protection[/i] were never properly adressed and discussed[/spoiler]. 

This game does possess some subjects that while horror visual novel fans might love, some might find triggering. This isn't an innocent, cutesy otome game. While there's no sex, there are mentions of it in discussions, as well as gory off-screen deaths involving fire, knives, roofs, etc. Plus [spoiler]Toma's cage *shudders*[/spoiler]. 

So to sum it up;
[list]
[*]great game,
[*]well-developed characters,
[*]unique storyline,
[*]a perfect start for those looking to try their first otome game or who are not generally fans of the genre,
[*]hopefully the start of many an otome game to come to Steam.
[/list]

If this looks like a game you would enjoy and you have money to spare I reccomend you purchase the game, both for the game itself and to show Steam and game developers that otome games have a viable market here.
