17871981.review:
TL;DNR- Very great VN. 9.5/10 Would forget about life again.

Now for the long version: this is quite possibly my favorite VN that I've played to date. I should start with a disclaimer that I'm fairly unusual in that I'm a straight male who generally prefers otome VNs, but if you can get over being a virtual girl chasing after virtual boys (or rather being a virtual girl being chased by virtual boys, I suppose) then I would recommend this VN to you regardless of your preferences... assuming those preferences didn't exclude VNs themselves, I suppose.

The story is fairly simple- you're a girl who lost her memories because I spirit crashed into your noggin or something and threw them across time and space and you gotta retrieve them by talking to a bunch of cute boys in parallel worlds who knew you before you lost your memories... that's about it (well, for the most part... the final arc has quite a bit more to it, but I'm not gonna spoil). Though this fairly simple setup allows it to focus more on the characters rather than developing a convoluted plot, and it does so very well. The writing is very good, dare I say quite exceptional by most standards, I found myself genuinely laughing and crying many times, it was really quite absorbing.

If I have any criticisms though, the first one would be the character design. Some of the characters look really good: I love the look of the Main Character (henceforth referred to as MC-chan because I'm a weeb and generally a terrible person) and Orion was cute... annoying at first, but he really grew on me; and Toma and Shin are both pretty good looking, but everyone else out of the main cast have outfits that look straight-up ridiculous... I mean, there's a character (Ukyo) who looks like he was a cab driver airlifted straight from the chessboard dimension... another character (Ikki) has what appears to be a tattoo of a spade on his face, which I assume they thought for god knows what reason accented nicely with his spade hairclip... like, what even the..? I mean, the boys themselves look really good, it's just their normal clothing is generally just absurd. I know this seems like a small complaint and it's totally subjective but considering you'll spend the majority of the game staring at them and reading text, if you don't like the way they look it can get pretty grating.

My second criticism is that in almost all of the CGs, MC-chan looks like a deer in headlights, like "OMFG HE'S KISSING ME WHAT DO I DO!?", even when there's no reason for her to do so. I mean I'm not exaggerating when I say that there was an instance in which I (and by proxy, she) asked a boy to hug her, he did, and she looked surprised that he did so in the resulting CG... like, why? Did she suddenly realize she left the stove on back home?

Other than that, there's a minor thing of the talking animations being... kinda lazy, it's basically characters just opening their mouths over and over again in the same robotic way until the speaking audio is done, it reminded me of the Putt-Putt games I played when I was a kid. That's pretty minor though since most of your game is spent looking at the bottom fifth of the screen reading text and listening to japanese voices anyways.

17871087.review:
This is the first dating sim and the first visual novel I've ever played.  I bought it entirely on a whim, mostly because it was on sale. 
And I LOVED IT.

Pros: 
-Amazing art
-Great characters, and not just the main love interests, all the characters
-Compelling storyline with multiple endings
-Relationships feel real and not forced (for the most part)
-Parameter system is quite helpful to find out how you are doing

Cons:
-There is the need to save spam in some instances, or you might die unexpectedly and lose a lot of progress
-Your helper spirit, Orion can be pretty annoying at some parts and is a master of stating the obvious
-Parameter system, while helpful, can't tell you what the boys actually want, leading to some frustration.
(For example, in one route I got a bad ending due to having too much suspicion. After restarting saves, micromanging descisions, and starting the route over again, I had to look up a walkthrough to find out that you have to be super lovey-dovey. but those descisions made him super suspicous so I always rejected those choices, leading to a getting an ending where he was too suspicious of me even though my suspision was as low as possible. Wow that was a long tangent/rant. Anyway.)
-One storyline is a bit fetish specific and may to off putting to everyone else
-The achievments are bit broken, for me at least. Totally did what the achievement told me to, but Steam won't give me it

Conclusion:
The pros massiy outway the cons. I really really enjoyed 4 out of 5 routes (sorry, just not into yanderes). This game is good for hardcore dating sim fans and people with just a passing interest, like me.

Amnesia is what you'd expect it to be for a visual novel read and choose the dialog options to decide your fate. There are a total of 5  arcs that took me 4-5 hours to 100% complete. There are a total of 5 routes 1 which is unlockable after completing the first 4 routes. The routes each have their own individual story lines according to who your love interest will be. The majority of the routes have 1 good ending, 1 normal and 2 bad endings some easier to obtain than others.

My favorite routes listed in order would be Kent , Toma , Unlockable route , Shin and Ikki 

Through out the game Heroin doesn't do much talking as orion the spirit who got stuck to you helps you regain your memories in each world in order for him to separate from you as explained in the introduction of each route.  He helps you as much as he is able which is mostly helping you in the very few ways he can since he isn't seen by other humans and can't touch any human objects.  The majority of the game orion is basically the narrator due to the Heroin doesn't speak much until she regains her memories the more she recovers the more she talks. This can be annoying in some routes but he generally grows on you in most of the arcs.

There's CG to collect, 2 Mini games based off of Shins route , unlockable  memories and some other extras to further the game telling the story of each love interest. 

PROs
Interesting Arcs
Verity of guys to choose from

nice extras
plenty of CGs to collect

CONs
Orion can become annoying (I know in 1 arc I was extremely irritated with him in)
some of the achievements can be tedious to obtain
certain themes may make some people uncomfortable
lots of reading (if you dislike reading but well this is a visual novel so what did you expect?)

17835518.review:
So, I've gone through majority of the game and I feel it's safe enough for me to review it thoroughly. 

9/10

Seeing that Amnesia: Memories is actually my first Otome game I've purchased and picked up, I really wasn't expecting much. I've played games like the Persona series and Harvest Moon series where there are these type of dating sims, but usually those games focused more on other types of gameplay (RPG and farming sim), but this is my first time picking a otome dating sim game where the main point of the game is to go through a span of 30 days with a chosen character where each answer and choice determines if you will be able to truly unlock the memories you've lost through Amnesia. 

I thought that after 1 or 2 routes, I would get bored, but I was wrong. I think the strong element that Amnesia: Memories has is its ability to make you continuously want to know what's going to happen next, if you picked the right choices and what the ending you will get. The plot for each 'world' you choose in order to retrieve your memories is determined by the character you interact with. Every route has its differences and you will see how your chosen character develops through the span of 30 days you are given to unlock your memories. I found myself doing my best to get to the bottom of each conflict in each route and when I successfully got through it and achieved the good ending of a route, I felt rewarded for my efforts. and when I got a bad ending, I'd be screeching at my computer wondering what the heck I did wrong. I never thought I'd be invested so deeply in a game where all I literally do is click buttons. 

Amnesia: memories caught my interest primarily because of its art. The CG images that are unlockable with each route and sprites are all so beautifully drawn. I also watched the anime that was revolved around this before I realized the game was coming out a week after I watched it. Watching the anime made me more curious about how the game would be and because of having that background, I was able to see how much more the game developed the characters and plot, something the anime could not (due to the amount of episodes). 

The reason I am giving this game a 9/10 and not a full solid 10/10 is because I think that after I have completed and unlocked everything, the game has close to no replay value. I think that if there was additional content or gameplay, there would be a higher chance of this game keeping my interest in the long run if I ever wanted to pick it up and play it again. Unfortunately, after I complete everything, there's not much for me to go back to.  Since this is my first otome game, I'm not sure if that's how otome games are or if there's differences in each one in terms of mini-games and gameplay. 

Nevertheless, I have been enjoying this game a lot. I am really happy that Amnesia: Memories was my first otome game. It left a lasting impression and I am eager to look into more otome games. I hope Idea Factory decides to localize the other games in the Amnesia series. I know I'd definitely be picking them up.

Gameplay: B+
Art: A+
Music: A
Storyline: A
Voice Acting: A+
Replay Value: C

17830729.review:
Okay, this game is really, really skeevy, and not in an intentional way.
The main character gets no say in her own recovery or life, hell she doesn't even get a SAY, period. She hardly ever speaks. Everyone talks over her and makes decisions on her behalf without consulting her or explaing the situation and we are supposed to find that endearingly protective instead of HOLY CREEP ALERT, BATMAN. That'd be bad enough already, but those decisions also happen to be life-or-death and incredibly over the top more often than not so it's doubly creepy to be subjected to that and not even get the option to feel mad about it.
I've only gone through two routes, but with how things are looking I have no motivation to keep reading. I'm seriously worried it might get worse (or even stay roughly the same, which wouldn't be comforting at all).

The routes I did were basically
A. "Almost get yourself killed in the name of MANPAIN with a dash of victim blaming"
B. "Forced isolation, gaslighting and attempted rape: Stockholm edition"
...and those were the "good" endings.

The main mechanic is supposed to be a balance of trust and suspicion, which would make for a really intriguing horror/suspense story. As things are, the mechanic doesn't even count for much, and the romantization of creepy and awful behavior makes it clear that wasn't what the game was going for.
The only positive might be the art, but it's hard to appreciate your abuser's pretty hair with all those red flags popping up around you.

17829710.review:
[h1][b] Quick Review [/b][/h1]

[h1] Overall Score: 8/10 [/h1]

[h1] Pro: [/h1]
[list]
   [*] Beautiful art
   [*] 5 Characters with very different stories
   [*] Mini-games
   [*] Many, many endings
   [*] Good voice acting
[/list]

[h1] Neutral (AKA more dependent on the player): [/h1]
[list]
   [*] Orion - You either love or hate him
   [*] Horror aspects - Expect to die horribly in this game more than once
   [*] Backgrounds - They are either artsy and refreshing to some or boring and empty to others
[/list]

[h1] Cons: [/h1]
[list]
   [*] Minimal save spots
   [*] Currently multiple bugged achievements
[/list]

[h1][b] What Can I Expect? [/b][/h1]

Top notch art, sound, and story for a reasonable price. Estimate about 30+ hours of gametime if you are a moderately fast reader. Even without all achievements up and running, there is plenty of reason to play through all of the game's many endings. Some style and story choices are hit or miss based on the player: such as Orion either being your best buddie or even worse than Navi. For those who cannot stand horror, this otome may not be for you. While there is little to no mention of gore, if you die you will know. Multiple stories have some involvement of people trying to kill you for one reason or another, so be prepared. Overall, these touching stories with decent character developement will leave you with a memorable experience.

First off: Not all of the characters are nice. I initially thought every character would be trying to sweep me off my feet, but it's not like that at all. You pick a single route to pursue and navigate your relationship with the chosen male character (and your other friends) in each playthrough. 

Secondly: There are multiple endings. For some reason, I had been lead to believe there were only the four routes and each had a single conclusion (which is ridiculous in retrospect).  A "bad" character may have multiple sides just as a "good" character does. Keep an open mind.

And finally, some have said this game is too hard. I disagree! Which I think I can do since this is my first time completing an otome game. I just had some fun exploring the options, saving often, and checking each character's reactions to my behaviour. Save often and if you absolutely MUST get the good ending, don't be afraid to consult a guide for some help.

One thing I disliked about this game was [spoiler] the diamond route. Toma's route [i]really[/i] creeped me out. I don't want to spoil much, even under a spoiler tag, but he's horribly abusive to the protagonist. However, all his actions are forgiven when she remembers she loved him prior to losing her memories, so they can be together now! Gross. Game would be better without that route. [/spoiler]

Overall, I would definitely say this game is worth the full price, although I bought it when it was on sale. If you like otome games, please buy this to support their english localization in the future!

17820402.review:
I am really conflicted about this game. On one hand, I think some of the plotlines are interesting, and I ended up really wrapped up in what would happen -- Shin and Ikki were my favorites by far. The character art is gorgeous, and I think that the game did an amazing job with the cliche amnesia storyline -- there's a lot you don't know but I felt like characters were suspicious when they should be and not when they shouldn't. There are things about the game that drive me crazy. 

The character you play is so passive. Orion ends up being the voice for nearly everything that happens and all the recapping irritated me. Yes, I know what that character just said, Orion, I was there and there's no need to tell me yet again. I have no idea why your character would even listen to what Orion is saying given that you don't know him and he's just a random spirit that invaded your consciousness and pushed out your memories. Honestly, the game would have been a 1000% better by cutting the part Orion plays in the story in half. I never fully get why in the Toma or Shin storylines you shouldn't call the police, other than Orion tells you not to, so it ends up making no sense at all. Not to mention how you spend the games supposedly trying to recover your memories, but in the Toma storyline you find your diary and then proceed not to read it for no good reason. Why even have you find it when you did when the game doesn't allow you to read it? Orion might have forgot, but the diary is my character's person, and she definitely didn't forget.

It seems like a lot of people liked Kurt, but I really didn't, and I was so frustrated when I realized there was no way to break up with him. I would have taken a bad ending death to end their relationship, but I couldn't, and in the end, Orion ended up telling me that Kurt was a nice guy, he cared for my character, and obviously my character had feelings for him. WTF. No, no she did not. Her dialogue throughout the path made that more than clear. You see this again at the end of Shin's storyline when your character is sympathetic and apologetic to Toma who was absolutely terrible. I hate it when games force you to think a way that's completely inconsistent with how you're playing your character. There should have been an option for you to say whether you forgive him or not. (The answer is definitely not.)

I was also a little disturbed by the fact that nearly every storyline but one includes either your love interest physically manhandling you in a way that's scary or uncomfortable, initiating sexual contact without consent, or telling you that something you've said or done is going to get you sexually assaulted. Seriously, game? Whether it's a boy that likes you but you don't like them back, or someone who's sexually interested in you while you're either unsure of your interest in them or don't have any interest at all, the game makes it sound like your character has done something wrong. Also, when the women in the game are jealous, they're crazy and murderous, when the men are, it's just because they love you so much. That's not a good message to send. Jealousy isn't sexy or romantic and shouldn't be portrayed like it is. (And as much as a personally liked Ikki's character, I wish the game had addressed the fact that the members of his fan club were all essentially magically roofied by his eyes. This game had so many consent issues in it, and that's before you get to crazy Toma.)

Also, while this is definitely less important than the other issues I had in the game. I really became sick of some of the repetive background art, particularly during Kurt's storyline where you seem to walk a lot but with no dialogue the repetition is both more obvious and tedious. As negative as I'm being about the game, I didn't hate it. I think it could have been a really amazing game, and I did like playing several of the storylines. But the physical and sexual aggression we see from guys we are supposed to like was a bit too far for me. I get it in Ukyo and Toma's storylines but I hate that it pops up in everyone single one of them.

17783773.review:
I played the Japanese version of this game way back 2013, and didn't get to finished it because of the language barier. Now 2015, it was surely surprising to see that this one got an English localization.  I bought it immediately and I was hooked! [i]This game is not related to the horror game Amnesia: A Machine for Pigs, this is an entirely different game.[/i]

[h1]Crazy boys, gorgeous art and some mystery.[/h1]
You play as a heroine whom Orion (a spirit) accidentally collided into, and because of that you lost some of your memories. In a span of 1 month you need to figure out whom to trust, what happened,  and piece it out (while the people around you should not know that you have lost your memory so you wont get taken advantage of). I've never had a dull moment in the craziness of some routes. Yes crazy I tell you, like [b]being caged[/b] or [b]almost dead[/b]!   Best of all it's 1080p (high resolution), compared to the original small scaled handheld game.

I have to recommend Amnesia:Memories  because of what it offers: a twist of fun, sweet,  and something crazy. With regards to the difficulty in picking the right direction for a good end to happen, feel free to refer to walkthoughs. I have to say I ran into the bad end multiple times without a guide because the choices are not obvious at all. Just remember that not all choices are good, which makes it even more challenging if you play it without the walkthrough.

[h1]Want more Japanese games to be tranlated to English?[/h1]
Diabolik lovers, Shinobi Koi Utsusu, Hakuoki, Norn 9?
I encourage you to try and buy this game! They're testing out the western market by releasing their first localized visual novel. If this happens to be successful, we can see more visual novels in the market!

[h1]New to Visual Novels?[/h1]
If you're still new to visual novels, think of it as reading a goosebumps book where you can choose how the story ends by picking a dialogue. However what makes visual novels a unique experience is that, you get well known voice actors in the anime industry to voice out the characters, gorgeous art,  mini games, and a friendly fan community.

[h1]Technical Stuff[/h1]
- Unlike the Vita port, you can't individually change a character voice level.
~ This is a straight console to pc port. They stilll use the Artemis engine.
+ Xbox360 contrller/generic controller supported
+ 1080p
+ Achievements
+ Steam Trading Cards & Badge
+ Minigame from the Vita port added. The original PSP version didn't have it.
+ Extra stories. The original PSP version didn't have it.

Choices and plot aren't super predictable like Voltage Inc. otome games.
Art is gorgeous and lots of CGs.
Music is varied and really fits the mood.

17744926.review:
My oh my, I have played/read a fair amount of VNs, but the writing of this one is on a whole new abysmal level...

Here's the short version: Bad pacing, too much convenience and a goddamn deus ex machina accompaning you sure ruin a story.

And now a bit of elaboration: This opinion is based on sitting through parts of the heart and spades route and mainly focus on the quality of the writing and to a degree the character design

First of all, in regards to the desgin, if the object (and let's face it it's little more than that) of interest of the spades route has a spade tatooed on his face, and yet somehow argues that sunglasses make the difference when it comes to recognition you know what to expect...

But the bigger issue is the writing.
I already mentioned you being accompanied by an incarnated deus ex machina, otherwise know as Orion and I want him to die. In a fire for example, though I am not too picky, anything should do the job.

As the games premise is you, the protagonist, losing all of her memories, it'd reasonable to expect that you would mainly portray apathy towards all of the people you used to know as they're nothing but strangers to you now. In theory the same would go for Orion, who is some kind of Spirit whose objective is to sever hiw tie to you so he can go his way. Specifying any further would be explicit spoilers, though the information is relayed within the first 10 or so minutes of the game.

However Orion acts as the protagonsit providing both your reactions and your motivation in all situations, with your choices, the only means of interaction you have, usually just change 1 to 3 lines of dialouge. Effectively whatever Orion says is what you say, even though he is supposed to be nonexistent fo ranyone but you, also he gets into it way too much...
Orion winds up being nothing but a bunch of plot convenience, e.g. with no explicit spoilers "Oh this route's guy is in some kind of problematic situation with local authoreties, we know he is innocent, but I'm worried nonetheless, and that means you have to be as well even though the story gave you no reason to." 

A story that utilizes amnesia as a story relevant tool has one simple advantage, you can forge all bonds and ties to other characters simulatniously to explaining them to the player, meaning, if used correctly you can combine exposition with story telling. It isn't used correctly though, while the protagonist was portrayed as worried I did nothing but shrug in apathy as the whole "conflict" was not an actual issue and easily debunked/resolved.

The story forces a linear approach on the player, even though the concept doesn't fit that kind of story-telling, causing a huge discrepancy between player and protagonist, having Orion being the actual protagonsit, rather than the player, he makes the calls, influences the interactions between characters and is nothing but a hypocrite in the process and that's putting it lightly...

By extension that also is quite telling in regards to the writer, here's some examples of the hypocracy and how it's bad writing:
1st. Orion thinks that Amnesia is treated by confining the patient to a hospital room or their home, took me about 5 minutes of using google to debunk that, he does however know what a goddamn maid cafe is.

2nd. He bases his opinion of humans on the subjective opinion of one of his acquantances and considers them greedy/egoistic, at the same time he thinks you would consider anything they say to be the truth and obey their every whim, making you little else but a toddler


This creates a fun little problem, you are treated as if, by losing all of your memories, you can not understand concepts such as lies, meaning that you wouldn't have common sense either, leading to apathy, otherwise you'd retain things such a common sense thus being able to do simple things such as saying "No" or debunking someones bullshit claims.  

Here is a direct quote from Orion to put some of the issues into perspective:
"Hee-hee. I'm pretty knowledgeable about human life, aren't I?"
The writer acknowledges the issue, but doesn't bother to fix it... We are talking about a commercial product here, if you know there is an issue fix it, you don't get a free pass by mentioning it and not giving another shit.

Now here is another fun quote:
"[...] try to actively meet people and investigate what kind of person you used to be."
This represents his initial motivation, as for plot related reasons he wants you to recover your lost memories, shortly afterwards however he ignores this objective in order to waste time on investigating an accident in order to make sure it was an accident.
You as the player get to point  out, that the clues at hand are insufficient to really bother wasting time on this investgation, but not a single fuck is given by Orion and by extension the writer...

I might not be the actual target group, being male and all, but I sure as hell can tell when a story is written in a bad fashion and the fact that some of the issues are acknowledged within the game is quite telling.
All I can say is: Don't bother if you are expecting quality, if you can just roll with all kind of bullshit and don't expect good writing, aka looking for a good laugh, this might be worth 20 bucks or less.

p.s. if you are wondering why I didn't use the formatting given by steam in certain places, that is because it didn't work properly

17743136.review:
Have you ever watched a Let's Play of a game? Have you ever watched one with an incredibly annoying narrator who talks about 10x more than the entire narration of the game and his attempts at being fun are just incredibly irritating?

Amnesia is an otome game about a girl who has lost her memories and must discover the truth behind who she is and her situation without arousing suspicion. You can choose from 4 different scenarios in which her life is different from each other. However, no matter which reality you pick, her life is pretty complicated, and you will need to get your bearings fast if you are to make the right choices. To make matters worse, in each world you are pursued by a green haired maniac hell bent on murdering you although the reasons aren't immediately apparent

Fortunately you have 4 hunks to help you out, though you can only pursue a relationship with one in each world. They each differ in personality and while they do have the typical Otome game borderline obsession with the comparatively bland protagonist it's very toned back in this game compared to your usual Otome game and they actually have conversations with you and other characters in which the subject of the conversation ISN'T you! For me this was a breath of fresh air since I was sick to death of the Twilight creepy obsession

I recommend this game, but only barely. And the reason for that is the opening paragraph of this review. For those of you who have played Legend of Zelda: Ocarina of Time, you will probably understand what I mean right away. Remember that fairy Navi? This game makes me wish I could have her as my companion again

You will be followed throughout the game by a shota boy with a chipmunk voice who learned to speak from watching the entire 7 seasons of Buffy the Vampire Slayer. He gets 75% of the dialogue in the game, no more than 2 sentences can be spoken before he gives his long winded, annoying and completely unfunny commentary, and there's no way you can get this little pest to shut up! The only positive thing I have to say about him is that at least he isn't PewDiePie

I recommend this game, and I recommend that every time you see an Orion dialogue bubble you immediately click past it. Annoying shota chipmunk schyzophrenic delusions aside this is the pinnacle of Otome games, so I recommend it!

17716436.review:
[h1]No, Amnesia: Memories isn't a [url=store.steampowered.com/app/57300]horror[/url] [url=store.steampowered.com/app/239200]game[/url], unless playing a female protagonist who can date four different guys (and maybe N from Pokémon) in a Japanese visual novel makes you break out into a cold sweat. If you keep reading, I’m going to assume you totally came here on purpose and share my strange passion for dating hot, fictional men who just can’t help falling for me…with the help of a walkthrough, anyway. (Sadly, I have a rotten personality and can never self-insert.)[/h1]

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=506376209

Hey look, otome fans: it’s Amnesia in English on Steam! Those who have been desperately hoping for an English localization of Amnesia (and may even be veterans of the Not-So-Civil Dialoveable-Amnesiac War) will probably get this regardless of reviews. I may just be writing this for my own amusement, but hey, why not? Maybe there's someone on the fence.

...Or in a cage.

Like many of the Japanese games making their way to Steam now, Amnesia: Memories is a port. Unlike most Japanese Steam games’ ports, however, this is Amnesia’s English debut, alongside a simultaneous Vita release. The text is all translated into English with the Japanese voice acting intact.  Fortunately, Amnesia makes a good transition from handheld to PC. Things that may seem like annoyances at first—such as being forced to left-click to progress the text—are easily overcome thanks to the ability to remap keys and controller support.

The game itself looks great in 1080p as well, with easily legible text, though close-ups of characters and backgrounds suffer from minor aliasing. While the character sprites and CGs are beautiful, the backgrounds seem like stock photographs and simple line drawings with your 12-year-old cousin’s favorite “Unicorn Diarrhea” Instagram filter applied. However, my BFF (who normally has good taste) calls them “stylized” and “appropriate” so it could just be my severe unicorn allergy speaking. 

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=506379697

Plus there are mini-games, so you get to beat your boyfriend(s) in air hockey and cackle maniacally at the first hint of their sad, sad anime boyfriend tears. Or if they beat you, [i]Oh my god I was playing in windowed mode and I accidentally Skyped my mom when I meant to fling the puck back at you, okay, so get over yourself, Kent.[/i] There’s also Inexplicably Violent Rock-Paper-Scissors if you prefer. (I would’ve enjoyed seeing additional mini-games, such as Flowerpot-Dodging or Knee-the-Yandere-in-the-Groin, but I understand that this is a visual novel first and foremost.)

Amnesia is a traditional, story-focused visual novel without any stat-raising; endings are determined entirely by the series of choices you make and the parameters those choices affect. Exploring alternate realities and unraveling the mystery of your past(s) is an intriguing approach that takes precedence over the romance in most routes, and completing all five routes is necessary to reveal the full picture. I recommend seeking out the bad endings even if you’re normally averse to your boyfriends hating, stabbing, or dismembering you. Then again, I probably took too much fiendish delight in finding new ways to get what’s-her-face killed.

Each route begins with already well-established relationships, though our heroine has to relearn (and hopefully remember) the exact nature of those relationships over one month. Having amnesia’s rough—even when you regain consciousness and immediately find out you have a hot boyfriend. Ikki’s and Kent’s routes felt like the best introduction to Amnesia’s setting and made the parameters feel especially relevant to the story. There’s no common route at all, so the scenes and events in each guy’s route are unique.

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=506377418

The love interests themselves were diverse and well-written, though how appealing the routes and characters themselves are likely comes down to personal preference. I [i]absolutely loved[/i] one route, enjoyed two very much, plodded through another because I totally already knew whodunit, and then one I fdgsffdgguyuggyhuyghgyuyuyuygugujyguyuyyujuyyhgnugngnnggyhdfrtgdhftrsgfd

Sorry, I must have gotten dizzy after recovering a repressed memory.

If you’re expecting light, breezy romance, this isn’t your best bet, but the feeling that you’re one misstep away from a horrible fate is far stronger in some routes than others. Your adorable giant bug sidekick Orion serves as the game’s main source of comic relief and also doubles as the heroine’s personality, because she apparently lost hers with her memories. I’m not a fan of “blank slate” visual novel protagonists (probably because of my aforementioned rotten personality), and it was off-putting that the MC doesn’t speak, with Orion reacting, thinking, and narrating in her stead. Luckily, Orion is the best. THE BEST. 

Even taking my (exaggerated) criticisms into account, I enjoyed Amnesia very much and am thrilled that it got such a fantastic English localization from Idea Factory International. It took me 47 hours total to complete all the routes with their many endings and they were hours very well spent. I hope this is the first of many Otomate releases on Steam and I’d love for Amnesia to help prove that there’s a market for Japanese otome games here.

One last thing—I forgot to make fun of the guys’ outfits, which made them look like they all rolled out of a Hot Topic going-out-of-business sale circa 1995 and woke up in a giant barrel full of rejected Final Fantasy characters’ belts decades later. There, my duty is now fulfilled; it is time for me to leave you. One day (probably today), you will forget ever reading this review…

[i]Note: The publisher provided each volunteer beta tester—including me!—with a complimentary Steam copy of the game as a thank-you for testing. Beta testers weren’t asked to write reviews (only bug reports), so this review is all me, baby.[/i]

17713447.review:
The only game in recent memory where you have to get senpais to notice you in order to get your memory back.

Amnesia: Memories is a port of a 2011 Playstation Portable visual novel, where the player takes control of a young woman who loses her memories and is forced to retrace her steps (and romance one of five vaguely-androgynous men) in order to get them back. Classified as an "otome" (girl) game, Amnesia is equal parts fascinating and hilarious.

The game starts with your character entering a spirit world, where a being named Orion tells you that he has somehow become lodged in your consciousness, and can't leave until you recover your memories. At that point, you gain the choice of one of four different paths (with one unlockable later), and you have to make decisions over the course of the story in terms how much information you gather and who you choose to romance/hang out with.

The most interesting part of Amnesia is that there's a lot of replay value. There are five distinct storylines, each with a wildly different set of situations and stories that occur. I was part of the beta testing team for this, and was initially struck by how separate each path is. The first storyline I played through (Shin's) had the characters attempting to solve a mystery, while the second was so off-the-wall that it might qualify as a parody of visual novels.

I know the opening line might seem a bit flippant, but that is the crux of the game. You can only trigger your memories by spending as much time as possible with your respective suitor(s), who have a bad habit of not revealing anything important to you until later on in the storyline.

From a plot standpoint, Amnesia is absolutely bonkers. In a good way, of course. The novelty of being a girl trying to collect information about her missing memories is balanced by a set of off-the-wall characters. Depending on which storyline you play, you'll run into a pair of childhood friends competing for your affections (one of whom locks you in a dog cage for half of his storyline), another teen who has somehow been gifted with the ability to be attractive to every woman he sees (thus explaining why he has a harem of girls who harass the player character) and a "Mr. Nice Guy" tutor.

The art style really sets this apart from other visual novels. Characters are expressive, blinking, moving their mouths and speaking in full Japanese. The backgrounds are generally detailed and varied, and there are nice interstitial moments that break up each scene.

There are also a pair of minigames that can be accessed through the main menu, but I didn't spend enough time to have much of an opinion. They're very simple (rock-paper-scissors), but are a neat diversion for anyone who wants to go for high scores.

In the end, Amnesia: Memories is one of the most interesting games I've played this year, and certainly among the best visual novels I've experienced in quite some time. It's well worth a look and offers a lot of value for the money.

Definitely worth a look.

17713126.review:
[Disclaimer: In no way, shape, or form was I compensated for the composition or publication of this review. This by my own volition. A review copy of the game was kindly provided by Ideal Factory International.]

Developed by Idea Factory under its Otome game brand Otomate, Amnesia: Memories is among one of the companies pioneering titles that finally gets a western release. And while Otoge or Otome games are meant to cater specifically toward a female audience, a male audience can also partake of them. The story puts players into the shoes of an unnamed female protagonist that has lost her memories after a strange incident. With help of mysterious young boy named Orion, the two work together to help make sense of the heroine’s past life, while trying not raise suspicion from friends and a boyfriend she never knew existed.

With Amnesia: Memories actually being my first Otome game and looking that is from the perspective of a newcomer, I do think that first timers like myself or those completely new to visual novels in general will be able to navigate it easily. For one, before you even start to meet the eligible bachelors, you will be able to choose who you want to interact with from the start by choosing a world – each holding a symbolic card corresponding to that person. You have the aloof Shin of the “Heart” world, playboy Ikki of the “Spade” world, his logical best friend Kent of “Club” world, and the big brother figure Toma of “Diamnond” world. There is a fifth guy and the route that puts all this into perspective, but needs to be unlocked by completing the others. Not only do each the routes play out differently depending on the world, but also changes how certain people will treat you. For instance, Waka, the manager at the place the herione works at is very nice in the “Heart” route, but his personality does shift greatly in others – going from docile to abrasive. This does apply to the other characters you meet as well to varying degrees, and serves as a nice change of pace to see how each route differs despite the feature being nothing new to visual novels.

Even though the main love interest and their personalities play into the typical paradigm most shoujo anime seems to reach for, I did honestly enjoy exploring the backstories of the guys I did go after. My favorite character would have to be the titular Shin, learning the reason behind his distant attitude that stems from a past event with his father. The writing is very simple in many ways and not that great when it comes to giving the story some interesting twist and turns, but still okay in its own right. The individual routes are fine on their own, but overall does fall short of being particularly great. That’s all I can offer on the subject without spoiling it. By the same admission, the characters themselves also aren’t as detailed as they could be, but still found them interesting. Especially in the case of Toma. Yup, very… fascinating personality shift for that guy.

Getting back to gameplay, the same orthodox process of reading text and making decisions at certain points become the norm like most visual novels, with one exception. Keeping with the theme of trying to piece together your life without letting your boyfriend be any wiser, the choices you make do have implications on 3 values: “Affection”, “Trust”, and “Suspicion”. The goal of is to ideally get a “Good” or “Normal” ending by keeping your Affection and Trust values high and Suspicion low. Again, depending on the choices, these values will fluctuate, so it is important to be mindful of what choices you make and keep tabs on your parameter menu frequently. Often or not, it is pretty easy to know how to response, yet can abuse the system by saving your game and seeing how a certain choice goes. In the event that you do have your Suspicion high, the game will continue, but will be able to get a bad ending more easily from making a wrong choice or simply getting the normal ending for that route if you happen to make it through successfully. Since replay value is a big part of games of this nature, it doesn’t hurt and obvious that making multiple saves will offer some assistance.

When you tire of trying to get through the story or even completed the game, besides viewing the CG library for illustrations, listening to tracks, or keeping track of the endings you received, the game does have two mini-games you can play at anytime: Rock-paper-scissors and Air hockey. There not the most interesting thing in the world, but it’s there if you need it as a brief diversion. I would like to detail this section, but since I never actually won a game, I will leave the outcome of what happens (if anything) to be a surprise.

On the aesthetic side of things, the artwork and animation for the game is very impressive. In a lot ways, the color scheme and style used kind of reminds me of that found in Steins;Gate, despite not having the same exact appearance or as drab. Animations are crisp and lively, and actually show off a lot of technical muscle such as changing the characters sprite angles (seeing them from the side or back) that really makes them come alive without having to go toward excess. My favorite animation would have to be of Ikki holding his signature sunglasses and smoothly slipping them on in the same scene almost like it was in one movement. The musical score is very genteel and well-done, piano pieces being the most prominent holding up the sentimental mood – that admittedly, tends get lost at various times. By the time you get through half of the routes it will become droning, yet mildly tolerable.

With visual novels gaining more acceptance and familiarity in the West, I do believe titles like Amnesia: Memories will be great boon for its biggest supporters. It definitely isn’t the cream of crop, especially when it comes to the overall writing, but still fairly remarkable in other areas like presentation and making that presentation work for it during the course of the game. While it won’t be for a couple of months until see Idea Factory’s other Otome offerings, Amnesia is a pretty pleasant harbinger of what to expect and do think this one will keep most fans satisfied for the time being.
